Exports were the key source of strength in the quarter with real exports increasing over 15 per cent, reflecting the success of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement.
It flows as well from the improving competitiveness of the economy instilled by government policies in the restructuring taking place in Canadian businesses.
The evidence of growth in its composition should buoy confidence in the economy. Most forecasters will revise their 1992 annual average growth rates back up to the 2 to 2.3 per cent range. Some no doubt will go higher. This will put them back in the range the Minister of Finance has consistently referred to since Statistics Canada revised 1991 growth after the budget.
The undue pessimism of some forecasters such as the Conference Board will now surely stand in even greater contrast. We are clearly on the right track. We must stay the course. Clearly the Minister of Finance and his predecessor have served Canada well.

Mr. Speaker, Rudy Wilczek, my constituent, and 25 of his co-workers at Revenue Canada's Pearson airport customs and excise office, postal division, will have a hard time celebrating Canada's 125th birthday on July 1. They will be waiting for the unemployment office to open on July 2 to join the growing list of unemployed people in Toronto.
As of July 1 the customs and excise branch will hand off responsibility for collecting duties on international mail to Canada Post. Canada Post has retained employment agencies and a few students to do the work formerly done by customs and excise officers. The employment agencies will cost more than the officers did.
Worse yet, Revenue Canada, which for months has promised to find jobs for these displaced workers in other divisions issued lay-off notices to them effective July 1. Every time this group of Canadians watches one of the government's expensive feel-good ads for Canada's 125th birthday, they, like many unemployed people in Toronto, cannot help but feel the painful irony of this government.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to bring to the attention of all members of the House the seventh annual Canadian Occupational Health and Safety Week. It began yesterday and continues until this coming Saturday, June 27.

June 22, 1992
We are moving toward an economy which is becoming increasingly advanced technologically. Consequently, we have to pay more attention to safety and health in the work place. The education and retraining of workers in response to these rapid changes must always incorporate the highest levels of safety awareness.
Strong emphasis must be placed on learning in the modem world of work. Accordingly, this year's theme is "Planning: Your Investment in Health and Safety". Business and labour share a joint responsibility to ensure that all activities related to the work place are studied in a spirit of co-operation. In this way, avoidable accidents can be reduced significantly.
On the occasion of Canadian Occupational Health and Safety Week, I ask my hon. friends to bring the challenges of this issue to their constituents' attention. In so doing, we may all one day be able to point with pride to the commitment which has made us the leading nation in the care and protection of all our workers.


125TH ANNIVERSARY OF CONFEDERATION

Mr. Speaker, in this 125th year of Confederation, it is important more than ever before to celebrate Canada Day, even in the current political climate. There are a number of reasons why we should be optimistic. As we all know, Canada is an exceptionally beautiful country, endowed with exceptional riches. We should never forget that Canada is a democratic society. In a world tom by hatred, persecution and fanaticism, Canadians have always been known for their tolerance. This tradition helped us build a country on half a continent that has become a symbol to all of peace, prosperity, comfort and freedom, so much so that last year we were ranked by the United Nations as the best place in the world in which to live.
In fact, if we look at the news, we realize that our problems are minimal, compared with those endured by
most of humankind. By building on our traditions, we will be able to solve our problems and offer a better life to all Canadians.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today's Vancouver Sun contains an article questioning the success of the Voyageurs '92 program. The article draws a damning picture of a last minute program lacking adequate support, organization and community interest. There was a lot of negative and a lot of bunk.
I will tell you about the positive. The Fraser Valley Broadcasters, the Metro Valley Newspaper Group and the Times joined together in a united community media effort to get the Voyageurs off the ground in my riding, and what a job they did.
We have two groups heading off to Pontiac, Gatineau and Labelle tomorrow and are they excited.
We have already seen two groups come to the Fraser Valley and they had a great time. The Sto:lo Nation and Tribal Council put on a cultural extravaganza including, dancing, food, a visit to a First Nations police training centre, a tour of the valley and Vancouver. The groups rode the gondola across Hell's Gate on free passes. The officers at CFB Chilliwack took the kids water skiing on Cultus Lake. There was a trip to Victoria, there was an all-night block party and a barbeque to close things off.
We have churches, veterans associations, schools and service clubs like the Hope Rotary and Lions all working together. This does not sound very negative to me. It sounds like the community got together to celebrate Canada and being Canadian.
A lasting impression was made that will do more for Canadian unity and personal development than all the negative media in the world.
Voyageurs '92, making great Canadian history yet
again.
June 22, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister.
Throughout the worst recession since the Depression, the government has repeated incessantly that it was not to blame. It repeated that the recession was caused by the world situation and that other countries were also performing poorly.
However, in its 1992 report on competitiveness, the World Economic Forum showed that Canada's competitiveness has fallen from fifth to 11th place. The truth is that Canada's economy fell faster and deeper than in any other comparable country.
How can the Prime Minister deny his responsibility and deny the fact that Canada has the worst growth in goods and services of the industrialized world?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, notwithstanding the fact that we have experienced a weak world economy, I think everyone should be encouraged by the first quarter results that have just been revealed today which show there has been a growth of 1.7 per cent in the Gross Domestic Product which indicates that there have been four consecutive quarters of positive growth. I think all Canadians should be heartened by that development. At least we certainly take comfort over here, notwithstanding the fact that we would like to see that growth more robust than it actually is.
With respect to the world competitiveness report, I would remind the hon. member that the data on which this report made its finding is stale dated. It is basically based on last year's evidence when Canada's inflation rate was 6.2 per cent, which was the worst inflation rate in the industrialized world. That has improved to 1.3 per cent.
The hon. member should also take cognizance of the fact that the government has embarked upon a very
Oral Questions
aggressive competitiveness and prosperity initiative, some of which we are seeing in the growth figures today.
An advertising campaign.

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: We are seeing a 2.5 per cent improvement in productivity in the first quarter of this year.

Mr. Speaker, Statistics Canada confirmed what 1.5 million Canadians have known for the last two years, that this has been the worst and the deepest recession since the Great Depression.
After winning the 1984 election, the Conservative government launched a budget.
In the government's first budget eight years ago, it said its plan was to foster higher investment, greater innovation and increased international competitiveness. Eight years after announcing that plan, Canada has gone into a free fall from fifth to 11th place in international competitiveness.
In the same budget, the Conservatives said: "It is an ongoing priority of this government to encourage much improved research and development performance in Canada''.
How does the Prime Minister explain that eight years after this promise, Canada ranked last in research and development among industrialized nations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is categorically and absolutely wrong when she suggests that this downturn and this recession has been the worst since the 1930s.
She should know, and I will tell her what statistics will reveal. The peak to trough decline in 1981 was something in the order of 5.3 to 5.5 per cent. The peak to trough decline in this recession is something in the order of 3.6 per cent. That is a remarkable difference.
In so far as her point with regard to competitiveness and productivity, I remind the hon. member to look at the data that has been released today. She will find that the recovery is led by merchandise trade, by export trade and by improvements in our productivity. That should be good news to all Canadians.

June 22, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, his own document from Statistics Canada says: "This is the first time since the Great Depression that the economy has shrunk two years in a row".
It's report card time across this country and the World Economic Forum has issued a failing grade to the Government of Canada. We ranked last in balance of trade. Canada ranks last on export market diversification. We ranked last in research and development. We ranked second last in merchandising training. We ranked second last in manufacturing. We ranked third last in the industrialized world in competitiveness.
How can you claim that your competitive agenda is succeeding when all world indications show that Canada is failing the challenge of competitive economy?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is hard to believe the rhetoric of the hon. member because she was in the House last week. She would know that merchandise trade has improved.
As a matter of fact, exports have increased by 15 per cent. That is one of the reasons why we have had a 1.7 per cent increase in Gross Domestic Product in the first quarter of this year. Merchandise trade exports are at a record all-time high for the last two or three months. That is because we have a free trade agreement and because most of that trade is being done with the United States.
It is because we have taken initiatives to improve and enhance productivity and enhance competitiveness. That is why we are producing such good results that will be translated into jobs and further economic opportunity.

Mr. Speaker, the latest leaked draft of the North American free trade agreement shows that Mexico will not capitulate as Canada shamefully has to U.S. energy demands. Mexico, unlike Canada, will not be forced to make up for U.S. shortages if there is a North American shortage.
Does this government not find it thoroughly embarrassing and thoroughly humiliating that Mexico has cut a better deal on energy than Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is somewhat outdated in terms of what is likely to be in the energy package.
He is looking at or quoting Mexico's early draft. He will find that in terms of the negotiating text that we are now considering there are areas of disagreement. We have no final text. In that final text he will find that we are doing quite well in terms of resolving the energy differences between Mexico, the United States and Canada.

Mr. Speaker, under this text, which was apparently negotiated two weeks ago, if there are any energy shortages, Mexico will not be forced to divert scarce supplies to the United States, but Canada will.
If the government cannot negotiate a more favourable energy agreement, an agreement which is at least as favourable as Mexico is obtaining under this deal, if it cannot do that, will this government refuse to sign the North American free trade agreement?
Once again Peterson has his facts wrong.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
I will repeat what I said before, Mr. Speaker.
It is very clear that my hon. friend is looking at an early draft which was not a Canadian draft. I would also like to remind him that there is such a thing as the International Energy Agreement which a previous government signed on behalf of Canada.
Which happened to be Liberal.
It happened to be a Liberal government. There is no question at all, we do not have a final text on energy. Our opportunities are to open up the Mexican market for Canadian goods, including energy.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
The minister responding for the Minister for International Trade has just said: "Well we are all dealing with early drafts of the Mexican and NAFTA talks". Perhaps if members of this House and Canadians knew what this
June 22, 1992

government was negotiating instead of being told: "Well nc, after it is signed", we could have an intelligent debate on what is in the NAFTA agreement.
Based on the reports today, it seems clear that this government is intent on taking a bad deal, the Canada-U.S. trade deal, and making it worse in the NAFTA deal by reducing our ability to control Canada's petrochemical energy industry, giving the U.S. more access to our energy resources and reducing Canada's ability to effectively conserve and manage our own energy resources.
Mexicans have had the guts to stand up and say: "No, you will not touch our energy resources". Why does Canada back down and why is Canada giving away our energy resources when Mexico refuses to do so?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the North American free trade agreement will not tie Canada's energy resources closer to the United States. That is another misconception being promulgated by the New Democratic Party that never wanted a free trade agreement in the first place because it is afraid of trade.

A supplementary, Mr. Speaker.
The New Democratic Party is not afraid of trade. We want fair trade. The minister is afraid of giving a real answer and letting Canadians know exactly what is going on in these trade talks.

The minister knows the Canadian Constitution gives the provinces control over their natural resources. However, it seems the proposed trilateral agreement would include areas under provincial jurisdiction, including that of provincial power companies.
Before going any further, does the federal government intend to consult the provinces about their provincial power companies?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there have been consultations and discussions with the provinces all through the free trade agreement negotiations. The provinces have met with the Minister for International Trade from time to time and they have
Oral Questions
met with the negotiating team from time to time. There is no question at all that the provinces know exactly where we are going and trying to go in this negotiation.
As far as energy is concerned, I do not understand why the New Democratic Party does not want improved opportunities for Canadians, particularly those from the west, to sell exploration production techniques all to do with the petrochemical industry.

Mr. Speaker, a supplementary for the Acting Prime Minister.
It is clear that in the draft that is available, through the news media not through this House of the NAFTA agreements, this government is signing an agreement which appears to extend into areas of provincial jurisdiction, namely to provincially-owned electrical utilities. There is no exemption cited in this chapter for provincial electrical utilities.
I again ask the Acting Prime Minister: Is it this government's intention to encroach on the constitutional right of provinces to control their own resources and utilities, yes or no? Will this government be clear that in fact provinces will have a say in any area that will affect their jurisdiction?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, that is why we have been consulting with the provinces right from the beginning, so that we will not do anything outside of the provincial jurisdiction. We want the provinces to be onside with us. We have made special attempts to have them onside with us. There is no question at all that we want an agreement that will be of benefit to all Canadians and of benefit to those provinces that have the resources.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
The minister will know that on the great northern peninsula of Newfoundland, and indeed including western Newfoundland, there has been a 67 per cent decline reaching 71,000 metric tons in cod landings over the last seven years and representing the longest and deepest

Oral Questions
decline in gulf cod landings recorded since 1960 by the federal department of fisheries.
The cod industry in western Newfoundland is in crisis. I want to ask the minister of fisheries what action the Government of Canada is going to take to rebuild the gulf cod stocks and what action, both immediate term and long term, the Government of Canada is going to take to assist the fishermen and fish plant workers who are being dislocated, displaced economically, because of this crisis in the gulf cod stocks.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we are continuing to manage the gulf fishery in accordance with the advice which we receive from CAFSAC and our Canadian scientists.
There has been a considerable decrease in the total allowable catch of the cod stocks in the gulf in the last several years, and in accordance with the scientific advice the total allowable catches have been reduced.
There is not any immediate crisis that I know of in that particular stock at the present time, with the exception that we have had to restrict mobile gear vessels because of the size of the cod that were being caught and because of some other activities which had to be discouraged.

Mr. Speaker, this member wants to assure the House that I want to work with the minister and with the government, but it is difficult to do that when the minister says there is not any crisis, when landings have gone from over 90 million pounds in 1982 down to 30-odd million pounds in 1991, and when there has been a 67 per cent decline in cod landings.
I want to quote to the minister from a report done for him by his department in December 1990, by William Steele of the program co-ordination and economics in the gulf region office. The report says in its conclusion, and I quote from the minister's own report: "The cod industry in western Newfoundland is in a crisis. The fixed gear fishery in western Newfoundland is at a point of no return if there is no strategy to rebuild the cod stocks in the near future".
That report is 24 months old and the rate of decline has continued over the last 24 months. What has the minister done since December 1990 to halt this crisis in decline in cod stocks? What is he doing now to rebuild
those cod stocks and to assist the fishing families who are severely affected by this crisis; yes, a crisis in the cod fishery?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, there are no new figures being produced by the hon. member today.
There is no new fish either.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
If I am allowed to answer I will answer. There is nothing new in the figures that have been announced by the hon. gentleman today. These total allowable catches were set some months ago based on the scientific advice we received from CAFSAC, from the Canadian scientists.
Because the hon. member rises in this House and shouts across the House does not make a situation a crisis. The cod stocks in the gulf are certainly cause for worry. Small cod were being caught in large numbers which had to be stopped, particularly by mobile gear vessels. The facts have been known for months and there is no sudden crisis today in the gulf.

Mr. Speaker, for some reason the minister is choosing today to downplay this problem. He knows that fishery in the gulf and the Atlantic fishery generally are in an absolute tailspin.
He has seen the numbers for 3PN and for 4R. They are even worse than the numbers for northern cod, as bad as they are. I say to him that no other industry in Canada is being so pulverized. This is the prairie drought of the 1930s.
People in his riding and mine are losing their homes. They are having their cars repossessed. They cannot buy the groceries. They need some money now. What is he going to do about it?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we all know with reference to the northern cod stock that in the province of Newfoundland in particular there is a serious problem in connection with the fishery. We also know other stocks are under heavy pressure.
There is no sudden emergency that has just occurred with reference to other fisheries. There are difficulties in other fisheries as well. We have brought in programs, as we did last year, to meet those difficulties. I refer to the
June 22, 1992

ice compensation program and others that were brought in last year.
Never in the history of Canada since Newfoundland joined it have so many programs been brought in to deal with problems in the fishery. They will continue to be brought in if the problems continue. It certainly seems likely with reference to the northern cod stock.

Mr. Speaker, all the reports tell the minister the contrary. We tell him the contrary. The fishermen's catches tell him the contrary. If he wants to paint a picture and say it has never been so good, if he enjoys that thought, let him get his jollies from it.
Will the minister answer the question? Fishermen and plant workers in Lawn and St. Lawrence with whom I met over the weekend and people along the southwest coast and the northeast coast in Nova Scotia are all hurting. They are really hurting. They are all asking the same question, and I am going to put it to the minister now, much as they put it to me.
When is the minister going to make a move? They are not talking about a song and dance to say how rosy the picture is. When is he going to make a move, a substantive move? When will he do something for those people at least to keep the wolf from the door for them?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in my opinion the hon. gentlemen is not serving the people he represents very well when he tries to exaggerate like this and when he deliberately distorts what I have said.
Has anybody else in the House heard me say how rosy the fishery picture is? Did I say that today?
No.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: Did I say today that never in history has the fishery been as good?
No.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
This is the kind of exaggeration that does a disservice to this serious problem in Newfoundland which we are attempting to deal with and which will not be helped by purported hysteria by the hon. gentlemen opposite.
Oral Questions SEXUAL HARASSMENT

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Associate Minister of National Defence.
A woman soldier at CFB Comox has been harassed by superior officers. She has been called a "sexretaiy", a "biker mama", and asked about her dating habits. She has been subjected to other comments that I cannot even repeat in the House of Commons.
Her allegations of sexual harassment were inadequately addressed through military channels and now she is taking her case to the Human Rights Commission, but she is still being harassed. Her job has been threatened.
What will the minister do now to protect her while the matter is being investigated?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yes, I am aware of the situation. It is an extremely unfortunate one. While I cannot comment on the individual's situation because indeed she has both redress of grievances in the system as well as a case before the Human Rights Commission, directions have gone out to the base commander to deal with this issue.
I understand certain actions have been taken, but there will be a further investigation to make sure. No woman should have to work in an environment which is poisoned as a result of sexual harassment.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the minister's response, but since this woman went public the women's centre near the base has been inundated with further stories of harassment on military bases; in fact they are coming from all around the province now. One of these women herself is being threatened with a court martial.
The Robichaud human rights case ruled against DND several years ago and said it was a responsibility of DND to provide a work place free of sexual harassment.

June 22, 1992
Oral Questions
What is the minister prepared to do now to stop this harassment and protect women members of the military?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to advise my hon. colleague that indeed there is a very good policy in place within the Department of National Defence dealing both with the military side and the civilian side.
Of course a policy is only as good as the way in which it is implemented. That is why the chief of the defence staff has taken this issue very seriously. We have incorporated into all of our training exercises for our base commanders just as recently as two weeks ago further information and education on how to provide harassment-free work places. This will be ongoing and every effort is being made to educate individuals about their rights as well as supervisors about their responsibilities to deal with the issue effectively.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
The government's constitutional plan seems far from certain. While the minister has refused to declare which of the many options he and the government prefer in order to overcome the current impasse, the clerk of the Privy Council is now embarking on a national tour of provincial capitals while the associate clerk is advocating a constitution based on the Belgian model, which would have serious repercussions for our national government role as well as linguistic rights.
I ask the minister quite simply: What is the government's constitutional blueprint and what is the government's action plan that will guide its deliberation in the next and important few days?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the House knows, we have made considerable progress on a Canada round of negotiations.
We have progress yet to make on four major issues. One is the Senate. A second relates to the amending formula. A third is to ensure that we have means to bring down barriers to trade in Canada. A fourth is to ensure there is agreement on a package relating to aboriginal Canadians.
At my instruction, the clerk of the Privy Council and other senior officials are meeting today in Halifax with senior officials of the Governments of Newfoundland, Prince Edward Island, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia.
They will meet in Calgary tomorrow with senior officials of the Governments of British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, and later I believe in Ontario with the Government of Ontario, not to negotiate but to determine where people are on each of those major points.
Then the Prime Minister and I, tomorrow night probably, will come to a view as to the next step we would recommend in this constitutional process. We very much hope that it will be possible for us to achieve agreement among governments.
That is our goal. That is what we are seeking to do. If we can get co-operation from enough governments across the country, as I hope we can, that is the way we will proceed.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is directed to the same minister.
I think Parliament has a right to know exactly what the federal government's plans are, and it expects the government to be clear about legislation that is very important to all Canadians.
Why will the minister not reveal the next stage in the federal government's plan? Will there be a First Ministers' Conference? Will Parliament be recalled to consider a new agreement or a referendum? Does this government really know when we can expect an end to this constitutional dilemma?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think a number of things are clear. First of all, sometime after mid-July, the Government of Quebec wants to start public hearings and consideration by the committee which is to examine what the Quebec
June 22, 1992

legislation refers to as Canada's offers. One way or another, the Government of Canada must prepare a Canadian position.
Actually, our government would prefer to have an agreement supported by the other governments in Canada. That is what we are seeking now. However, if it is impossible to get an agreement with the other provinces, then the Parliament of Canada will have to get ready to prepare proposals for consideration by the Government of Quebec.
For the time being, I can give no indication whether there will be another multilateral conference to seek an agreement by the various governments. If it is feasible, if there is a very real possibility an agreement can be reached, then of course the Government of Canada will convene another ministerial meeting to finalize such an agreement.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
We learned this weekend that the federal government commissioned just one independent technical study before it committed $80 million in loan guarantees to the owners of the Westray coal mine.
We also learned that the energy department bureaucrat who conducted the review spent-and I want to underline spent-a meagre 18 hours reviewing safety and other issues at this mine.
Why was the Government of Canada content to spend only 18 hours reviewing the safety aspects before pouring $80 million into the Westray coal mine?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member already has the documentation. It is very clear that the CANMET report, which is the report to which he is referring, was a study of several other reports that had already been done and it was a report that concluded that the mine was technically feasible. It concluded that on the basis of at least three other large reports that were done by consultants.
Oral Questions

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister is contradicting his colleague, the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism somewhat. He said in the House on June 5, and I quote: "We did further studies of a technical type in order to make sure that our loan guarantee was reasonable".
We now know exactly the technical study which was done. It was an 18-hour review consisting of nine pages authorizing $80 million for the Westray coal mine.
Again I ask the question of the Deputy Prime Minister. Why was the Government of Canada content with only an 18-hour review, a nine-page summary of information with no further technical studies done to pour $80 million into the Westray coal mine? Why was there such gross negligence by the Government of Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows, because he has had the documentation available to him for some time, that every party in the negotiation had its own interest. We had to be able to insure the bank loan.
We had the CANMET review. Eighteen months after the CANMET review we provided financial assistance for this project. ISTC undertook detailed economic and financial investigations of this project. The Bank of Nova Scotia undertook detailed technical, economic and financial investigations. The Government of Nova Scotia undertook to ensure that this project could be done, was technically feasible and could be done safely.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Defence. Many Canadians agree that Canada has too many military bases and that military bases must be closed.
The panel formed to provide guidance for the process has recommended that the decisions for closing bases be established on the basis of national security and not on considerations of regional development.
When future closures of military bases are made, will these closures be in line with the recommendations of this committee?

June 22, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as my hon. colleague knows, the work which that committee did was excellent and the report has now gone to the Standing Committee on National Defence and Veterans Affairs which has been hearing witnesses on it.
We will obviously await the recommendations of that committee. Our own department is reviewing the recommendations, as will other departments as it has implications for them as well.
Once this process is completed I hope we will have in place a good process by which we can evaluate the requirements for future bases. Until that process is in place, the minister has already indicated that there would be no base closures until that matter is finalized.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to put a question to the President of the Treasury Board.
As the minister knows, the Minister of Public Works brought forward a submission to refurbish St. Andrew's lock and dam and the submission was put over for further review. The minister also knows that the most recent safety report on the bridge states that the best case scenario is that the bridge would have to be closed by the end of this calendar year if not sooner.
With the greatest respect, I would like to ask the minister, what further review is necessary, what timeframe has been assigned this review and when will this issue once again be reviewed by Treasury Board?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the hon. member for his question. I appreciate his concern.
We are reviewing the over-all program of public works. In the absence of the Minister of Public Works I would like to say that this particular department is monitoring very attentively the conditions of the structure and it is carrying out the emergency repairs as they are needed.
That being said, we are also aware that there will be ongoing discussions with the Government of Manitoba and they will discuss the future of this facility.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of energy and it concerns the Westray mine.
Given that of the thousands of pages of documents tabled in this House, the only ones referring to a report by and for the federal government relate to the so-called 18-hour report, and given that there were a number of requests filed through access to information for the release of materials on the federal role in the Westray mine, will the minister assure the House that any information released will automatically be tabled in the House or with the Clerk of the House if the House is not in session?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, once again there seems to be some implication that the CANMET report was not a significant report. The CANMET report surely was significant because it reviewed at least three major technical papers having to do with whether this mine was feasible or not.
In terms of tabling information we are, of course, prepared under the Access to Information Act to look at whatever is available.

Mr. Speaker my supplementary question is for the same minister.
It is rather interesting that there is such heavy emphasis put on the CANMET report, when of the approximately 1,000 pages which were tabled, a mere nine concerned the CANMET report.
Given that Justice Richard, appointed by the Nova Scotia government to examine the Westray mine disaster, has indicated that he does not have jurisdiction to examine the federal government's role at Westray, will the minister explain what the process will be to allow for a full examination of the role of senior public servants opposed to the mine, the involvement of the Minister of
June 22, 1992

Oral Questions
Public Works in pushing for the mine and of the involvement of the Prime Minister?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, both Judge Richard and the inquiry council have said that they are satisfied with the mandate of the inquiry. They have indicated they will inquire into the federal involvement in the Westray mine where they believe it is necessary. Of course, we will co-operate with the inquiry. We have always said we would co-operate with the inquiry.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Secretary of State.
This year, the Government of Canada will expunge $55 million in accounts receivable because of its failure to trace people who default on their loans under the Student Loans Program. We are talking about $55 million in taxpayers' money.
Will the minister establish a line of authority this year for the recovery of student loans, because today, the banks, the universities and a number of students could not care less about taxpayers' money?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can inform the hon. member that I have already started discussions with the provinces, students and other groups for the purpose of improving the process.
There are problems with the program. We are aware of the problems and we know the rate of loan defaults, but I have also started negotiations with financial institutions to develop a new financial structure for the program, in order to reduce payment defaults and make the program more efficient.
I can give all members of this House the assurance that this thorough review of the program is progressing very well and that by the end of the year we will be able to make an announcement in this respect.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Solicitor General.
Last week the Solicitor General told us that occasionally he is required to be aware of the names of former CSIS informants on a need to know basis. However, he did not say anything about previous solicitors general or their political staff.
Will the minister tell this House whether the CSIS targeting committee was ever forced to permit the presence of political staff at its meetings between 1986 and 1990, thereby allowing the names of informants to be disclosed to these staff?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, naturally I am not in a position to say what happened under previous solicitors general. I have no reason to believe there has been any change in the process that would lead to the conclusion my hon. friend has made.

Mr. Speaker, will the minister agree today to assist us on this, to provide to the subcommittee on national security the rules governing informants and will he assure Canadians now that information about informants has not been used for any political purpose by his office or by the offices of members of cabinet?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I can assure my hon. friend that if he wishes to enter into discussions with the Security Intelligence Review Committee on that particular matter, I am sure its members can apprise him of whatever information is available which it is possible to reveal.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare.

June 22, 1992
Oral Questions
Immediately after last week's meeting of the federal and provincial ministers on medicare, the minister publicly questioned the high cost of providing medicare to the elderly.
Could the minister please indicate to the House why he has singled out the elderly? Does he not understand that these people have paid for medicare all their working lives so they would not have to worry about some government in their future deciding they are too old to be taken care of?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is quite an extension to what I said last Thursday.
I will explain to my colleague that first, figures were provided by the province of Manitoba minister which showed that 50 per cent of the cost to the health care system is due to costs for people over 70 years of age. But I said, and he should know this, that there is no way the health care system which we have today, based on the five principles, will not apply to senior citizens. It means that any request for care by a senior citizen under the Canada Health Act will be provided. There is no reason to make any cuts.
We must consider the appropriateness of the ways and means we use money at all levels, particularly at this one. It does not mean that the ministers said there would be cuts. They said they will make an analysis of expenses to see the way to do it.
I repeat what I said, I confirm and I will always say that the five principles will apply, particularly to senior citizens.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the same minister. The minister will know that when he introduces facts like 50 per cent of the cost goes to people over the age of 70, those people are sitting there listening to the minister speak and are very concerned about whether or not they are going to be under additional pressure.
The minister will also know that he has a responsibility to all Canadians under the Canada Health Act, despite pressures coming from the provinces, to defend medicare for everyone.
I would ask the minister to assure the House that he is not about to introduce any amendments to increase the so-called flexibility to the provinces.

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I repeat, I never said that.
May I ask the member something? How does he think the senior citizens consider a member who, when the minister said something is not true, repeats time after time that the minister said that? What do we call that kind of member?

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State. Last week, the Government of Ontario announced at the convention of the Association canadienne-frangaise de I'Ontario that the provincial government intended to help fund two French-language colleges in Ontario. When will the federal government also announce that it is taking part?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, negotiations not only with the Government of Ontario but also with other governments are going well. Agreements in principle have been negotiated. Funding, specifically the amounts to be allocated, is being discussed. The government will make an announcement on this in a reasonable time, further to the discussions that have taken place so far.

Mr. Speaker, there is great concern in the francophone community in Ontario about the fact that some 50 per cent of those who participate at the elementary and secondary level drop out at the post-secondary level. They are anxious to know when this government is going to make its announcement that it has committed itself, as has the Ontario government, to the quick initiation of these two colleges.

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, negotiations have been ongoing for six to eight months with Ontario, as they have with other provinces. They are going very well and I think we have reached an agreement in principle on all the issues. The
June 22, 1992

Routine Proceedings
Government of Ontario must recognize that the provincial governments, not just Ontario but B.C., Saskatchewan and Alberta, have to introduce legislation to make something like this happen. We are talking about the monetary side of the equation. Negotiations are proceeding. In due time we will make the announcement.

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 32(2), I have the honour to lay on the table copies, in both official languages, of the annual report of the Correctional Investigator for the year 1990-91.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
subsubtopic: SECOND ANNUAL REPORT ON EXPORT OF MILITARY GOODS FROM CANADA
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I have two tablings today. Pursuant to Standing Order 32(2), I have the honour to table, in both official languages, copies of the second annual report on the export of military goods from Canada.

subtopic: CANADIAN COMPANIES OPERATING IN SOUTH AFRICA

speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
subtopic: CANADIAN COMPANIES OPERATING IN SOUTH AFRICA

speechtext: Pursuant to Standing Order 32(2), I have the honour to table in the House the sixth report on the administration of the code of ethics for the employment practices of Canadian companies operating in South Africa and on compliance therewith.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, pursuant to section 36(8) of the Standing Orders, I have the honour to table, in both official languages, the government's response to 96 petitions.
[Editor's Note: See today's Votes and Proceedings.]

Mr. Speaker, as vice-chairman of the Standing Committee on the Environment, I have the honour to present, in both official languages, the fourth report of the Standing Committee on the Environment on the thinning and depletion of the ozone layer.
Pursuant to its mandate under Standing Order 108(2), the committee studied the depletion of the ozone layer. In this report, it expresses its concerns about ozone depletion and its effect on health.
I also want to point out how pleased I am that all members and all parties co-operated in writing this report.
[Editor's Note: See today's Votes and Proceedings]

Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 34(1), may I present, in both official languages, the report on the fourth Commonwealth Parliamentary Seminar as a delegate from the Canadian branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.
Allow me to record our gratitude to the CPA branch of the Trinidad and Tobago group for their sponsorship of this worth-while seminar. The benefits that accrue from the exchange of views and information by parliamentari-

Routine Proceedings
ans from across the Commonwealth demonstrates the value of maintaining Commonwealth relationships.
10TH REPORT OF THE STANDING COMMITTEE

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present, in both official languages, the 10th report of the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General.
In accordance with its order of reference of Ibesday, March 31,1992, your committee has considered the draft regulations on gun control and has agreed to report it with 37 recommendations.
[Editor's Note: See today's Votes and Proceedings.]
for leave to introduce Bill C-356, an act to amend the Statistics Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
Pursuant to Standing Order 68(2), the motion is deemed adopted.

Mr. Speaker, this bill attempts to establish a status for Statistics Canada which is more independent than the present position it has. This desire to achieve greater independence for the agency comes after attempts by the finance department to pressure Statistics Canada to make changes in withdrawals in a study which Statistics Canada presented earlier this past year. It is for this reason that I think the need arises to establish more clearly the independence from government pressure of Statistics Canada so it will be able to report directly, clearly, and honestly to the people of Canada.
Perhaps I should advise the House that the hon. member for Essex-Windsor was out of time in the filing of material. However, with consent I would be very pleased to proceed. Do we have consent?
Agreed.

Mr. Langdon moves that the bill be now read the first time and printed.
Pursuant to Standing Order 69(1), the motion is deemed adopted.
Bill read the first time and printed.

Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I would like to present two petitions from many people in the riding of Beaver River, from Bonnyville, Ardmore, Medley, Grand Centre and Cold Lake.
These people recognize the Proud to be Canadian project that was undertaken by the Kinsmen and Kinette Clubs of Canada. The flags travelled across the country and they, along with these petitions, were sent down to celebrate that Canada is a wonderful country.
The petitioners support the Proud to be Canadian project as an opportunity to nurture a positive, life-long relationship with our heritage and our flag, to encourage stronger ties among all Canadians for the further advancement of Canada as a leader in world circles and to promote our tremendous pride in being Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to present a petition on behalf of a number of residents of the North Thompson Valley who point out their concern regarding a plan to divert water from the North Thompson River near Valemount into the California area. The petitioners call upon the Canadian government to prohibit any notion of this type of interbasin water transfer.

Mr. Speaker, I have a petition signed by a number of veterans from Kamloops, British Columbia. They call on the government to maintain the current level of services provided to veterans through the Veterans Independence Program and to assure there is no increase in charges to veterans for board and lodging in institutions for long-term care.

Mr. Speaker, on another matter, the petitioners call on the House of Commons to ensure that if a referendum is called regarding the Constitution that it be binding upon Parliament although they realize this is impossible technically but simply to reflect the views of the petitioners.

Mr. Speaker, on another topic, the petitioners from Kamloops call on the government to reconsider the decision not to proceed with more co-operative housing. They feel this provides adequate housing, accessible for people who normally have difficulty accessing decent housing.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to present a petition from Simcoe Centre area, which humbly prays and calls upon Parliament to enact legislation providing for a referendum of the people binding upon Parliament to accept or reject constitutional amendments proposed by the government.

Mr. Speaker,
I have several petitions to present.
The first one which is quite detailed comes from a large number of Canadians of Chinese origin and concerns the Chinese head tax. The petitioners state that Chinese immigrants came to Canada in the early part of this centuiy and had to pay a racist head tax. Some 81,000 Chinese immigrants paid approximately $23 million, a sum worth over $1 billion today. That was followed by the Chinese Immigration Exclusion Act, which was not repealed until 1947, and which prohibited virtually all Chinese immigration. Both these policies had a very negative impact on Canadians of Chinese ancestry, led to a bachelor society, severely hindered-

I think the House is very aware of the matter the hon. member is raising but we are limited in remarks made at the presentation of a petition. I would ask the hon. member to proceed with the petition itself.

Mr. Speaker, the petitioners ask for an all-party resolution to consider this matter. They call on the Government of Canada to provide symbolic financial redress of $10,000 for the head tax certificate, community financial redress and post-commemorative plaques regarding the Chinese Canadians who worked on the
Routine Proceedings
railways. They ask Parliament to pledge again to ensure such injustices will never happen again, including reform of the charter of rights, and in particular to respect section 33.
That was my first petition. I have several which I will combine into one although they are different.
Do I have assurance they are on a different subject?

Mr. Speaker, the three petitions are on the subject of co-op housing. They are quite different petitions but I will combine the essence of them.
These petitioners are from throughout Vancouver and B.C. who are very concerned the federal government has discontinued the co-op housing program and are reducing the CMHC programs. They urge the federal government to reinstate co-operative housing.

Mr. Speaker, it is my honour and duty to present a petition from a number of residents of the cities of Toronto, Scarborough, Downsview, and North York.
The petitioners are concerned about the military dictatorship in Rwanda which has lasted for 30 years. The pass laws, the only ones in the world similar to South Africa's pass laws, refuse to let two million exiled Rwandans return.
They urge Parliament to urge the Canadian government to apply pressure on the Rwandan regime to immediately stop killing innocent Rwandans, to urge the Canadian government to stop economic aid and other forms of assistance to the current Rwandan regime, and to urge the Canadian government to support the European Community resolution on Rwanda issued on February 20, 1992.

Mr. Speaker, I too rise at this time to petition the House on behalf of my constituents and a few others from outside of

Routine Proceedings
South West Nova who are in support of the establishment of the peacekeeping training program in Canada.
They call upon Parliament to maintain CFB Cornwallis as a multi-purpose training facility and to establish the proposed peacekeeping training program at CFB Cornwallis.

Mr. Speaker, my first petition deals with cuts to education, training, retraining, research and development, with a special emphasis on the reductions of transfer payments and the 3 per cent tax on student loans.
These petitioners request that the government reverse its policies because they believe they are contrary to increased effectiveness and enhanced productivity.

Mr. Speaker, my other petition deals with the goods and services tax on books and reading materials. These petitioners point out there has never been any such tax in our country. They believe it is contrary to the basic principles of a democratic society and they ask this tax be removed.

Mr. Speaker, my other petition deals with fair taxation. The petitioners point out that certain people get tax credits with respect to child care facilities while others do not. They believe there are a number of tax measures that are discriminatory. They ask for a simpler and fairer tax system.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I have the honour to present several petitions bearing 1,850 signatures.
The petitioners humbly declare that for nearly 20 years the federal government has had a policy of multicultural-ism based on preserving and promoting heritage languages and that the federal government affirms that the preservation and promotion of heritage languages should be supported and encouraged.
For these reasons, they humbly ask the Parliament of Canada to restore the full financial support for the Heritage Languages Program of the Department of Multiculturalism and Citizenship, which the government reduced in its budget of February 1990.

Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36,1 am pleased to present a petition signed by hundreds of Canadians from Vancouver and Burnaby, British Columbia; St. Lawrence and South River, Newfoundland and many areas in between which states:
"We your petitioners draw to the attention of the House the following: That hundreds of thousands of Canadian senior citizens live below the poverty line; that over 80 per cent of single women over the age of 65 live in poverty; that the 37 cent increase in Old Age Security pensions in April 1992 is inadequate to meet the needs of Canadian seniors; that it is desirable for all Canadians to provide senior citizens with the necessary support to live their lives as independently as possible; that the federal government has a primary responsibility to ensure the adequacy of seniors' pensions. Therefore, your petitioners call upon Parliament to urge that the government ensure that Canadian Old Age Security pensions are sufficient to meet the basic needs of Canadian senior citizens."

Mr. Speaker, after reviewing my remarks in the House as recorded in Hansard on June 12 of this year I note that the third sentence in paragraph 2 on page 11971 is incorrect and should be replaced by the following:
It seems incredible to me that someone in Mrs. Bisset's case could not share on a credit-splitting basis the pension of her husband after 35 years of marriage, 28.5 years as the wife of a military officer and the other 6.5 while her husband served in the Public Service. A maximum of 35 years of contributions to the pension plan was paid up prior to the separation and divorce. As you know, when a wife is divorced from her husband she is disentitled to the benefits acquired under the marriage.
Thank you very much for the opportunity of correcting the record.
June 22, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, Question No. 315 will be answered today.

speakeroldname: Hon. Henry Perrin Beatty (Minister of Communications):

subsubtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 ATLANTIC FISHERY
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I ask leave pursuant to Standing Order 52 to move the adjournment of the House for the purpose of a debate on a matter of great urgency, namely the crisis in the fishery in Newfoundland and Labrador and other parts of Atlantic Canada.
With the House of Commons about to recess for the summer in 24 hours, today presents the last opportunity for there to be a proper debate on the crisis in the fishery in Newfoundland and Labrador specifically, but also in Atlantic Canada.
I ask the Speaker to give consideration to this request so that an emergency debate may be held today.

subsubtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 ATLANTIC FISHERY
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I believe you realize this is on exactly the same issue. We believe this is an emergency situation with the collapse of the Atlantic cod fishery and the devastation, not just to the resource itself but to the people living in those areas, particularly Nova Scotia and Newfoundland, and the need for some emergency action to protect the resource itself and also to deal with the problems of the people living there.

The hon. member for Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte some days ago, also the hon. member for Nanaimo-Cowichan, and subsequently 40 other members have indicated their wish that there be an emergency debate with respect to the situation resulting from the difficulties in the northern cod fishery.
I notice that the request is that these Canadians urgently require an indication of the kind of short-term and long-term strategies the government will employ, et cetera.
I have listened very carefully over several days to the questions and the answers. There is no question that the matter is of importance and concern to all members of the House.
After careful consideration, under the provisions of Standing Order 52, I am in a position to grant the request for an emergency debate today. However, the House is in a quandary as it adopted last June 9 an order to extend the hours of sitting until 10 p.m. In addition, earlier today the House agreed to a motion for time allocation on Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof, which would require, if necessary, an interruption 15 minutes before the expiry of time provided for government business, namely 9.45 p.m.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
While Standing Order 52 governing emergency debates states that such a debate be held at 8 p.m. until midnight, I have also gone back and looked at the McGrath report. In light of the spirit of the McGrath report, which sought to allow for emergency debates without infringing on the time of the House, I am prepared to set down for debate at 10 p.m. the matter raised by the hon. member and members.
This debate will conclude at no later than 12 midnight, as specified by the Standing Orders.

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Valcourt that Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope; and the amendment of Mr. Allmand (p. 12472).

Madam Speaker, it disturbs me a great deal that this government is determined in pushing the most significant changes to immigration laws in almost 15 years without providing opposition parties sufficient time to review the legislation in detail and consult with various non-governmental organizations and other immigration experts.
Bill C-86 has more than 120 sections and is over 110 pages long. Since the emphasis of this legislation is on trying to improve the management of the system and has new enforcement measures, these provisions must be examined very closely because they may impact directly on immigration policy and can be far more significant than simple technical or administrative changes.
I am worried about this legislation for another reason. This bill is shifting the responsibility from Parliament to the regulatory process. It is of profound concern that this bill is transferring powers away from Parliament. It leaves the system wide open to abuse.
Canada deserves an immigration system that is understanding of the needs of Canadians and that treats immigrants and refugee claimants with dignity and respect. Anything less would be unacceptable.
Far too often the process has treated both immigrants and refugee claimants with disdain. My constituency office is swamped with files of cases showing how insensitive the immigration and refugee determination process has been.
The policies and practices of this department seem to run on the assumption that all refugee claims are bogus and that immigrants should consider themselves lucky to be admitted to this country. This type of attitude fails to recognize that Canada benefits from their arrival on our shores and that no matter where they come from and no matter what experience they bring to Canada they contribute greatly to our economy and form an important component of who we are as a nation.
As an illustration of how the process has treated people, I want to tell the members of this House about the Mirzad family. These people came to Canada with four children. They escaped from Afghanistan, a nation devastated by the Soviet invasion in 1979 and perpetually victimized by a civil war that has killed thousands upon thousands of innocent people.
They came to Canada hoping for a new life and to escape from the mindless violence that plagued their homeland. When they arrived in this country they applied for refugee status and entered the process. While waiting for immigration and refugee officials to decide their case, the Mirzad family proceeded with their lives. They even had a fifth child here in Canada.
When the decision of the first step of the refugee determination process was reached, officials claimed that the parents did not have credible basis to remain as refugees in Canada. At the same time, the same body that rejected the parents gave their young children at least part of the required status to remain here. In effect, this decision would create orphans in this country by allowing children to stay and sending their parents back to a life-threatening situation.
A couple of months ago I rose in this House asking the Prime Minister to look into this case. He stood in this Chamber and said he would investigate the matter.
June 22, 1992

I am sure that members of this House will be shocked to learn that the result of this commitment was a government appeal of the decision granting the children credible basis. His own people.
After the Prime Minister's intervention, the children, including one born here in Canada, may be forced to return to Afghanistan. This decision is completely incomprehensible.
What this bill will do is give more power to the people who make these kinds of decisions. We must remain a compassionate nation. We were at one time. We must reach out and understand that human rights of all people is something Canada must uphold.

With this bill, the first part of the refugee determination process will be eliminated. With this proposal, even the Mirzad children could have been deported from Canada.
Refugees can present their case without being biased by a system that does not take into account neither what is going on in their country of origin nor the problems associated with being a newcomer in Canada.
This legislation will empower immigration officers at Canadian ports of entry to turn down refugee claims. I am not convinced that this provision of the legislation will effectively entitle refugees to a lawyer and an interpreter and, more importantly, to a fair assessment.
We cannot and should not leave decisions affecting the life of these people in the hands of a single person. They have a right to be heard by Canada, while Canada has to carry out the international responsibilities it has under the refugee conventions.
Again, this legislation describes a safe third country system in which immigration officers would be allowed to send refugees back to the country through which they entered Canada. This provision ignores the reality of far too many refugees. Many countries may be safe to visit for someone born in Canada but be very risky for people from other countries.
How can we make sure that the list of safe countries reflects reality? Political and military changes happen all the time. We must be sure that government will recognize these changes as they happen.
Government Orders
The refugee determination process, as it stands, calls for only one member of the two-member determination board to accept the individual as a refugee. Under Bill C-86, a unanimous decision will be required. Again, access to our country is made more difficult for people who are legitimate refugees.

This bill will make it somewhat easier for family reunification but it is still less than what is recommended by the Official Opposition and various non-governmental organizations.
We must make sure that family reunification is swift and that it is sensitive to the various definitions of family. It should not be one only based on the North American notion, but one which recognizes that the definition of family is as varied as the quilt that makes up Canadian society.

Every one in this House remembers the incidents reported by the media where members of the determination board looked down on refugees. Unfortunately, this is an all too common occurrence, which forces us to question the integrity of such a system.
That is why I support the proposal to create a system for disciplining board members who do not understand the importance of what they do, the seriousness of the situation and the impact of their decisions.
Too often, we have heard that board members did not understand the situations experienced in many countries of origin. For that reason, they do not show compassion and sympathy for families who have had to live through trying situations and only want an opportunity to start over in peace and harmony in the best country in the world. The system must deal with the problems that we find too often now.
I want to talk about the case of a married couple living in my riding. The woman is Canadian and the man is from the Middle East. They have been married for two years, and it certainly was not a marriage of convenience. The woman is now two months pregnant. They are building a life and making a family in Canada.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
Immigration officers want to force this father-to-be to leave Canada because his passport is no longer valid, having expired. The embassy of his home country does not want to renew it because he has not yet done his military service, which is compulsory in that country.
He does not want to return to the Middle East because he does not want to die there. His wife does not want to go to the Middle East because she wants her child to be born in Canada, where it can live in a peaceful society.
The members of that family want to live together, but our Canadian refugee system will force them to live apart for two to three years. This is another humanitarian reason that we could mention here, Mr. Minister. I hope that the proposed changes may improve such a situation.
It is surely not by fingerprinting and photographing refugee claimants, as the new bill proposes, that Canada will be perceived as a welcoming country. It is not by having the preconceived idea that refugees come here to cheat the government that those who decide on their fate will be more equitable. This part of the bill is particularly humiliating for those who come to Canada to flee political situations that are humanly unacceptable and to have a chance to work and live without fear.
Will their first contact be questioning by the host country? That is unacceptable. Why would we accept for others what we would find completely out of place for ourselves? It is a double standard.
I can only approve if the government wants to improve the immigration program, but deciding where newcomers must live and for how long before they are free to choose where to settle is surely contrary to human rights.
How can Canada define itself as an open and hospitable country when it fingerprints and photographs applicants for the record and tells them where to live for x number of years, which will probably be monitored very closely? That is a funny kind of welcome.

Many people have come out and said that the provision which would force immigrants to live in a specific region could violate the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. It would in effect be creating two types of immigrants: one group that is free to move as it pleases and another that is restricted to a specific area.
I have serious doubts as to whether this provision will stand up to a charter challenge. Why not try to find out first? Several immigration lawyers have said quite publicly that they did not believe this provision was constitutional.
If we are to be sure of the integrity of the immigration and refugee process then we have to make sure the law is constitutional. Immigrants, as well as Canadian citizens, have to know that the immigration law will be applied consistently and equitably across this country for years to come.
I sincerely hope we will be able to examine this legislation very carefully in committee. It is imperative that the immigration and refugee system we create follows some very basic principles. It must be a fair, compassionate and responsive system that meets the needs of Canadians, respects and treats with dignity those people from around the world who wish to join us, and helps us contribute to a greater Canada.

Of course, some of the proposed changes will make the immigration procedure more efficient, but the obvious flaws, that is, the inhumane proposals, must be corrected right now to give refugees and immigrants the greatest chance in this country. If they need us, we also need them. Only together can this country grow; otherwise it will die a slow death.

Canada is a vast country. We must realize that in a world that is overcrowded, where human rights violations are an all too often occurrence and where people struggle to better their lot in life, Canada is a natural choice. We have so much to offer and we must be generous. This generosity not only benefits the people coming to our shores but benefits us.
We cannot submit to the tiny minority of Canadians who because of misinformation are hostile to immigrants. Together, native bom or naturalized, we have a role in building this country. Canada's immigration process must recognize this fact.

Madam Speaker, I compliment my colleague from Saint-Laurent-Cartierville. She referred to the family from Afghanistan in her speech. I believe the parents were given

a deportation notice and the children were allowed to stay.
This case is just one example of many that happen like this week in and week out. We know how tough it is when parents of young students in high school come into our constituency offices. They could be weeks away from getting their grades. The teacher is saying that they are good students. They are established in the community and their parents have received deportation notices. It is just a mess, the way families can be tom apart.
We have tried on Friday and today to be very constructive in this debate with the government. We have pointed out certain aspects of this bill that we support. However,
I come back again to the fact that the best plan can go off the rails if there is not the proper staff to support the implementation of the plan.
The member talked about the right to decide who stays and who goes being put into the hands of officials. This can be a very dangerous transformation of powers. In a situation where public servants are stressed out because they are overworked and because of the volume of immigration cases coming at them, it is absolutely impossible to have all of them keep their cool all the time. Quite often rash decisions are being made.
Does the member think that one of the real problems in this legislation is that the Government of Canada is not giving the Public Service of Canada enough person-years to make sure that its best intentions in implementing this plan go forward properly? I happen to think that without the proper person-years this is going to be fiasco.

Madam Speaker, I thank the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood. He has touched on one element that is very important. When this commission was first founded a lot of money was put into it in the hope and with the assurance that it could complete the job. It has been a long time and it still has a backlog of a couple of a hundred thousand people. No wonder its people are tired.
The government's preoccupation is to get rid of our debt only at the cost of anything else. It does not matter to the government. It wants to try to lower the deficit, which none of us can complain an awful lot about, but it
Government Orders
should not at the cost of human lives and human dignity, which is what is happening here.
It is easy to say that our public servants are tired and overworked with some of the cases I have read about. The Prime Minister of this country stood in the House and said that he personally would look at the case. Then his own government decided to appeal in the case of the kids. They had credible basis accorded to them in one hearing. The parents know about Afghanistan. Another problem is that there are people sitting on this commission who do not know what is going on in the Third World countries.
Our own Prime Minister stood up. The minute the talk is about children, he loves to get to his feet, but when he has to do something he does not do it.
Cheap shot.
It may not be a cheap shot. The minister should take a look at the dossier.
Cheap shot artist.
I have many other cases. Another case from Afghanistan is being given the same response.
Cheap shot.

The minister keeps repeating "cheap shot". When five kids are at stake, I am glad I am in a position to give a cheap shot because none on that side of the House would. You are talking about a baby here, Mr. Minister. I am sorry, Madam Speaker. I say through you to the minister that we are talking about children. You know very well how I must feel, Madam Speaker, because we are both mothers.
I have a second case which is the same. People were tortured and left the country, and a couple of members who do not know anything about Afghanistan say: "We do not believe him.
