at the initial hearing. For several other reasons that I intend to explain in my speech shortly, an appeal is necessary. Why did the government not accept this right to appeal? Could the government consider such an amendment when this bill is studied?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I can reassure this House that even after the act is amended, everyone will still be able to demand fair and equitable treatment. Even under this new legislation, every case will be considered individually, in a humanitarian way. Of course we will be able to make the appropriate decisions based on personal circumstances.
As I was saying a little earlier, what we are trying to do with our amendments to the act is to maintain this balance between our humanitarian tradition in dealing with refugee claims and reliable and efficient management of our immigration system.

Madam Speaker, we all ought to know that Canada is a country built by immigrants and which continues to depend heavily on immigrants for its growth. It is this fact which has created on Canadian soil a unique multicultural society.
My own riding, Mount Royal, is a microcosm of that Canadian dream that has drawn so many millions of people to this land, whose diversity is a source of cultural and economic wealth and is proof of our potential to make not only this century but the next one also, a century of Canada's greatness.
The matter of immigration is a matter we all ought to take to heart. It is a very sensitive matter and it is a very emotional issue.
As a Canadian of Jewish faith I certainly know about refugees and I certainly know a great deal about immigration. I know about there being no safe haven, about the fact that there is no open door and about boats being refused at our ports. I know about that, as do many other groups in our society who have come here as immigrants. We all just have to think back to Nova Scotia and Newfoundland and their shores and the fears that were aroused with the Tamil arrivals and of the Sikhs.
There are groups, not only in my riding, but across this land that know about not having access or safe harbour with an open spirit at times. Times have changed, attitudes have changed and I would hope that Canada's great open spirit to that change will never close down.
Montreal is one of the great cultural mosaics in this country. The centre of that cultural mosaic is Cote-des
Neiges, a Snowdon district, which is in my riding. The many cultures which coexist there side by side in this district has given it a degree of vibrancy, a sense of being alive and fascination and differences. We have learned not only to be tolerant, which I find not to be the kind of word I particularly like, but we have learned to have respect for each other. We live in that area of my riding in very close quarters under very difficult circumstances with a lot of emotional trauma that is accompanied by the impact of having to live as either a refugee with an unsettled case or as a new immigrant trying to find one's way, whether it be in the linguistic sense or the cultural sense, in a whole new milieu.
With this new mosaic that has built into this wonderful part of my riding, we have seen self-help groups arise. We have seen community service groups come into being. We have seen ethnic centres that are helping out and extending a hand. We have a wonderful place called Project Genesis that has done some wonderful work so there is better understanding about the cultural way of life, because it is a cultural way of life. It is different for each one of these groups that come here, whether it is landlord tenant relations, whether it is how you shop in the store, whether it is your transportation system, your education system, language at work, language at home, the mores of a society which are different from the mores of many of the societies from which these people come.
I can tell you that there are many aspects that go into the development of an immigration and refugee policy that must be taken into consideration. I guess that is one of the reasons I regret so sincerely that we have had closure called on this bill. This is one of the last bills on which this government should ever have considered closure.
This is a bill that touches the very fibre and heart and life cycle in this land. There are so many things that need to be discussed that are left out, never mind that which is included.
If we could perhaps have raised those issues it could have sensitized the committees when they went out to have some discussions. It is not only me and my riding. It is almost every single member of this House who spends hundreds and hundreds of hours with people who are stressed, who are concerned and upset. They do not understand why their children are behaving the way they behave. They do not understand our education system. They do not understand what the changes have done to their husbands from families that were patriarchal and
June 22, 1992

Government Orders
where the mother is now the breadwinner and they have turned to a matriarchal society.
We need to do things to help the immigration and the integration into our larger society, not only for the people coming in but for those of us who are on the receiving end.
To be fair, there are many things in this bill which are interesting proposals and I hope will help us accomplish our national goals of prosperity. Indeed, we should encourage different forms of immigration and particularly those who can afford to invest in this country, those who have a spirit of or demonstrate a sense of entrepreneurial capacity or talent.
We have essentially three streams put in here. The first stream says "wealthy investors". I am not 100 per cent keen about wealthy investors. I am keen about people who are prepared to invest. What does wealthy mean? If you have $150,000, is that wealthy? If you have $200,000, is that wealthy? If you have $2 million, is that wealthy? If you are going to live in a major city, does that make you less or more wealthy, depending on the money you have in your pocket? I think it is a very difficult decision to make as to what is a wealthy entrepreneur. I suppose if you start in the millions and lots of zeros beyond which I am normally not able to count, that would be the wealthy investor.
What about the entrepreneur? I think that is very important. What about the independent immigrant? The reason I raise these three streams, whether it is the wealthy investor, the family member or the accrued refugee in the first stream which are fast-tracked, or the limited access, which are the parents and the grandparents, the self-employed, and people with job offers, or the third stream of entrepreneurs, independent immigrants, who are going to be based on point systems, these will all be defined in regulation, but not in the act. That means they can be changed around at will. There will be no accountability for the House of Commons. I think in a bill of this nature we need a serious sense of responsibility.
There is another aspect of this bill that I do not know how one gets around. People do not recognize the importance of immigration to the well-being of this country, that all immigrants are a boon to Canada, that they are the taxpayers, they are the consumers, they become the producers, and they become the employers. We have a very important study in that regard, the 1992 study of the Economic Council of Canada. They outperform native-born Canadians in labour force participation. No greater a percentage end up on welfare than do native bom. That is a myth that people like to circulate which is unfounded. Almost 28 per cent have some university training as compared to approximately 24 per cent among native-born Canadians.
Studies by other learned institutions, and I have a lot of studies in front of me, debunk a lot of the myths, studies from the Laurier Institute and as I said from the Economic Council. I might get around to quoting some of them. Right at this moment they all support the findings that it is vital and important that we increase the people of Canada, the numbers of people who fill this vast land, through immigration. We are certainly not doing it through our own repopulation systems right here in this land. Immigrants are a boon and they are a treasure.
Is that message getting out? I do not think so. We have been sending wrong messages. It is very important that we change the language of discourse, the language that makes us feel that they are not an important asset and a boon to our society.
The fact is that the message that immigration is a blessing, as I said, is not out there. If it were out there, the fact that racists in our country continue to suggest or imply or insinuate that immigration somehow harms us, or takes away jobs, or dilutes our national identity would not be current, if we were doing our job.
The fact is that thousands of signed petitions against turbans as an acceptable headdress or a head covering for the RCMP officers would never have come in and been deposited in this House if we understood the significance of dress as a cultural part of life for certain

Government Orders
streams of immigrants coming into this land. That does not make them any less or any better than any other Canadian.
The fact is that some suggest that racism is exacerbated by immigration to Canada of visible minorities, of people of colour. The fact is that some go so far as to suggest that only those immigrants who look and act "like Canadians", whatever that may mean, should be admitted because they will integrate more quickly into the mainstream of Canadian life and Canadian society.
That language is anathema to me. I find it would not be on the tongue, in the mouths or in the minds of people if we had done a proper job in the integration and in the instruction within our school system and within the larger society so that we could count those blessings for the blessings that they truly are.
Does the legislation dispel this myth in any way or any of the other myths about immigration? I do not believe so. Many pieces of legislation have come into this House with preambles that are absolutely overflowing with fanciful language that find no place in the law. This was a perfect time to put a preamble in that would indicate the strength and the importance of immigrants to the growth and the development of Canada.
Somehow or other there was such a rush to get this massive bill in here and through here we forgot some of the key phrases and the key thoughts that could have been there that would underscore the fact that the definition of Canada is unity in diversity. Whether it is the diversity of our geography, the diversity of our regions, the diversity of our people, the diversity of their colour or the diversity of their language, that is what has built this country. As we go across this land we can appreciate that and we can understand it. We should have written it into a preamble in this bill.
As we did not accompany this bill with any kind of an education campaign, I think we had better look to that as the next step so that we can debunk the myths that are out there.
One of the big concerns that I heard over the past weekend as I was home and saw large numbers, as all of us do, of constituents, is that they are very concerned about the lack of prior consultation. Many a group committed to Canada's present and future and committed to a fair and equitable immigration and refugee
policy has expressed dismay at the lack of consultation which preceded the tabling of this important legislation. These groups are not opponents but are allies of Canada, Canadian immigration, and the minister. They know the immigration and refugee field well and they seek the best for our country. The minister would have been well advised to have consulted them.
Why did we hear there was no prior consultation? We have learned all too well in recent years how far a faulty process can go to derail even the best of proposals. I am not going to read chapter and verse in here about all the failures by this government since it came to power, the backlog, and all that business.
I have in front of me a number of press releases. I will read the B'Nai Brith Canada release which along with the Canadian Jewish Congress is well known for its interventions in the interest of a very good and healthy immigration and refugee bill.
I do not have to remind this House about the role of Rabbi Plaut in setting the stage for the first of the trilogy of bills that are in here. The B'Nai Brith says:
That while the proposed changes to the Immigration Act introduced yesterday in Parliament address many issues in need of attention, the lack of prior consultation in drafting these changes and some of the proposed changes themselves are a cause of concern to B'Nai Brith Canada's Institute for International Affairs. The institute was deeply involved in the debate over changes to refugee legislation adopted by the first Mulroney government and has continued to express concerns over fairness and humanitarianism in the management of refugee change.
As a community that has experienced the consequences of restrictive immigration and refugee policies, we are committed to the development of a fair and effective process in this area. B'Nai Brith has supported significantly increased immigration targets for Canada which is a country built by newcomers and which will grow primarily through immigration. While it is natural that Canada would act in its own interest in recruiting perspective immigrants we must never neglect our humanitarian obligations.
This is Frank Dimant, chief executive officer of the Institute speaking.
I would bring to your attention:
The legislation does not deal with major concerns which have existed for some time regarding fair procedure. The appeals procedure is inadequate and the benefit of the doubt has been eliminated in requiring a unanimous decision by refugee board adjudicators hearing cases of individuals arriving without documents. Finally, refugee claimants should be able to work as soon as they make their claim rather than only once it is accepted. There are a few other points that are made here.
June 22, 1992

I often look at this saying you are supposed to arrive here as refugees with your documents. What are you supposed to do? Go back to the city hall and say please while I am running away to save my life and save my children could you please just go to your files and get out my birth certificate? Really there is some insanity that goes along with this whole thing.
With respect to the lack of consultation and the shortness of debate on this bill, the closure which I find totally unacceptable, I do not understand what the rush is. We have already got enough problems with this. I think we should do this, do it this time, and do it right.
The shift from legislation to regulation, I would like to move from process to the substance in a sense or to a substance process issue. The bill provides for far greater use of regulation by the minister and officials. Matters which were once in law are now going to be brought in through regulation.
I am sick and tired of this government bringing things in through regulation. There is a lack of respect for Parliament, the democratic process, and that must be corrected. The fact you have called closure is one example. The fact you like to do so many things by regulation. I will never understand why you want to do that.
One day you are not going to be the government and you are going to dump all this muck on the heads of this party. Who needs it. Thank you very much. Do your job. Put it in law. Never mind regulations that are going to drive ministers crazy.
You are not helping the Liberals.

I would suggest, as I said, the power of Parliament is being reduced. The system becomes more susceptible to abuse. At minimum these regulations should be submitted to Parliament for a review.
With respect to the obligation to settle in specific areas or in specific regions in terms of the substance of the bill, the legislation makes it easier for potential immigrants to gain admission to Canada if they agree-if you put it in regulations-to settle in a specific area where their particular skills may be needed.
Questions have already been raised in this House and around the country whether or not this is an infringe-
Govemment Orders
ment on mobility rights as set out in our charter. Did anyone check? Has anyone gone to see about court challenges?
I see the minister is coming in. I must have aroused his interest in some remark I made. Welcome.
I would really like to know from the minister if anyone checked about court challenges. I think it is very important to know whether the charter is going to stand up in this area.
The key to an immigrant's becoming a fully productive member of Canadian society is integration. I talked about integration.
Will adequate integration services be available to all those who settle in smaller centres? Will immigrants' integration be hampered by the absence of people of similar origin who may have been here for some years now?
Much of this is very important in the settling of people who are very, very uncomfortable when they first arrive here. Immigrants have been gravitating to Cote-des-Neiges in Snowdon because they see it as a place where they can establish themselves when they first arrive. There is a sense of tolerance and respect for differences in this community because people living close together here know they are all going through the same experience.
The last point I would like to make is this question of the excessive demands on health and social services.
When this bill refers to this excessive demand, are these code words for AIDS victims, for HIV-positive people? Are these provisions for more assuredly removing barriers for handicapped people, and people who seek to immigrate here who might cause us some extra weight on our social services? I do not know, but there are some serious problems there.
There are also serious problems in the refugee determination system. The government has given criminal images to refugees and wants to fingerprint them. It wants to do all kinds of things for refugees to find out if they are going to be abusers. I think the number of abusers we have had indicate we do not have to worry about it but if we did, we should have an appeal on merit.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
I am soriy my time has come to a close. I would like to have addressed the question of a safe third country. A lot of work needs to be done when this bill goes to committee. I hope there will be an openness of spirit, and the legislative committee will not be like a kangaroo court. I hope we can make significant and important changes for these people.

Mr. Speaker, my colleague made a very good speech, but she said two completely different things.

One was positive, the other was negative.
We have been handling refugee status since 1985. I have attended 800 to 900 different meetings and we have consulted 500 to 600 different organizations. It always comes to the same thing. They want this and they want that.
When Bill C-55 came into effect I was against it because the committee had not made enough recommendations. Right now she is saying we should have more consultations. I think we have already had enough. Now this bill is applying some of the Bill C-55 recommendations, such as having one level for refugee status.
When people come in now and ask for refugee status, we will know right away if they are acceptable or not. Having just the one level will shorten the period by about a year and a half for them to attempt to go to the second level. We will have no backlog. It will be done within five to sue months. Before with the first level they would say you might be a refugee. It looks like you have a credible basis, but you have to go to the second level to prove it.
Right now there is only one level. It is going to go much faster. It will be fast, efficient and honest for the people coming in, and they will not have to wait. People are not going to have to wait two and a half or three years to get to the level. They will already have been passed and accepted or not. There will be a better screening test and the refugees will be honest to goodness refugees. People in my riding are complaining that some are using the back door because it takes too long. Before Bill C-55 we had six or seven levels and now we have two. We said we should have one level and now we
have it. Thank you very much, Mr. Minister. I consulted with him enough in the last three years and have said to every minister of immigration there should be only one level. There has been enough consultation, let us start the ball rolling. We are using closure because we have to. It should have been done yesterday. It should have been done six months ago.
Believe it or not, I agree with a Liberal that people do not know how much of an asset to the country immigrants are. One member from Toronto said we should make decisions, so let us tell the people out there in Canada immigrants are an asset. They buy clothes, shoes and food. They even buy from one of my stores. We definitely should have this.

I thank my hon. colleague from the other side of the House. I often tell people for the most part every one of us are friends behind the curtains, but we have different ideological points of view sometimes. I think we can be respectful of that difference.
We have gone to many meetings together. We have shared similar concerns with respect to many of the dossiers. We had great admiration for your stance as chairman of that committee on employment and immigration. It was not easy for you to take the courageous stand you took and we acknowledge that.
I would like to remind you our competent critic, the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, indicated as early as last year, on May 21st I believe, we should have eliminated the two-tier system. We certainly should not have done what we did. It did not prove to be effective anyway, as 95 per cent passed the first stage of the hearing.
I think you would agree with me no one in this world is perfect. As refugees come across the border, who is to say the immigration person they see is not wrong? I think you would agree there is a potential margin of error. I would not even use the word "abuse" although that could be, depending on your point of view. We are dealing with a human life. We cannot afford a margin of error when we are dealing with a human life.
There has to be a method of review. There has to be the right to fair or due process. So when officers at the port of entry reject a refugee applicant, there has to be the right of due process. I think that was the nature of your question.
June 22, 1992

Madam Speaker, I want to say to my colleague from Mount Royal I share her view on the emotional trauma people go through. We cannot seem to get through to the government today the emotional trauma people experience when they are caught in the system and not getting the proper service.
I want to cite a very specific case. I have a gentleman in my riding whose name is Mohammed Ali. Mohammed was given his convention refugee status in November of 1990. He was told by employees at the Immigration and Refugee Board it would take approximately two years to get his landed immigrant papers. After a few months they asked for his fingerprints. They wanted to check to make sure he did not have a criminal record. Mohammed sent his fingerprints to the department and knew there was certification there had been no criminal record because it was an FBI clearance. He then went ahead and made arrangements to many a person this summer from Sweden. The wedding was organized, but the papers would not come through. They discovered two months ago the department lost the fingerprints. We got another set of fingerprints taken but now because the department is so busy, they cannot be processed in time and he has had to call off the wedding. These are the kinds of things that really cause emotional trauma. If the minister had proper person-years to address these situations a lot of this frustration would be alleviated.
I want to ask the member if she can tell me why she thinks the minister refuses to give this department enough person-years to do this job properly.

Madam Speaker, I would love to be able to understand why this minister does a number of the things he does. I cannot answer that question.
I can tell you that I went to Hong Kong and pretended to be a refugee and an immigrant applying through the procedures in the Hong Kong office after having visited the Vietnamese camps there. I do not know how the staff in Hong Kong stand the stress. They are overworked and stressed. People are coming in with serious problems that create emotional tension. There is a building that has nothing but files in it. There are not enough people. I understand that New Delhi is worse. It takes anywhere from two to three years to even find the file. As
Government Orders
members of Parliament we know how frustrating the whole thing is.
I would presume that the Minister of Employment and Immigration would love to have more staff. I would presume he has made an application to Treasury Board and I would presume that either the Minister of Finance or Treasury Board have been tight. If they are so tight, why do we have a $160 billion budget, a deficit and we are still short-staffed? I do not know the answer. I wish I could help but I am sorry, I do not have a crystal ball. I cannot answer that question.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure this afternoon to take part in the debate on Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
I was somewhat surprised to learn how many pages were in this bill. When this is sent to the legislative committee it is going to have its work cut out.
I would also like to tell the people that are listening, as other members have said, because of closure we cannot make changes in it. There will be no changes made in this bill here in this House during second reading. The only changes that will be made will be made in committee and brought back to the House at report stage. Therefore, we do a disservice when we insinuate that because there has been a limitation to the amount of hours we will take in this House of Commons to debate this, it is against democracy and all those things that go along with that. That is not telling people the truth about how things work in the House of Commons here in Ottawa.
The member opposite also alluded to the fact that there have been no consultations. There have been continuous consultations on immigration matters. This is now the second bill we brought into this House since we came to power in 1984.
Canada has the most open and generous immigration and refugee program in the world. Unfortunately, over the past 10 years our generosity has been perceived as a weakness instead of a virtue. In short, I would say our generosity has been abused. This has been a sore point for many Canadians. When we extend our hand to others

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
in friendship we are not anxious to have our hospitality spumed. Yet there are many who are quick to abuse us.
The tools of the multibillion dollar migrant smuggling trade are sophisticated and include colour photocopiers, high-tech printing techniques and new computer technologies. They challenge the ingenuity of Canadian immigration officials and law enforcement staff around the world.
This is the ultimate irony. People want to come to Canada because our society is open and tolerant. People can achieve anything to which they turn their hands. We have created such a society because of our parliamentary system and our belief in the rule of law. Law is paramount in Canada and all people are equal before the law. Yet to benefit from the society which our laws have helped create, many are quick to break those very laws.
I find this unacceptable. The residents of my riding of Fraser Valley East and indeed all Canadians find this outrageous. As generous as Canadians may be as a people, we will not be abused. Canada will defend the integrity of its society and the integrity of its laws.
Back in 1984, when I first entered politics, I included in my personal platform a pledge to do what I could to help restore control of our borders. I know that immigration has a positive effect on our economy, our standard of living and our quality of life. But an open door policy, a policy that is open to abuse does a disservice to all Canadians and immigrants alike.
The Minister of Employment and Immigration has risen to the challenge of the 1990s and has introduced amendments to the Immigration Act that meet these challenges. Among the proposed changes is a series of important measures that will help those at the immigration desk and in the field to give better protection to all Canadians and our way of life. That issue is a matter of effectiveness. All of the best policies are not worth very much if those who are to administer the policies are not given the tools to carry out their jobs.
Consider that customs officers can search a suspected smuggler for something as innocuous as perfume, a lighter or a watch. Yet we have all heard of the limits imposed on customs officers when they are confronted with an individual who claims refugee status and cannot be searched even when a passport is visible on their person. The limits are astounding. These changes are coming none too soon.
There are also the stories of smugglers collecting passports during a flight so that they can be destroyed and refugee status can be claimed. What about those who file duplicate refugee claims under different names? The time has come to end such absurd abuses.
Really what we had in the Immigration Act up until now were limitations so that our officers were not able to cany out their duties as we would wish them to. They need to have that enshrined in law so that they can carry out the various things that people expect them to be able to do.
This legislation includes provisions that extend more discretion to officers to seize documents, to detain vehicles, to search individuals and to use fingerprints and photos to establish an identity. I do not apologize for giving this role to our officers because if we are going to have control of our borders, and we know that we want to have immigrants come to our country, we want the people that are willing to obey our laws. As well, we also want to make sure that they are the people that we desire to come here, that they are bona fide and are legitimate refugees.
Action is needed and action is forthcoming in this legislation. New provisions for document searches and a restructured system of fines are proposed to deal with these document couriers and others who would abuse our generosity and our hospitality. These migrant smugglers can be likened to the slavers of old. They prey upon the desperate and the downtrodden and they deal in people. Now they will be caught and they will pay. In fact those caught smuggling could face fines ranging from $100,000 and five years in jail up to $500,000 and 10 years in jail.
There are measures to allow removal of illegal entrants in an expedient manner. We are addressing the problems and we are taking the necessary action.
Are we putting up barriers to immigration and refugees? I say, hardly. The numbers of people we accept exceed 200,000 annually. What are some of the things that we have in this bill before us, Bill C-86?
We know that the Immigration Act requires the government to announce each year the number of immigrants to be admitted during the following calendar year. This announcement follows consultation with the various interested parties, including the provinces. However, the current act does not provide the authority to manage the admission of immigrants in such a way as to
June 22, 1992

achieve the levels in the plan and to realize other policy objectives.
What is being proposed in this legislation is that there will be three new management streams. The first one would not be subject to fixed annual limits. What does this stream involve? This stream is of particular benefit to spouses and dependent children, in other words the immediate family members of people living in Canada, including adopted children.
One asks if the family reunification plan is alive and well. You bet your boots it is. It is alive and well and we encourage it. There are no limitations on that.
I want the people who are here and looking forward to having their family members join them to know that there is no cause for them to be alarmed about what is in this legislation. It will if anything help them be. It will help do away with some of the clutter that is clogging up the system.
People found to be convention refugees by the Immigration and Refugee Board and business persons applying under a revised immigrant investor program can contribute significantly to Canada's economic development.
Are refugees going to be welcome in Canada? Yes, they will be. Are there limitations? Are there numbers being put upon these refugees who land here and are claiming refugee status? No, there will not be limits placed upon them.
The second stream, what does it take in? It will deal on a first come, first served basis. What are some of the characteristics of what will be in the second stream? They will be the parents and grandparents of Canadian residents. They will be government assisted and privately sponsored refugees. They will be applicants who have arranged employment or are self-employed and apply to come to Canada as live-in caregivers, and people allowed into Canada under special programs that may be set up for public policy reasons.
What takes place in the third stream? This will be selected on the basis of excellence because they are the
Government Orders
best in their category, for example the most highly skilled workers demanded by Canadian employers in a field for which Canadians are not available.
Those in stream three are subject to limits established in the annual plan. These are people who are applying to come as independent immigrants, people who are qualified in certain designated occupations, and people who are qualified entrepreneurs with business experience who can contribute to Canada's economic development.
When we look at the over-all scene of what is taking place in this bill, it is clear that Canada is open for people to immigrate to our country. We are encouraging people, but by the same token we are going to make sure we have adequate controls on the system.
What we are doing is ensuring that our system is effective. Fairness has been maintained. We will not sacrifice our commitment to fairness, but make no mistake about it, we will not be abused. We cannot afford to sacrifice effectiveness in the name of fairness.
This legislation contains, as I have outlined, a balanced approach that considers and safeguards the principles of fairness and effectiveness. Too often we hear about rights and about freedoms. What we do not hear enough about, what we can never hear enough about, is the responsibility that must necessarily accompany rights and freedoms.
Freedoms and rights come at a cost. That cost is responsibility back to the society which extends the rights and freedoms. There is nothing worse than when we have freedom without responsibility, because then we have irrational behaviour and sometimes we have illegal behaviour.
In Fraser Valley East the community is comprised in large part by descendants of immigrants. We have all come to the Fraser Valley to build a better life for ourselves. We have worked hard and we have created a wonderful community, a community which welcomes immigrants with open arms. We do not welcome abusers who pervert our system and break the laws. We welcome those who will meet their commitments to our society and those who will become responsible citizens in our country.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
Our generosity is great. Our tolerance is great, but we will not be abused. This is the message I have heard from my constituents. This is the message I have endorsed and relayed to the minister on more than one occasion. I am happy to see that the minister is taking action, and I encourage all members of this House to support this legislation.
Before I sit down I would like to reiterate that if there are things which are flawed in this legislation there is a means of correcting those flaws. That can come from any side of the House. We do not want something to go forward that will cause problems in the future.
We want something that will help make sure people are treated fairly and we also want to make sure that it is not letting people jump the queue, so to speak, to get in other than at the times they have been selected to come to Canada. We know that during the closing of this debate at second reading, which will be later on this evening, there will be a legislative committee struck to work over the summertime so that some time in the early fall this bill will be brought back to the House. Hopefully there will not be too many amendments but if amendments are necessary, I sincerely trust that the committee will endorse these amendments and bring them back to the House so we can deal with them to make sure the legislation is correct in every way possible that we know how. We are only human. We are not perfect but nonetheless I am committed to make sure we do the best job we know how.

Madam Speaker, I listened carefully to my colleague who said, I believe that Canada was one of the most advanced in the world when it comes to admitting immigrants. I would not say that Canada is the most progressive, but I agree with him when he says that we have an enviable reputation over several countries for having admitted so many immigrants.
As an immigrant myself, I can tell you that, so far, I have found Canada to be a very welcoming country indeed, but I am concerned about this bill, because I get the feeling that government is trying to further limit access to Canada for immigrants. Let me give you two examples and then ask my colleague to comment.
The first thing I noticed was this: there are presently hundreds of thousands of claims in the system and I suggest that the power to cancel them retroactively is an
abusive power which could be challenged under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Second, I know from my experience as a member of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee that government demanded maximum mobility on the part of Canadian workers to move from one place to the other, to work where they want them to, precisely to ensure Canada remains as competitive as possible.
What we see in this bill is the exact opposite of what we were advocating, what we promoted before the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. Government can prevent immigrants from going where they want. It can force them to stay in the same place-say Moose Jaw, La Prairie, the Saguenay or Chambly-for a number of years. It can force them to stay there for a given length of time. On the other hand, I wonder how it will manage to enforce such regulations.
Why is this government which is so anxious to avoid challenges under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, as we have seen with the referendums legislation, prompting such challenges by acting the way I just described in these two examples?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
I want to thank the member opposite for his intervention and for his questions.
What we are trying to do here is work with the provinces. The provinces want to end up having some say as to what will happen with regard to people who come into Canada and they want to see if they can have some influence on that.
I see nothing wrong with that. I think it is perfectly legitimate. We already have an agreement worked out with the province of Quebec. I know British Columbia has actively pursued working out an agreement with the federal government with regard to immigration.
Various provinces have desks around the world to seek out people who want to come to their province and to help set up businesses in their province and they will do everything they can to assist them.
The member opposite asks whether it is wrong to force people to go to a place. I do not think there is anything wrong in asking people to come and make a commitment that they will stay for x number of years in a particular area. If people want to come to Canada and seek this as
June 22, 1992

their home, I see nothing wrong with asking them to make that sort of commitment ahead of time.
He talks about the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The charter says everyone will be treated fairly under the law. If a person is going to say he would like to come to this country and he will stay in a particular place, and then after he gets here he goes and claims the charter is against him, that person is being dishonest with us. We do not want people who are dishonest with us, when they do not put down on paper what they say they will do when they come to our country. Everyone wants to hide behind the charter as to what they will do.
We want to try to discourage that. Such is the case that people get on an airplane with papers and suddenly when they get off the airplane they no longer have papers. What happened? Did they disappear into thin air? We have to have the ability to take corrective action.

Madam Speaker, I would like to invite members of the House and people who read Hansard or who are watching this debate on television to really question the speech that was delivered by the member for Fraser Valley East. I want to point out that the member started off by saying that Canada has the most open and generous system in the world but then alleged that the system is too generous and people are taking advantage of it. He introduced no evidence whatsoever to support the claim that people are taking advantage of our system.
He also said that Canada must defend the integrity of its society. Again, the assumption is that the integrity of our society is in danger. There is no support for such a sweeping statement.
He then said when he was elected he pledged to restore the control of our borders, again suggesting that somehow Canada has lost control of its borders. Again, he introduced no evidence to that effect and I certainly would challenge him on that point.
The member was engaging in a pretty familiar technique which is to set up a straw man and then knock it down. I would really like to tell him that I feel he was engaging in a pretty cynical exercise which is called fear mongering or scare mongering among Canadians that somehow the gates of the country are open and the hordes are about to descend upon us.
Government Orders
The Canadian council for refugees in a press release dealing with the government's legislation said that it is disturbed by the language and orientation of the government's statements. The emphasis on control and abuse, not justified by any available statistics, will undermine public sympathy for refugees. That is the kind of cynical exercise that this member and this government are engaged in.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I take great exception to what the hon. member opposite has been saying. Where I come from there have been refugees who have been sponsored into our area and they have been well received and well looked after. They have been a tremendous asset to Fraser Valley East.
We also make no apologies for wanting to have control of our borders as to whom we invite to come to our country and that is what this bill is talking about. I make no apologies for that. That is what is taking place in this bill before us here today.
We have a situation now in which our officers are not able to carry out their jobs adequately. There are instances of that. I do not have them chapter and verse here. He knows it.
That is what this bill is addressing. I encourage members to let this bill go forward to committee so that it can be scrutinized in a very thorough manner.
I think is only right. There will not be a single amendment made to this bill here in the House during second reading. It will all be done in the committee room and there will be weeks and months of work at the committee level. That is what is necessary and I endorse it on that basis.

Madam Speaker, I rise to speak on this very important legislation from the point of view of my own constituents. Surrey is the fastest growing riding in Canada and is now nearly the largest one. We have had an increase of 10,000 households since the last election and many of these people who are moving into the riding are new Canadians or recent immigrants who come from diverse backgrounds: eastern Europe, Central America, Latin America, the Philippines, India, China and the British Isles.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
The community has been blessed by this diversity, particularly with the Indo-Canadian community. It has contributed greatly to our economic strength, being involved in small business, labour organizations, gardening and agriculture. It has added greatly to a social milieu within the community, particularly its concepts of family and community responsibility. It holds very strongly to assisting not only its own families and extended families but other people in that community. It has added greatly to the richness of the culture, the language, the music and the food.
I also have had many of these people and their friends and relatives approach me about the problems of immigration. This bill does nothing to address their concerns and the concerns of the average Canadian. This bill does a couple of things that are diametrically opposed to what most people say they want to see in terms of immigration.
First of all, it makes fast-tracks for the wealthy. The person who is in a position to invest a lot of money in Canada is given priority and as some people say he is allowed to buy Canadian immigration status and a Canadian citizenship.
It is fixed. It is proposing to speed up the process for spouses and children but I will tell you that it was done administratively a year ago and it is now taking less than six months for most countries to unite spouses and children with relatives in Canada. Therefore it is not going to do anything for that because it has already been fixed administratively. It only needed the will of the government.
It is changing the fundamental concept of what the family is. Particularly, it is down playing the idea of extended families. In many of our communities the family is more than the mother and father and minor children. A family is parents and grandparents. A family is adult children who are not married. This bill now puts them into a lower category in which it is going to take a long time to be processed.
It puts an emphasis on recruitment of skilled workers at a time when people tell me this government should be putting more money into training within Canada to ensure that we have the skills we need in our work force. Let us not rely upon immigration as a method of recruiting skilled workers when we should be building up the strength within our own community.
In this whole business of immigration, there is concern that the policies reflected in this bill do not reflect the values of Canadian society.
Another thing that is not addressed in this legislation is the real problem in administration of immigration throughout the world.
Recently I had the opportunity to travel to India and to see the numerous problems facing immigrants and people applying for visitor visas in the immigration office in New Delhi.
First of all, it was obvious the office was dramatically understaffed. The immigration case-load had grown from 6,900 in 1986 to 12,300 in 1991 with no increase in staff. This resulted in tremendous pressure on that
office.
Of the cases coming to the office in New Delhi, 75 per cent come from the Punjab. It is difficult and even dangerous for many of the Sikhs to travel from the Punjab down to New Delhi.
The government is talking about opening a second immigration office in Bombay. I have been urging this government to open up an immigration visitor visa office where it is needed. That is in the Punjab.
Within the New Delhi office there is a problem with interpreters who understand the Sikh religion and customs. One must remember that the bulk of the people applying for immigration from India are Sikhs and from the Punjab.
There are approximately 80 locally hired staff in that New Delhi office. In other business establishments in New Delhi obviously there are Sikhs working, but in our Canadian immigration office which is dealing with 70 or 75 per cent Sikhs or Punjabi-speaking people, there is no one who is Sikh.
I went with one of my staff members who is fluent in Hindi, Punjabi and English. We sat in on an interview and the interpreter misinterpreted the interview. These same people are advising Canadians on what is Sikh religion and custom as it pertains to immigration. For example: "Is this a valid marriage? No, it is outside the custom". The people who are giving that advice do not know what the religion and custom is and they will give our officers incorrect advice. I have suggested they hire some Canadian-born Sikhs to work in the office. They hire local.

There are physical problems at the embassy. People line up from three o'clock in the morning and stay all day hoping to get a chance to get a ticket to see an immigration officer. There are no washrooms available, no water available, no shelter. That kind of a situation in a Canadian embassy would not be tolerated in any other part of the world where 300 people line up starting at three o'clock in the morning and we do not even make washrooms or water available. The temperature gets up to 40 degrees.
In the administrative process of handling immigration there are things we repeatedly make people come back and forth from the Punjab to New Delhi for. For example, we refuse to have medicals done in the Punjab. Why do we not designate four doctors who are authorized to do medicals in each of the major cities? If they submit medicals that are not appropriate, we strike them from the list. It is very easy. Some people have had to come back not only two but three times to get medicals because they last only six months and their name has not come up for immigration.
There is also another problem that this legislation has not dealt with that is as much a problem and that is the issuing of visas for visitors. Visitors visas are issued arbitrarily by the officer, with no right to appeal. The officer says: "I decide that you are not a bona fide visitor". They do so on whim and I will give you a couple of cases and our response.
I know a young man who is the president of a travel agency for all of southern India. He has been to Canada three times. He has been here with his wife and his daughter. He has always returned home. His sister is a very prominent Canadian. He applied for a visitor's visa to visit his sister for two weeks. He wanted to bring his daughter, an eight year old. His wife was going to stay behind because of her job. Immigration said he could not bring his daughter because he might abandon her in Canada. He was told he had to come the six hundred kilometres from Kerala to Delhi.
Another woman applied to bring her two children to visit her parents in Canada. Her husband was going to stay behind. She had a job to go back to. They had land in India. She was told she could not come to Canada unless she left her two infant children behind. In other words, the Canadian government said that it would hold the children hostage to guarantee the woman's return. That
Government Orders
is the kind of decision that is being made on visitors'
visas.
When my assistant was getting married, her grandmother and grandfather applied. The immigration officer gave her grandfather a five-year multiple entry visa and denied her grandmother for absolutely no reason. It
was an arbitrary decision.
The community is relying on priests in Jutha to help them within their religion. Immigration arbitrarily says this man is a farmer because in their custom and religion the guy does more than just be a priest and therefore they will not allow him to come.
We have made very strong recommendations that people who have visited Canada, the United States, North America and have returned to India should be granted visitors' visas without the need of going all the way to Delhi for an immigration interview.
The general interpretation of the legislation is that the onus is on the person who'must prove beyond any doubt he or she will be going back home. The fact that the immigration officer says you are going to abandon your husband, your children and your farm and stay in Canada, that is nonsense. We need a reasonable interpretation that the person is a reasonable visitor.
Parents and grandparents should automatically be given five-year visas. A grandparent coming from England can come and go when he or she wants. Why do we not give a five-year visa and simply let them come and visit their children and grandchildren when they wish to and go back home when they wish to. Let us give special consideration to issuing visitors visas for priests in Jutha.
My concern is that a lot of the problems in the issuing of visitors visas from New Delhi are based on the arbitrariness of immigration officers.
Who are overworked.

Now we have in this bill that a lot of the same types of arbitrary decision-making powers are going to be given to officers as they deal with other areas within the immigration and refugee process. They are going to be able to arbitrarily make decisions.
I want to talk about two or three other points of administration before I start talking about some of the refugee problems. We have another tremendous administration problem in immigration in Canada.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
People in my riding who have applied for immigration, who have been here and are now eligible to become Canadian immigrants, because of the delays in processing their applications sit there for 18 months or longer from the time they have completed their qualifications to become a Canadian citizens until they actually get Canadian citizenship. They have met all the requirements. They simply need the opportunity to go before an immigration judge, satisfy the judge that they meet the requirements, and go before the citizenship court.
There are delays now, long delays of a year, 18 months and more. We are taking a person and depriving him of job opportunities. You cannot work for the province of British Columbia unless you are a Canadian citizen. You have other losses that you are suffering. This legislation does not deal with any of the real issues that most Canadians and immigrants are concerned about. It does not deal with the real issues. It deals with the straw man model that there is a real problem with fraud in the refugee section and there is a real problem in fraud in the immigration section. There are people who are coming here who are unqualified, who do not want to work or are going to end up on welfare. That is not true.
There is another thing that really disturbs me about this piece of legislation and that is the government's approach to it. This is a significant change in immigration legislation. It is fraught with problems that are ill-thought through. What does the government do? It waits until three or four days before Parliament rises. It introduces the bill in the House. It forces it through the House on closure so we have basically two days to debate it, discuss it or look at the implications.
It is a huge bill. This is not a one-paragraph bill. It is 110 pages and some of them are very complex. They are difficult to understand. Now what is the government proposing? During the middle of the summer it proposes to rush this through a committee.
People out there in the community are in the process of getting ready for summer holidays. They are going to be away. Ethnic organizations, religious organizations, immigrant organizations are winding down for the summer. Their staffs are going on holidays. They are not going to be able to get together in two weeks, prepare
detailed briefs in response to all of these technical questions and interpretations of law and legislation, get it presented to this government and have it properly considered over the summer.
What is the hurry? If the government really feels it is right, why did it not bring this legislation in two years ago when there was lots of time? We would have had two or three years. Why is it waiting until the dying days of its mandate?
Some people in my community over the weekend suggested to me it was a another sceptical ploy to try to see if it could get before Parliament as an election issue rather than take a serious look at the needs of Canada in terms of immigration to look at our history. Under this piece of legislation my father would have never been admitted to Canada. Maybe some of you on that side feel that is quite acceptable. I will bet most of your parents and grandparents would not have been admitted to Canada either.
The people who have built this country, the people who have made this country strong, the people who have enriched this country are the ones who are no longer going to be admitted. That is a shame. It is more shameful when there is an obvious attempt by the government side to push this through the House now, to push it through committee during the summer when organizations will not have the time and resources to properly bring before the committee their concerns about the bill and then bring it back either late in August, as we are now even hearing rumours, or early in September and dump it through the House. I do not think that is acceptable.
I want to close by saying one additional thing and it has been mentioned before. Canada needs immigrants. We have a growing elderly population and the percentage is growing significantly. We need to have younger people to develop the strengths within our community.
We also need to ensure that the diversity of Canada which is its rich heritage is continued. An open and liberal immigration policy is what is needed.

Mr. Speaker, I listened carefully to the remarks of the hon. member
opposite.
June 22, 1992

When the hon. member mentions that it takes at least six months for a spouse to enter this country, has he talked to the immigration critic?
Moreover, he mentioned that we should have additional manpower in New Delhi and he quoted a case in point. If we increased our staff in New Delhi, creating additional expenses, what would his reaction be?
I went to New Delhi and I was able to see all the people lining up. If we agreed to increase our staff, what would happen to the many hundreds of people waiting in line? Would that speed up the process? To do so, we need sound criteria and I think we can do it with what we already have.
The member also mentioned that it could take one or one year and a half to get an immigration visa. I do not want to enumerate all the changes that will affect family members and multicultural communities. When they will all come into effect, an immigration visa will be granted faster to a refugee's close family members, whether they are already in Canada or not, and whether they are in the applicant's country of origin or not.
Has the member carefully reviewed all the changes that will be made? A moment ago, he said that we should have done it two years ago. I must say that I am puzzled by that. The law was already in place two years ago, we are simply improving on it. Believe me, we have been working very hard for the past two years to improve this piece of legislation. This bill is a very good one.

Mr. Speaker, I consulted with immigration people in New Delhi and they said to me that they need a minimum of six full-time additional immigration officers. What would be the effect? It would cut down on the line-up so maybe people would not be waiting around for 11 or 12 hours.
Maybe they would not deal with visitor visa applications so arbitrarily. Maybe they would sit there and listen to the person for five or ten minutes and actually find out why they wanted to come and get the correct information instead of arbitrarily dismissing them. Maybe they would not make arbitrary decisions that say, for example, this is not a legal marriage or a proper marriage because the woman is older than the man.
In some parts of India that is not considered custom but in the Punjab it is done all the time. Maybe if they
Government Orders
had more time, they would make better judgments. They would be more humane judgments.
That is what is necessary in order to increase it. You talk about the six months.
You are lucky if you get it in six months.

After much yelling and hollering for the last three years and documenting cases, one year ago last summer, unbeknownst to this government, the officers in New Delhi took it upon themselves, with the sanction of the senior bureaucracy in Ottawa, to change the procedure.
They simply said it is unacceptable that a spouse who has been waiting three years, four years-I have one who has been waiting sue years-to come. They said they are going to process them in six months.
Other than in a case where there is a problem with the documentation, they have lived up to that and they are processing spouses within six months. In fact, they are doing it within three months and four months by simply changing their policy.
This legislation only now sanctions what the people through their own initiative in the Delhi office were able to do simply by changing their procedure. They simply said: "We are going to do it. We are not going to put them to the bottom of the pile and let them sit there for three or four years".

Mr. Speaker, I want to compliment the member for Surrey North on his remarks. I think he really communicated the emotional frustration we all experience very well.
I want to hear his views on an idea that I put to the minister earlier today when I was asking him specifically about giving members of Parliament some authority to have conditional approvals on some of the applications that are before the system, that are delayed because of the lack of person-years in the department due to their inability to catch up.
The minister in this legislation seems to be very quick in giving all of this authority to unelected officials, but he does not seem to want any authority given to members of Parliament. Quite frankly, we are much more accountable to our constituents.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
In other words, we are certainly going to be put in a harsh light if we put someone through the system on a conditional approval if it were the kind of person who was scamming the system or to quote the Solicitor General, who I think called them riff-raff.
My concern is that the minister seems to be so rigid in his way. He does not want to recognize that we as members of Parliament could be part of this solution. I just wonder what his remarks would be on that. We do sign passports and why not immigration cases?
It is a novel I idea but my first reaction to it is I did not get elected to Parliament to become an immigration officer.
But we are.

No, we are not. We sign passports saying this is the person's picture and we know them. I really think that would end up being a sham because in my riding I would spend all of my time reviewing refugee cases in detail. As it is now, my staff spend too much time.
The government mucks up, the government has improper procedures, the government does not have a system in place. I do not think the proper solution is for us then to take it over.
One of the things you get into is this whole arbitrariness, particularly with refugees. One of the things in this bill that bothers me is the provisions for removal of immigrants or landed people and how the government is proposing to broaden the arbitrary ability to remove people. I read this section and I wonder if this is really Canada. It says: "Provisions would be introduced to protect the disclosure of information obtained in confidence from foreign governments or intelligence agencies. The court would examine information in camera in the absence of the person to be removed, or his or her counsel".
Are you suggesting the MP become the person that hears that information in camera without the benefit of the person's counsel?
On humanitarian grounds.

This is on the same kind of arbitrariness. The government is setting in place procedures that are undemocratic, arbitrary, and not even open to the person to know what is going on.
The government in a case such as that can have CSIS quietly designate the organization as subversive and not say anything to the public. A person then goes to a social event sponsored by the organization and is removed from Canada after a hearing that is held in camera in his or his counsel's absence.
As an individual member of Parliament I certainly do not want to get involved in any of that kind of nonsense whatsoever. It is bad legislation. Let the government make proper legislation. Let the government deal with it in a normal administrative manner, but do it properly and humanely and with justice.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
The first five hours of debate are now expired.

Pursuant to Standing Order 74, I may remind hon. members that the maximum length of speeches is now 10 minutes, without questions and comments.
Resuming debate. The hon. member for Terrebonne.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to take part in the debate on second reading of Bill C-86, an Act to amend the Immigration Act.
When a main thoroughfare becomes so congested that rush hour becomes practically synonymous with traffic jams, constant slowdowns and drivers who never know when they are going to get home, city planners start reviewing their traffic plans. The expressways, intermediate roads and access roads they design will help deal with the problem. After that, traffic flows at a far more logical rate and the overall impact is more satisfactory. People spend less time on the road and the number of accidents decreases.
In recent years, the number of immigrants to Canada has increased regularly. This year, 250,000 immigrants and refugees will be admitted to Canada. They come to our country, attracted by the opportunities available to those who live in a country as rich as ours. And why not, when the United Nations ranks Canada first in the world for its quality of life? They also come to this country because economic and social conditions in their country of origin are such that they want to seek a better life for themselves. In any case, the number of people who are leaving their countries for political, economic or social reasons is constantly increasing, and this creates many
June 22, 1992

new challenges for Canada and other industrialized countries.
We currently have an Immigration Act that was designed to manage the demands of simpler times. For instance, in 1980, approximately 1,500 people applied for refugee status. Last year, more than 30,000 people asked for our assistance: from 1,500 to 30,000 people per year in twelve years. This means that the situation has changed drastically and we can no longer take the same approach to the problem. Compare Germany, which expects 400,000 people to claim refuges status in that country this year.
However, we did not wait until the problem took on crisis proportions. Two years ago, the federal government introduced a five-year plan for immigration, setting the numbers and categories of immigrants we will admit annually until 1995. There is an element of response in this plan. However, today the time has come to update the instruments we intend to use to implement the action plan and that is the purpose of the amendments to the existing legislation.
The federal proposals include a new traffic plan that will help us accelerate the arrival of newcomers and fully integrate them in Canadian society, as quickly and as fairly as possible. We would do well to remember why Canada opens its doors to newcomers. There are three reasons for this. More often, it is to reunite the family of a Canadian resident. In other cases, the doors open to offer protection and asylum to refugees.
Last but not least, we regularly open our doors to independent immigrants and entrepreneurs whose presence here will strengthen our labour market or add to our expertise, technology or investment capital.
The amendments proposed by the federal government will divide our immigrant selection process into three streams or channels. Each stream would have a mix of candidates meeting our three main objectives, but the three streams would differ widely in terms of procedures and priorities.
Applications from qualified individuals in stream one would be processed as they were received, with no set limit on the total number approved in any year. These applicants would be processed in very precise time
Government Orders
frames, such as within six months for spouses and dependent children.
This stream would include spouses, fiances and dependent children of persons already living in Canada, all those recognized as convention refugees by our Immigration and Refugee Board and immigrant investors who are willing and able to invest in our economic development upon their arrival.
Stream two could also reflect our threefold interest in families, refugees and independent immigrants. This second stream would include parents and grandparents of Canadian residents, refugees sponsored by a government or a private organization and anyone benefiting from a special government program arising from a particular international problem, as well as applicants with reserved employment, working independently or admissible as domestic workers.
Applications from these people would be processed in order of receipt and, for the first time, the total number of applications in each category would be subject to limits set in the annual immigration plan. Processing time limits would be set for each application, according to the number of persons already in the system and the total provided in the annual plan. Once the limit for a category was reached, applications would be deferred until the following year.
Finally, stream three would include persons selected on the basis of excellence. There would be no refugees in this stream, since there is no connection between excellence and the need for protection.
Distant family members who are not in the other two streams will be classed with independent immigrants, sometimes in specially designated professions, and qualified entrepreneurs.
Only the best in each category, independent or entrepreneur, the most qualified or those whose qualifications were most in demand with Canadian employers would be selected. There would be precise limits for each category. In this stream as well, once an application was refused, the applicant's file would be closed. He or she would have to apply again.
In summary, these streams would speed the processing of immigrants. Stream one, the express lane, would enable us to process applicants rapidly within precise time limits. The new control measures for stream two, the intermediate lane, would help improve the flow of

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
immigrants, but the processing times would not be as precisely guaranteed as for stream one.
The third stream would give us something that we greatly need, as we all know. We need a selection method based on success, but which in itself would take nothing away from generosity, a way of channeling excellence into the mainstream of Canadian society.
From the beginning, we wanted to be sure that with the changes made to the Immigration Act, the program would continue to serve the best interests of all of Canada and all Canadians. We are convinced that these amendments will help us achieve our objective, which is to have a fair, balanced, efficient program.
For all these reasons, I am pleased to support the bill and I will vote for it because it is what Canadians want.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to debate Bill C-86 which profoundly amends the present Immigration Act.
Let me begin by quoting from Sir Wilfrid Laurier's eulogy to the first and greatest Canadian Prime Minister: "The life of Sir John A. Macdonald-is the history of Canada".
The history of Canada at that time was one shaped by a vision of unity, of a binding from sea to sea. The cords that were to bind the country were the people, people of every race, colour and creed, of every language and culture, toiling to make a better life for themselves and those they loved.
Macdonald himself emigrated from Scotland. Laurier, the first Canadian-born Prime Minister, opened Canada to the immigration movement. He filled the land with hard-working souls who built the railways, ploughed the prairies, and mined the hard, unforgiving rock. Trees were felled. Towns were built. Boats of every size and shape plied the waters of the Atlantic and Pacific, bringing fish to port or goods to market.
The vision: the country came before region, unity before language and culture.
These two great men, one an immigrant, another Canadian born, began through the process of immigration a legacy of nation building that has set Canada apart in the world. Ours is a country that now is a shining example of compassion to immigrants and refugees.
Last Tuesday, June 16, the minister's office released a communique on Bill C-86. The opening paragraph read:
Bernard Valcourt, Minister of Employment and Immigration, today announced a series of important changes to the Immigration Act which will ensure that the country's immigration system continues to contribute to the unity and prosperity of Canada.
Yet the message of the Minister of Employment and Immigration had a distinctly unpleasant after-taste. When he speaks not from prepared text his language really reveals and echoes the intent of his government. The message comes through loud and clear to the people on the other end of this legislation, refugees and immigrants and those who volunteer on their behalf, that what is in their bank account is of greatest importance when they reach Canadian soil.
In his press conference the minister remarked on bogus refugees and welfare cheats, on immigration scams and asylum shopping. He said:
We are going to give ourselves the powers to stop welfare abuse.
I felt that in many ways the minister perpetuated myths that the government should be trying to refute, myths that our immigrants and refugees are a strain on the system, that they are a commodity to be managed, that they are to be accepted or rejected as mere commodities.
The minister perpetuates the myth that immigrants are a drain on the public purse, suggesting our welfare system is abused. Studies show that to the contrary costs associated with the arrival of foreigners are short-term and that a much lesser number of them go on welfare compared to Canadian-born citizens. Also, immigrants take jobs that have been shunned by Canadians or for which there are not enough qualified people in Canada.
The Employment and Immigration Advisory Council reported Canadians need to be educated on the benefits of immigration. Yet the government has never supported such an education campaign. For its good advice the advisory council was axed by this government. The minister himself repeats the cheating immigrant myth,
June 22, 1992

telling the media at his press conference about a refugee collecting multiple welfare cheques.
Why has the minister not highlighted the achievements of Canadian immigrants instead?
These people include: Wilder Penfield, founder of the Montreal Institute of Neurology, an American turned Canadian and one of the foremost brain specialists of our times; Timothy Eaton from Ireland and Sir Donald Smith of Scotland, who headed two of the largest chains of department stores in Canada and who were players in our history; Tommy Douglas, also Scottish, who broke the ground for some of this country's most loved social programs including medicare; and more recently we think of Dr. John Polanyi, a Canadian chemist and Nobel prize winner who was born in Berlin and immigrated to Canada in 1934.
Canadian arts and culture have flourished under the attention of immigrants like Ofra Hamoy, a world renowned cellist from Israel; Rohinton Mistry of India, winner of the 1991 Governor General's award for fiction; and Austin Clark, a novelist from Barbados.
Broadcasting owes much to Adrienne Clarkson who immigrated to Canada from Hong Kong. Rosemary Brown, advocate for women's rights, was the first black woman elected to political office in Canada. She came to this country from Jamaica.
Recognition for excellence in sports goes to Sharif Kahn of Pakistan, many times world squash champion.
For success in business, who could forget Thomas Bata, a Czechoslovakian who built the largest shoe manufacturing company in Canada.
For a legal luminary, do not forget Justice Bertha Wilson, bom in Scotland, who was the first woman appointed to the Supreme Court of Canada.
As an immigrant from the Philippines and now a member of this Parliament, I take pride in the precedent set by these immigrants whose hearts and talents have long belonged to Canada. I can only aspire to the heights they as immigrants and Canadians have reached.
At that press conference soon after tabling the bill, the minister with his 113-page bill on the table before him was writing himself a blank cheque to be the one to
Government Orders
manage the immigration system. In effect he is writing Parliament out of the process with regulations that bypass the legislative process. He is removing the rights of refugees to appeal Immigration and Refugee Board decisions to a court of law.
Precedents are abundant to show that a court of law has not always agreed with the decisions of the refugee board. Has this government forgotten that the courts are the fortress of law and justice, that democracy becomes meaningless if natural justice is denied? Have the minister and this government failed to remember that courts of appeal prove to the world the vitality of democracy by which we live? Truth does not have to be afraid of appeal, particularly in a court of law where men and women dedicate themselves to the noble pursuit of justice and understanding.
Arbitrary decisions on visitors visas in the past have also infringed on the rights of both Canadians and of their visiting family members.
Recently I intervened on behalf of a Mrs. Kaur from India, the sister of a man who died in my constituency. She travelled long and arduously from her home in the Indian countryside to the Canadian Embassy in New Delhi, applied and was denied. I intervened on her behalf, and after a prolonged agony a minister's permit was given. How many more Sarjit Kaurs are refused visitors visas every day?
Recently a constituent invited a relative from Ukraine. The visitor was refused admittance for similar reasons.
