Ukrainians until now had been prisoners in their own country, until the collapse of the Soviet Union. Is it not ironic that again they are prisoners this time because of Canadian immigration policy?
I would like to conclude by saying that this country was built by immigrants. It is a country that was not built overnight, yet overnight the government is trying to drastically change the whole immigration process. Some changes are good, but some changes are bad. We and the people who care about immigrants and the continued growth and prosperity of this country should be given time to study this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I too, am very pleased to stand here to speak to Bill C-86. The motion put forward by the immigration minister refers to the second reading and reference to a legislative com-

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
mittee in the Departmental envelope of Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof and on the amendment by my colleague, the hon member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, seconded by the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys:
That the motion before us be amended by deleting all of the words after the word "That" and substituting the following therefor:
That Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof, be not now read a second time but that it be read a second time this day six months hence.
It is saying the bill should not be passed this evening but it should be given an extension allowing us the opportunity to scrutinize it.
The complex and extensive bill was tabled less than a week ago. There has not been enough time to carefully scrutinize it or to have broad consultation. It is disappointing the government has not allowed a full and open discussion about this most serious bill which would involve all parties concerned.
The government is attempting to regain votes lost to its extreme right-wing adversary, the Reform Party, by catering to the perception that the system is being abused and manipulated by a significant percentage of refugees and immigrants. Available studies prove that the opposite is true and that in fact, immigrants contribute far more to this country than they take away.
The language of the bill is disturbing in that it concentrates on issues of control and abuse and not on the interests of helping genuine refugees while at the same time streamlining the process.
We know that 95 per cent of those who come to Canada are approved for recognition as refugees in the first stage of the present system.
We need time to study this bill in order to offer constructive criticism. Instead, the government would rather blindly push the legislation through to suit its own political agenda. This fact has added significance when one considers that this legislation constitutes the most extensive revisions to the Immigration Act since 1978. There are obviously many flaws and we must have time to deal with the issues properly.
When we are dealing with refugees we are dealing with life and death situations. As the opposition critic for
human rights, I know from experience that those who are sincere refugees-and the vast majority are-come to Canada to escape severe oppression and in many cases death.
Let us for a moment try to understand the people we are supposed to be helping through our system of refugee determination. According to article 1 of the 1951 United Nations convention relating to the status of refugees, a refugee is "a person who, owing to well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or a political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable, or owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country".
In 1969, Canada signed the United Nations convention relating to the status of refugees and in 1989 Canada received the UN High Commissioner for Refugees highest award for humanitarian assistance. That speaks tremendously well of Canada.
In 1986, the Special Joint Committee on Canada's International Relations published a report entitled Independence and Internationalism. It concluded that Canada's refugee policies were consistent with the country's larger foreign policy objectives, namely humanitarianism, humanitarian assistance to disadvantaged peoples and our interest in a stable and just international order.
There are few countries in the world which have sufficient resources and the capability to provide temporary or permanent asylum to refugees. Canada figures prominently on that short list.
I submit that our enviable record has slipped. It has slipped at a time when the world needs us most. Environmental disasters, chronic famine and regional conflicts are factors contributing to the creation of new classes of refugees and give rise to even more confusion about what should constitute a precise definition of a refugee.
Recently, global trends have placed unprecedented pressure on Canada's refugee determination process. In 1981, 3,450 refugee claims were made to Canada. The 1980s saw a remarkable increase in claims. In 1987, there were 25,000 people claiming refugee status and by 1989
June 22, 1992

that number had increased dramatically to 95,000. We saw an incredible backlog as a result.
In order to deal with this the government introduced legislation in an attempt to streamline the process. The changes prove over time to be slow, open to abuse and grossly unfair to many of the refugees who get caught in this trap. Today, we look at the government's attempt at improving the process.
Many of the provisions proposed in this legislation deal with management of the system and with enforcement. Whether or not they can actually be considered an over-all improvement to Canada's immigration system is yet to be determined.
As has been the case with other bills passed recently by this government, Bill C-86 grants to the minister and cabinet a greater use of regulation and removes several matters from the law.
The measures included to speed up family reunification of young children, husbands and wives are indeed very welcome.
Our immigration critic, the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, recommended some time ago, on May 21, 1992, that those granted refugee status should be allowed to sponsor their families as soon as they are recognized as refugees.
One-third of refugees have spouses &/or children and many have been separated for over five years as they get caught in the extremely slow process. It makes sense to allow immediate reunification of refugees with their families since approximately 95 per cent of refugees are eventually granted landed status.
The bill also resurrects a safe third country provision which was opposed a few years ago in former Bill C-55. This allows an immigration officer to return a refugee applicant to certain countries which the applicant passed through on the way to Canada.
According to the Canadian Council for Refugees much decision-making has been taken away from the quasi-independent immigration adjudicators and given to senior immigration officers. The CCR continues that decisions that will be made without the claimant having a right to counsel. Genuine refugees because of that may be sent away at the border having no recourse at all.
Changes as well are proposed to the process of the refugee panel. In the present process only one member
Government Orders
of a two member panel need approve the applicant for recognition as a refugee. Under this bill the approval of two members out of two will be required in certain cases.
Under the legislation the minister will be allowed to choose among applicants for immigration those he or she considers to be the best for one reason or another. This would replace the system of first come first served for a system of pick and choose. The cynical side of me can only guess which immigrants from which countries will get preferred treatment, especially if we were to believe the majority of the proposed changes are politically motivated.
Other changes include that the general stay for visitors visas has been extended from three to six months, but nothing has been done to correct the abuse in rejecting legitimate applications for visitors visas. The bill introduces more stringent provisions against potential terrorists and criminals involved in organized crime. It is not clear how freedom fighters, for example, would be distinguished from terrorists. I think it is critical that this distinction be made quite clear.
The bill also shifts a substantial burden from the government to transportation carriers for enforcement of the law. There could be serious implications here for cost accountability and control. It is interesting that the government is expressing such a desire to control immigration and the influx of refugees on the one hand and on the other hand to relinquish some control to transportation carriers. It just does not seem to make sense to me. One good provision is the inclusion of a system of discipline for members of the Immigration Refugee Board who misbehave or are negligent. There were several cases where board members were rude and ridiculed refugee applicants. I think most of us were quite shocked by that.
While it is good to clearly define what is acceptable behaviour, I am left wondering whether it is a politically motivated inclusion or whether it has been included in the interests of humanitarian concern for people who have already suffered enough.
There are a number of areas that have not been dealt with by this bill. There is no provision for an appeal on the merits of a case from decisions rejecting refugees at the border or at the refugee board. There is an appeal on questions of law-to the federal court, but even this is

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
restricted. No board is perfect and an appeal system is essential where human rights are involved.
While the bill will clarify and improve the enforcement provisions of the act, nothing is being done to clarify and improve the use of section 14, which provides for admission of refugees on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
I prepared a 20-minute speech and unfortunately now have to cut it down to 10 minutes. There are a lot of other things I wanted to speak about, but obviously I do not have the time. Members on this side of the House and I believe the bill needs more study in consultation with immigration refugee experts. There needs to be genuine improvement, which will incorporate efficiency and compassion, not just attract some of the voters who have fled to the Reform Party.
This bill has serious implications for Canadians. To close debate and ram through bad legislation is a disservice to Canadians and a betrayal of the people of this world who are not fortunate enough to enjoy the same freedoms we do.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak for 10 minutes on this bill.
First of all, I would like to congratulate the Minister of Employment and Immigration. This is not a bad bill at all. This is a good bill that I think is welcomed by our constituents and Canadians from coast to coast.
It will help Canadian residents be reunited with close family relatives from abroad. It will commit Canada to providing shelter to legitimate refugees and it will promote the development of a strong and viable economy in all regions of this country.
The government is proposing a series of changes to the way we have been doing things since the last immigration act was passed in 1976. They are sensible, pragmatic and important changes that will ensure immigration continues to serve the best interests of all Canadians. Some measures will streamline the way we identify and receive refugees, while others will place more emphasis on attracting to Canada those with particular skills and talents we require. Others will reduce the abuse of these programs and clear up the inefficiencies to make the system fair to all.
The changes are needed because the context for our immigration program is very different than it was in 1976. Political and economic conditions around the world are less stable today. Natural disasters, regional conflicts and economic collapse have sparked large-scale and unpredictable movements of people. Some experts suggest as many as 80 million people are on the move at any one time.
In 1983, for instance, about 95,000 people sought asylum in OECD countries; in 1991 that number had jumped by 800 per cent to 700,000. Most of those asylum seekers would not qualify as refugees according to United Nations definitions.
There has been a blurring of the distinction between refugees and economic migrants.
At present, the number of individuals wanting to enter Canada is enormous. The demand is impossible to predict and moreover the classification of newcomers is far from straightforward. In this environment we need the tools to help us manage the ever-increasing demand on our immigration program and help us make the most straightforward determination and the best selection possible in the best interests of Canada.
Embedding efficiency and control in our system is particularly important right now, given the future all industrial nations face as we learn to deal with this mass movement of people. It is not a question of closing the doors as some have suggested. It is a question of managing our programs in the most effective way possible with the resources at hand in order to best serve the interests of this country.
One of the problems with the 1976 act was this. The federal government was given the responsibility of establishing the over-all level of immigration in a given year but it was not provided with the authority to actually achieve those levels. To effectively manage the immigration program, the Government of Canada requires that authority. It is given that authority in Bill C-86.
To make sure Canada's immigration program benefits all Canadians, we must be sure that our system is under control. Many of my constituents in Niagara Falls, through surveys they have returned to my office, through their letters, when speaking to me in the street, believe that we are in danger of losing control of the system. In
June 22, 1992

that fear I believe they are right. That is why new enforcement measures are needed.
There are individuals on our doorstep who are very adept at circumventing immigration procedures and our laws. We see this in increasing numbers and we also see the sophistication of fraudulent documents, new techniques for avoiding legal entry, and methods of smuggling illegal immigrants into Canada. It is time for some new and appropriate tools to fight these and other forms of abuse which attack the integrity of our immigration program.
Within our borders things have changed too since the current Immigration Act first went into effect. The needs of provinces and regions for residents with specific skills and experience are an even greater priority now during a time of economic difficulty and increased urbanization than it was in 1976.
As well we have a much more pointed sense of where inequities in our system exist. For example, why does it take so long to process the applications of legitimate immigrants from around the world? It is one of the difficult things that all of us as members of Parliament face when we get constituents who say they have somebody in the old country who has filled out all the proper forms, they qualify, they have the medicals, they have everything in place and then they are told they may have to wait three years. That is a system that works in nobody's interest and it is one which should change.
These proposed changes will go a long way to reducing those kinds of frustrations for individuals immigrating to Canada. It will at the same time deter cheating at the time of entry and ensure that the balance among the three primary goals of our immigration system best serve Canadians.
The changes we propose will make that system fairer and more straightforward for everyone and that is why I support it. That is why I think all members of the House should support this legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I am going to begin my speech on Bill C-86, the immigration bill, by picking up where my hon. colleague left off. As a member on the government side, he said that this immigration bill is a bill which is going to provide a sense of fairness to the immigration procedure and process. I do not buy that. I do not buy that at all.
Government Orders
If you look at the bill carefully you can easily pick out five or six areas where it does not provide this fairness. I ask for my friends on the government side to bear with me and listen. Perhaps they will see why I consider the bill unfair.
First, we are talking about the requirement that we have developed where the wealthy get into this country no matter what their competency is, no matter what the need is. As long as they have money they jump to the head of the line.
It is like a new head tax except it is much more expensive nowadays. I guess the government is keeping a line on inflation and has decided if you have enough money you can come into the country. It is made even worse with this bill because they are given even higher priority. Actually we are making this injustice even worse than it was before.
The second objection I have concerns the speeding up of the reuniting of families. I understand this has already been done administratively. It is not necessary to have a bill.
We talk about reuniting families and allowing the working family to exist and allowing immigrants to work. However, by the time the paperwork is finished and the citizenship granted, what good does it do a family if they cannot earn any money because they are not Canadian citizens until about one year or 18 months after the paperwork has been done?
What happens to those people who are waiting for their paperwork to be processed? Some of the people in some provinces have to go on welfare. Some of the people in some provinces have to work illegally. They do not pay any taxes. The government is shooting itself in the foot because it does not allow these people to work. It takes so long to give them their citizenship that actually these people are withholding money the government legitimately should have through taxes. This bill does not even address that fundamental problem.
Third, we should look at the fundamental rights of immigrants when you come to this country. We are all immigrants to this country I suppose except for the First Nations. Perhaps I am one of the most recent immigrants. I am an immigrant from the United States.
When I talk about fundamental rights I know what that means when you are an immigrant and you come to

Government Orders
that border and you are given an interview with someone who has more information on you than you know about.
I recall vividly when I went before the immigration authority seeking to become a Canadian citizen after renouncing my American citizenship, after being in the U.S. army for three years, after being honourably discharged, having spent my time in Panama. On the other side of the desk the immigration authority asked me if I had ever been in trouble. Had I ever been in trouble? I wish I had a dime for every time I had been in trouble. I would be a rich man today. I grew up during the turbulent 1960s.
I was in charge of a boycott in my college which saw the president resign. Spiro Agnew, who was the governor of Maryland, jailed me overnight along with others because we were suspected of inciting to riot because we were boycotting classes. We were working with groups affiliated with Martin Luther King. I guess I was some kind of terrorist because I had been arrested for marching in demonstrations.
I knew from information that the immigration authority who was interviewing me had, that I had a chance to respond, to explain, and to give examples. He understood. I was allowed to come into Canada and I guess we are all suffering for that right now.
Here I was, relatively well educated, someone white coming into a country which wanted to have I suppose immigrants such as myself. I had done all the paperwork. Then at that one moment of fundamental right, and we call that audi alteram partem which means being able to speak on the other side and being able to confront your accuser.
We do not have that in this bill. Immigrants will not know what they have got on them. They can say you are a member of some suspicious organization, some terrorist organization. What is the difference between a terrorist and a patriot? The one who wins.
Thlk to me about the Stem gang in Israel. Thlk to me about the PLO, the Contras, talk to me about anyone who is fighting for principle. If you are fighting for principle it takes many different forms, many different ways, and it just takes one high-level bureaucrat to decide you do not fit into his or her way of trying to change society. It does not matter if that is the way it is in
your country. Therefore, you are to be excluded without ever knowing what the accusations were.
That is what is so dishonourable. That is what is so unjust. That is what is so obscene about this bill. You will not have a chance as an immigrant to confront your accuser.
I have another problem with this bill about requiring immigrants to stay in one place. I do not think it can be enforced. On the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee we looked at mobility across the country. We needed mobility, people working where they were needed. We wanted to promote that.
We have a bill right now saying: "Look, you are black. Why not go to Moose Jaw? We think we could have you in Moose Jaw for two, three or four years". "You are brown. Let us see. What colour do we want to paint the northern part of this country?" "Maybe in the eastern part we will make it a little darker hue". This is tantamount to disaster. This will not work. We cannot force people to go into areas where they do not quite naturally belong and where they do not want to be. They are going to go where their families are, and to do otherwise is cruel and unusual punishment.
There are a number of things about Bill C-86, the immigration bill, which I disagree with. It is a contempt of Parliament mainly because much of what is in it is going to be decided by regulation. The government through regulation and orders of cabinet will be able to reward with favours people it wishes to favour and restrict people who it wishes to restrict without having a debate in Parliament.
I think that is wrong. It is even a contempt of the Supreme Court and the Singh judgment of 1985 wherein the Supreme Court said that the government was wrong, that it had to give them a fair hearing, and that it could not exclude people from entering this country without listening to the basic reasons which brought them here.
In conclusion, I would like to say there is a cherry on this cake, this gift to the Reform Party, this pre-electoral cake. The cherry on top of this putrid cake is the ability to cancel retroactively applications which are already working through the system.
June 22, 1992

There are 300,000 applications in the system. This is what the government is talking about when it talks about streamlining. That is its definition of streamlining: retroactively cancelling applications.
I do not know how this fits into the lexicon on the government side when it talks about fairness, equity and streamlining. It seems to me this is a bid to reduce immigration. This is a bid to make it so difficult that people will not try as hard as they have in the past to come to our country.
Perhaps our country has not been the best as far as receiving immigrants, but it has been damn good. If we compare the United States where perhaps 7 per cent to 10 per cent of applicants are admitted to Canada where we have close to 60 per cent admitted, I think it is something to be proud of. Bill C-86 is not something to be proud of. I am very much ashamed that we have a government on the other side which dares to present it.

Mr. Speaker, I am not an authority on immigration but I would say to my hon. colleague, the last speaker, that this bill is not something to be ashamed of. I think, frankly from what I have seen of this bill, that it is something to be very proud of.
It is not surprising that the recent recognition of Canada by the United Nations as the best place to live in all the world has been previously heralded by the immigration and refugee pressures which have been upon this country from virtually every nation around the globe. Canada, as we all know, is in tremendous demand as a place in which to build new lives.
Immigration is not just a one-way consideration, however, because Canada needs new citizens just as surely as so many new Canadians want to come here.
For example, I am told present economic and demographic statistics show a minimum immigration requirement annually of 1 per cent of our population or more than 250,000 new immigrants each year just to keep our economic viability in balance on a population basis.
Contrary to what the hon. member has just said about immigration not increasing, immigration in 1991 was at the level of 220,000 immigrants. In 1992 and onward it is estimated and projected at 250,000 as a constant. The chances are that as conditions dictate, those figures may increase in the future.
Government Orders
Immigrants want Canada and Canada needs immigrants. Thus our immigration policies and management of them are a critical part of our nation's master plan for the future, both economically and socially. This Bill C-86 not only contains important measures to make our immigration program work to an improved potential but it is comprehensive, constructive and responsible. It addresses four main themes. They are the immigration management system, which comprises several areas of attention, selecting and processing immigrants, special programs, provincial and regional interests, geographic and occupational mobility and the Immigrant Investor Program.
The second major structure is that of protecting society, of intercepting illegal immigrants, border controls, new search provisions to enable apprehension at the border and certification of legitimate immigrants at border points and the enforcement of our immigration policies in Canada to prevent abuse to our welfare programs, abuse of the refugee system by criminals and to provide for necessary removals and deportations as they may occur.
The third structural pinnacle of the bill is the refugee status determination system where access and international co-operation are featured, streamlining the system so that the Immigration and Refugee Board operates more efficiently in the service to all involved so that there is timely action with respect to faster landing, clearances to employment, to removals and deportations where required and to an appeal process through the Federal Court of Canada.
Last, the fourth major pinnacle of the structure is that of improved services, procedures which are simplified, response time which is faster, better information systems, issuing and renewing of documents, returning resident permits and perhaps, very significantly also, the transparency of the program, the fact that the rules and the procedures are open and visible to all.
Immigrants are very well served by their new status as permanent Canadian residents, but the increasing numbers of people seeking to enter Canada have put enormous pressures on a system which is not adequately designed to handle them. As a result, the process that immigrants must go through is marred by less than

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
satisfactory service. The road to landed status for an immigrant or a refugee can be filled with line-ups and delays, with uncertainty as to when important events will take place, with forms that are complicated and with rules and procedures that are both hard to understand and unclear as to their purpose.
Unsatisfactory service is both troubling and troublesome as a symptom of certain problems within our immigration program. To deal directly with those causes this Bill C-86 has been introduced. As I said, it contains some very comprehensive elements to bring improvement to our entire immigration system.
The most important of these changes is a plan to subdivide the flow of immigration and refugee requests into three main streams, distinct in priority and procedure. It is worth dwelling on those three streams for clarification.
The first stream is the one which is to be demand driven, where applications will be handled on demand, where there will be no limits. These will include immediate dependent family, spouses and children, refugees and investors and their families. That portion of the immigration flow, based on 1991 figures, I have estimated to be in the order of 24 per cent.
The second stream is what has been termed the first-come first-served stream where there will be limits on the total immigration allowable count and where time standards will be set. These will include parents and grandparents of immigrants and their families and selected refugees from abroad. That category will comprise an estimated 35 per cent of the total immigration flow.
Last, the third stream will be immigrants who are selected for excellence. There will also be a limit on the number of those immigrants annually and there will be a schedule and a timetable. Those will consist of entrepreneurs, not just investors bringing dollars, but entrepreneurs, people will skills, people who have demonstrated their ability to run a business and to create wealth. It will include those with special skills and it will include assisted relatives of families.
In speeding up the process of the immigration flow, earlier this afternoon a reference was made to delays at the immigration office in Delhi. It was suggested that it
was only the immigration officers at that one post who were responsible for bringing about improvements in the processing of spouses and dependent children.
It is true that the immigration officials at our posts throughout the world are very efficient, innovative and have much ingenuity. For the record, I think it is important to note that the improvements at Delhi and at other posts are the direct result of the five-year immigration plan improvements which were introduced in this House in November 1990. The commitments contained in that plan and in that introduction are contained in this bill.
The qualified applicants in stream one as I have said will be processed on demand with no fixed limit to the total number of applications. Those in stream two would be processed on a first come, first serve basis with the total number in each category subject to limits set out in Canada's annual immigration plan. Finally, stream three would include individuals who are selected for excellence, as I have said earlier, entrepreneurs, those with special skills and assisted relatives.
Only the best in this last stream, the most highly skilled or those with skills that the Canadian employers need, will pass through in numbers also corresponding to the limits of the annual plan.
The proposed management streams would greatly improve the treatment of all potential newcomers. If spouses, dependent children, refugees and immigrant investors are placed in stream one they will receive immediate attention. As for those in stream two, the new authority to turn away applications when levels are reached will eliminate backlogs which presently drain our resources and which presently limit our flexibility to handle emergency situations. Finally, no backlogs will be allowed at all in the build-up in stream three, backlogs which presently drain our resources and reduce our flexibility to help others.
In closing, I would just like to say the Immigration Act in 1976 committed Canada to an ongoing immigration program with high principles and a series of clear goals. Those goals which are as vital today as they were then are to help Canadian residents to reunite with close family relatives from abroad. They commit Canada to provide shelter to refugees fleeing persecutions and they promote the development of a strong and viable economy in all regions of Canada.
June 22, 1992

The proposed changes in Bill C-86 will go a long way to reduce frustrations for those immigrating to Canada, to deter cheating at the time of entry and to ensure that the balance among the three primary goals of our immigration policy best serve the interests of all of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, it is my hope that the government will proceed very carefully with this legislation. It is my hope that the government will go out and speak to the special interest groups, church organizations, non-governmental organizations and those in fact who would be affected before this legislation is passed into law.
Just a few days ago I had the pleasure of speaking with a representative of the local organization in my riding, the Bootleggers. They are inviting a team from Moscow to come and play here in Ottawa. The team's name is the Moscow Swans. In fact, the Governor General wrote a very nice letter welcoming the team to Canada.
The team arrived in New York only to be told that they could not enter Canada unless each one of those players pays a $50 fee for his or her visa. This is not very healthy, simply put.
The tourism industry in my view will be the largest industry in Canada over the next few years because of the beautiful land that we have, because of the country that we have. To that extent, to put a charge on each individual who wants to come to Canada to visit will not enhance tourism. It will be a deterrent. That is exactly what happened in this situation in which the people who invited the team to come to Canada in order to celebrate Canada 125 were quite upset and rightly so. There is nothing in the legislation that would give the minister the right or the provision whereby visa charges can be waived.
Having said this, while it does apply to visitors it also applies to immigrants. An applicant for permanent residence would have to pay $350 regardless of whether he or she is approved. How much of that is fair? I think each applicant should go through a preliminary interview with a preliminary application. If he or she passes the test, they can proceed from there. To use the immigration system as a measure to generate revenue to the Government of Canada is not fair. I would suggest it is also discriminatory.
Government Orders
Eighty per cent of the cases that my office deals with are immigration cases, refugee cases and visitor applicants. Believe it or not, in some cases it takes up to three months for somebody who wants to come and visit Canada to get a visitor visa issued. I received a call from a local lawyer who told me in business you have to move fast. If there is a deal here in Canada and a prospective investor from Hong Kong, in this particular case the applicant is from Hong Kong, that prospective investor cannot wait two months to receive his visitor visa to come to Canada and have a look at the project at hand. There are certain aspects that need to be addressed.
In many cases prospective applicants have to wait over two years, separated from their wives and their families, before they hear an answer. I have many people who will arrive in the office asking why their brother or sister or cousin was refused when so and so was accepted: "Why was my brother, who speaks the language and has these qualifications, refused when so and so was accepted?" There is inconsistency and simply put, to a large extent when we talk about applications from outside of Canada, the applicant is at the mercy of an immigration officer. That has to be clarified and put in a way that is consistent.
You bring those landed immigrants here to Canada, many of them with Ph.D.s, with a lot of qualifications. I want to say it has saddened me to see many of them are cab drivers, waiters, garbage collectors, doing all sorts of odd jobs, and not because they want to do those jobs. Simply put, it is because in the way we deal with it, in our educational system, there is absolutely no provision to recognize their qualifications so they could fit in to the mainstream.
I have dealt with a dentist who finished his degree in the United Kingdom. He came here to Canada only to end up being a sales person, a real estate agent, for two and a half years and could not qualify in order to practice as a dentist here in Canada even though he had his degree from the United Kingdom. A physician, an electrical engineer and so on, many of those professions are very much needed here and yet we do not deal with their qualifications in an effective way in which we could give them the accreditation they deserve so they could be full-fledged citizens.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
On second language training, we have many immigrants who bring their moms, their dads or their children who do not have second language training, who do not speak either French or English back at home. Our second language training in Canada is a total failure. Simply put, there is no system that is in place in order to see whether all of this money we are pouring into second language training is getting the results we should be getting.
School-boards are getting stuck with the end product. Many children are coming to a school in which they do not speak the language. The teachers have to be not only social workers but moms, planners, nurses-just about everything.
The government has not done enough in order to set up a fair and equitable system that is accessible whereby we could take our immigrants and put them into the mainstream by first giving them the education they deserve, and that is second language training, or the education they need to become full-fledged citizens.
My colleague from British Columbia alluded a little bit to citizenship. It is a major disaster. The Citizenship Act is a total failure in a lot of ways, not only because an applicant for citizenship would have to wait over one year in order to receive an application form to become a Canadian citizen, but after that one year, once he or she is given the application, they would have to wait up to another eight months to have an interview with a judge, only to be asked by the judge about the length of the St. Lawrence River, the number of lakes between Canada and the United States. These are not the kinds of questions we should be asking landed immigrants. We should be asking landed immigrants about what they have done since they arrived in Canada, whether they have been in trouble with the law, whether they have raised their families, whether they have been full participants in the mainstream. These are the questions we should ask landed immigrants.
My colleague from Quebec agrees with me. He is shaking his head. That is the way we measure citizenship. Unfortunately the Citizenship Act which we have right now is not only discriminatory against potential citizens, it is also unfair, ineffective and a total failure. While we accept in excess of about 250,000 landed immigrants a
year, we are not processing even one-third of that number for people who want to become full-fledged citizens of this country. Simply put, our citizenship courts are full. Take a number, as my colleague is saying; it is a long queue.
Nothing in this bill addresses the question of the full integration of immigrants in Canada. Nothing in this bill addresses the question of citizenship in Canada. Nothing in this bill addresses the question of what to do with qualified landed immigrants once they arrive in Canada.
I want to say that there are a lot of good things in the bill but my suggestion to the government is to go for a full-fledged public consultation before it makes it law.

Mr. Speaker, I thank my friend from Davenport for allowing me this opportunity to discuss for a few moments the contents of the bill that we are presently debating before this House, a bill that is designed to change the immigration policies of Canada.
My comments will be veiy general in nature inasmuch as this bill changes the policy and changes the philosophical principles by which we have built Canada over the past 50 years. The clause by clause interpretation will be handled by my colleague, the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, and myself as members of the immigration committee as the bill finds its way through the committee stage before it is reported again in the House at third reading. We intend to be involved very much in the process of trying to implement the changes that we on this side of the House feel are so necessary with respect to the policies and the philosophy by which immigration should be handled in this country.
Again, as a preface to the bill, it is very interesting to me inasmuch as immigration policies in this country allowed my family to enter Canada some 45 years ago. I guess I could be construed as a product of the immigration policies of Canada at that time. The bill is of particular importance to me because it dictates what we will be doing in the next 50 years in the progress of Canada as we build toward a stronger and unified future.
I would like to repeat the words of our colleague from Windsor West who was applauded in this House just a few days ago for having served 30 years as a member of the House of Commons in almost every portfolio. Let me reiterate his words because I think they express what
June 22, 1992

immigration in Canada is all about in the best terms I have heard. He said:
Mr. Speaker, as you know I am proud to be the son of Jewish immigrants from eastern Europe.
If I could just paraphrase, if any member of this House were speaking she or he could substitute child of Finnish immigrants, Portuguese immigrants, Ukrainian immigrants, Polish immigrants, Cuban immigrants, Haitian immigrants, Italian immigrants, or immigrants from any of the countries Canada has been able to build and draw from for so many years.
The hon. member for Windsor West went on to say:
Looking at the story of my parents and their hopes and aspirations, and looking at my part in that story makes me want to say to the members of this House that it is only a small part of the larger story of the Canadian dream, which is being told and retold every day in this country by the strivings of tens of thousands of people who are working to create better lives for themselves, for their families and thereby to build a better country for all of us.
Those were the words spoken by the member the other day in this House and they are as apropos today as they were 50 years ago.
Our immigration policy and procedure must give those people who choose Canada as the new home for themselves and their families every opportunity to do so in an efficient, streamlined and empathetic manner. We must make future Canadians feel welcome, needed and wanted by the country they have chosen as their new home.
The reality of the fact is history has taught us Canada is no longer a country made up primarily of those with English backgrounds. Nor do we have a country made up primarily of those with francophone backgrounds. Today in Canada more than 12 million Canadians, more than a third of its population, came from other lands and countries around the world.
Many people came to this country at the turn of the century and in the great immigration waves of the late 1940s, early 1950s, and early 1960s. Their fathers, mothers, sons, daughters, grandsons and granddaughters have made very substantial contributions to the future of this country.
They came to Canada with the ability and desire to work. They came to Canada because they wanted freedom and hopefully they came to Canada because they
Government Orders
wanted to make a better life for themselves and their children.
I think it is inevitable when we look at what Canada is today, that the United Nations just recently voted Canada the number one country in the world in which to live.
Those people who came from all the countries in the world and chose Canada as their home have truly succeeded in helping to make Canada the country it is.
With this bill we are not just talking about another piece of legislation. We are not just talking about another bill. We are talking of developing a philosophy through this new immigration law of where Canada shall go as a country in the next 50 years.
There is no question in my mind once we overcome this debate on unity we are presently going through, many of the people who choose Canada as their home will add as substantially as those who have come to Canada in the past 50 years.
As a result, the legislation must be regarded not as just another piece of legislation, but it must be regarded as a philosophical concept of how we want and where we want this country of ours to go.
I must show my displeasure, not with the entire contents of the legislation but with the manner and procedure which was used to introduce it into this House. Last week the immigration bill that will guide Canada's immigration policy for perhaps the next decade, was introduced on Wednesday in this House. There was a short debate on it Friday-Monday is also a short day in this House. I am told-I was not able to be here early today-time allocation was announced and some one hour and a half from now there will be a vote for passage at second reading and then the bill will go to a committee.
To develop such important policy for the country, to develop the criteria we are going to need to help us build this country, we cannot do justice to this bill by speaking on it in this place for just 10 or 15 or 20 minutes over a shortened debate. There are many members on this side of the House and I am sure on that side, who want to make a contribution that elected members of Parliament

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
should be making with respect to the future allocation of people in this country.
I wish that I did have more time to expound on some of these principles. Let me say something else about this legislation. It is time-and I come to the support of all the municipalities in this country-that we stopped passing legislation that passes the burden of cost on to the municipalities. I see in this legislation, just in a cursory review, that again we have not come to grips with the fact that we make the laws and we pass the burden of responsibility for most of the costing on to the municipalities right across this country. We know that in these difficult economic times the costs involved in welfare, schooling and hospitalization are passed to the provinces which passes them on to the municipalities. It is putting a heavy burden of responsibility on these communities, which is intolerable.
As we go through the committee structure after second reading approval, we must always bear in mind on this side of the House, as will I hope my colleagues on the left, that we must stop putting the burden of responsibility for paying for legislation at the federal level on the municipalities of this country.
Those two areas are the only two areas that I have the time to discuss today and I thank you very much for the opportunity of making those two points.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak to a bill that will fundamentally change our immigration system. This bill will give great arbitrary powers to use discretion in immigration selection. Instead of fair rules, which treat immigrants as human beings, a big brother attitude will now permeate the Canadian immigration system.
Immigrants to Canada will be required to live in a place chosen by the Canadian state, despite the wishes and the family and support networks that these immigrants might have elsewhere in Canada. Immigrants to Canada will be required to work in an occupation chosen by the Canadian state despite the skills, training and education they may have in another occupation.
I know of a doctor from India who was working as a taxi driver because his credentials as a doctor were not accredited in Canada. This type of situation can only
increase under this bill. That doctor may at least now have the opportunity to requalify for his profession, but under this bill the Canadian government can say that there are too many doctors in Canada, you are not allowed to qualify or work as a doctor. You must drive a taxi or sweep floors instead.
This is clearly a violation of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. More than that, it breaks the code of common sense and compassion to which I believe all Canadians aspire. Canadians are proud of their country. We see our country as being a tolerant country in a free society. The new immigration system is not tolerant and limits the fundamental freedoms of a certain class of human beings within Canada. It is simply wrong.
Along the big brother theme, this bill gives border officials greater powers to detain, even fingerprint and photograph people arriving, particularly refugee claimants, but also Canadians. These border officials have not necessarily received any anti-racist training.
I want to tell you a story about a person who worked with me here in my Ottawa office. She was from the west coast like me. She was sitting in a committee room one day with many others in the audience listening to an important session on my behalf. A security guard came into the room and surveyed all the people as a matter of routine. There was no disturbance, no noise. All the people in the room were white except for the staff person who worked with me.
The guard walked across the entire room to demand to see her House of Commons pass. She showed it to him immediately. He looked at the pass then looked at her again and said: "Whom do you work for?" She said: "Dawn Black". He asked: "What is the phone number of her office?" This kind of checking is unheard of. She had a valid pass, she told him the office number and he still looked suspicious but he then dropped the matter. He did not approach anyone else in that crowded room. He approached the only person in that room that was not white.
This is not an isolated incident. Black and aboriginal people talk about being stopped on the streets by the police when they were simply walking, talking, shopping or attending to their own business.
June 22, 1992

We have all read in the papers of examples of refugee officials being insensitive, such as the recent case of two refugee board officials making fun of the fact that a man had been tortured.
Refugee boards have ruled to send women back who would face persecution, violence and perhaps even death in their country of origin because these officials did not understand the different cultures in the world. A story broke only last year about a Canadian immigration official demanding sex from a woman in exchange for entry to Canada.
Most immigration officials are trying to do the best they can and operate ethically, but they are overworked, understaffed and under a great deal of strain.
We have also heard of instances where there have been abuses of power. These front line government officials certainly need more support and training, particularly, anti-racist and anti-sexist training. We need employment equity with mandatory goals and timetables in these and in all Public Service professions to ensure that these officials reflect what is the diversity of Canada.
This big brother bill would also turn away refugees who come to Canada through a third country that Canada has ruled to be safe. This is neglecting our role in the international community. Canada does not border any country from which refugees can come directly. Canada's new rule would mean that countries bordering other nations from which refugees come would be inundated and overloaded with refugees that have no hope then of going on to settle somewhere else. It is not fair to expect only a handful of countries in the world to take the entire load of refugees.
Canada cannot remain a strong and proud member of the international community if we send refugees back the way we have seen recently, the way the Americans are doing with the Haitian refugees right now. Canada has had a shameful past in this regard. It is important for all of us to acknowledge that and to remember it.
Before and during World War II Canada refused entry to Jewish refugees from Europe who were attempting to escape from certain persecution and death.
Government Orders
The Komagata Maru was a ship of predominantly Sikh passengers which sailed to Vancouver and arrived in 1914. They, like many Europeans, wanted to emigrate to Canada. The ship sat in the Vancouver harbour, denied docking, and Canadian officials would not even allow supplies of food and water to be taken aboard. The Canadian government sent those people back.
My riding has a large Indo-Canadian community which has in fact enriched our economy and enriched the culture of the Vancouver region. Many discretionary measures have been used in Canada's immigration past. The Chinese head tax was used to limit Chinese immigration to Canada. The Asiatic Exclusion League stirred up hatred against Chinese and Japanese immigrants and targeted Asian businesses for physical attack and looting.
This big brother bill before us would pass regulations similar to those passed in 1908 to limit Asian immigration. In 1908 a Canadian government regulation was passed requiring immigrants to arrive in Canada by way of a continuous journey from their place of birth or citizenship. As there was no direct steamship from India, this measure virtually eliminated immigration from India.
In 1992 this regulation has been recycled for refugees. Only those who have made it directly to Canada and not passed through any so-called safe third country can stay here. There are no direct flights or ships or any other means of transportation from Somalia, Sri Lanka, El Salvador, Guatemala, China, Bulgaria, Iran or Lebanon, and most other countries in this world in turmoil.
In 1907 Prime Minister Robert Borden said in a speech in Vancouver: "British Columbia must remain a white man's country". The Prime Minister redrafted immigration regulations citing an overcrowded labour market in British Columbia and made it illegal for those of certain occupations to enter B.C. Of course those occupations were predominantly those of Asian immigrants.
In 1992 this government is revisiting these regulations. This proposed legislation sets up a system of quotas by country or otherwise that can be used to weed out immigrants from so-called undesirable places.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
One's country of origin says nothing about how hard working someone is, how much they care about their family and society, how willing they are to contribute in every way to an economy and to our society. Everyone deserves an equal chance based on their own ability to adapt to Canada, not on some stereotypical notion a bureaucrat or a politician may have about their country of origin.
In addition, this big brother legislation restricts the principle of benefit of the doubt in Immigration and Refugee Board hearings, a principle to which Canada subscribes through its signature on UN conventions. Refugee claimants are assumed to be lying or defrauding the system even if there is no proof. This bill also further restricts the right to appeal, which is the right of all other persons in Canada.
The time for racism is over. Canada should be able to prove to the world that we are all equal no matter what race we are and that we can all live and work together, share our ideas and our customs and respect each other's religious beliefs. This is the tolerant and harmonious Canada I want to live in and work for, one in which everyone has equal access to the justice system, to services, and to fair and respectful treatment.
This bill and its cousin, the new immigrant language training program, are not steps toward this goal. This bill not only disregards the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms but also the UN conventions that Canada has signed. It is a step backward into a tarnished past.
This is Canada's 125th birthday. We should remember the positive aspects of our past and become active in changing what needs to be changed in our society.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling me that my time is up.
I just want to mention that we should remember, unless we are First Nations people, that we or our ancestors arrived in this country as immigrants. For the sake of peace in our country and around the world, we must eliminate racism and all unfairness, and we should begin with immigration and refugee system.

Mr. Speaker, one of the negative aspects of this proposed measure is that it reinforces the government's favouritism toward immigrant applicants from the Third World who are wealthy
and well educated. My colleague from York West earlier today spoke quite eloquently about the discriminatory and negative effect of that policy for Canada. I would like to talk about its disastrous consequence from a sustainable development perspective, and particularly seen from the southern hemisphere perspective.
What we have here is a government which is working at cross-purposes with itself. On the one hand it funds the International Development Research Centre as previous governments have. If I remember correctly, it was founded in 1971. It does so for the purpose of supporting the establishment of scientific, educational and social infrastructures in the developing world. In doing so it supports the work of researchers and scientists in the developing world to develop research that helps the economic and social well-being of the people in the southern hemisphere where most of the developing nations are.
This work has two purposes: to help developing nations deal with its problems on their own terms and to help the educated elite to remain in the land for the total benefit.
The International Development Research Centre in major part was established to help developing countries begin to provide the necessary leadership, educational structures, research facilities and international prestige for their educated citizens so that they would stay at home and help in the development of their economies and their structures.
Yet on the other hand the government brings forward for consideration by this House a bill which would entice the well educated population in the developing world to emigrate, and hence aggravate an already serious brain drain to the northern hemisphere, toward developed countries.
Much mention is made of the growing wealth gap between north and south, the growing brain drain to the northern hemisphere of intellectuals and scientists from the south to the north. It is a serious matter. Emigration of educated persons from the south to a country such as Canada represents a much greater loss for the country of origin, since there are fewer individuals in the developing world to carry out the difficult struggle of providing the necessary expertise.
The world population is expected to double between now and the year 2050 to 10 billion. This bill seems to have been conceived in a vacuum. It does not deal with long-term population policies. It does not deal with the size that we intend or expect in our urban centres since most immigrants settle in urban centres. It is a measure that seems to be conceived as a reaction or as an attempt
June 22, 1992

to improve previous measures. It does not have any sense of vision nor a sense of long-term breadth and scope. It is just intended to rectify here and rectify there.
We must take into account the fact that over 80 per cent of this doubling of the population from 5 billion to 10 billion will take place in the developing world. With a consequent reduction in resources such as fresh water and arable land, the need for these developing nations to keep their own expertise becomes more crucial than ever. Bangladesh, not Canada, will need its best people to solve its critical problems. At the OECD in Paris, a publication was produced in 1989 which dealt with the impact of international migration on developing countries. In that OECD report the following statement is made:
Migration of manpower from a developing to a developed country is bad because it inflicts irreparable losses on the former and robs it of irreparable innovative individuals.
It goes on to say:	_
The brain drain leads to increased inequality; the rich countries continue to become richer while the poor countries become poorer- It removes strategic manpower from key positions in a country, causes loss of present and future production, of present and future saving, of taxes and potential innovation.
One must conclude that the Conservative government's pursuit of immigration policies which result in the steady increase of educated elites as successful applicants at the expense of a southern hemisphere developing nation is wrong within this broader context. It is wrong within the longer term and within the perspective of Canada's aid and development and international research policies aimed at assisting developing countries. In other words, it does not make sense. It does not add up.
On refugees, I would like to bring to the attention of the House because of this debate the plight of Somali refugees in the city of Toronto where I come from.
In the first quarter of this year some 118 Somali refugee claimants have been rejected by the department. Why? Because of the claim that safe areas do exist for Somalis in their native land to which they can return. I submit that these claims are inaccurate.
Government Orders
The minister of immigration must be aware-and if he is not he should perhaps have a briefing by his colleague, the Secretary of State for External Affairs-Somalia is in a state of unbridled chaos without any sort of government in control.
The International Red Cross has stated that Somalia is presently suffering from the worst inhuman situation in the world today, without exception. Somali families are separated, many living in dangerous situations in then-native land or in refugee camps in Kenya.
Measures are needed for those who are here. This was stressed and underlined by public demonstrations on June 4 at Queen's Park in Toronto.
It was repeatedly asked that the department of immigration do the job it was intended to do traditionally. That job is to provide settlement and adjustment programs for people who come to Canada as refugees and as immigrants upon arrival so as to facilitate and accelerate their integration into Canadian society. In the case of the Somali refugees it has been an abysmal failure so far.
In this measure there is also a denial of mobility rights if this proposal becomes law. It is unacceptable that one should expect from immigrants, be they in the category of refugees or otherwise, to give up their freedom of movement which every Canadian has. Once an immigrant is landed in this country that person cannot be expected to live in a designated area and remain there unless there are strong incentives for that purpose.
I hope the minister will reconsider that clause so that the legislation covering immigrants to Canada will allow them the same basic mobility rights that have been recognized for Canadians in general.
{Translation}

Mr. Speaker, it cannot be repeated often enough that immigration and refugee determination do not apply the same criteria. We use immigration to try and meet the needs of this country. Our economic interests, our manpower requirements-which often include the need for skilled workers-and family reunification all meet the needs of this country. I would like to stress that yes, family reunification responds to the need of Canadians to live with their families. However, when we admit refugees, We are meeting their needs, their need for security. The

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
1951 Geneva convention where the signatory countries agreed to wave their right to select those who enter the country, is an exception to the rule of international law.
This evening, I will speak very briefly about immigration, but I would prefer to focus on the issue of refugee status determination. As far as immigration is concerned, the government has announced that in the family class, files will be processed according to specific deadlines. The government says that its objective will be to process applications from people in the immediate family category in six months, whether they apply in Germany or in India. We welcome this kind of specific timeframe and objective. I hope the government will be able to meet this objective.

As I said, I want to concentrate most of my remarks on the question of the determination of refugee status because I believe that it is in this area that the government is spreading misconceptions about the nature of the problem we face and about the nature of the humanitarian question we are trying to deal with.
In reading this bill and listening to the speeches of the spokespersons for the government, I have to conclude that the government has not learned very much.
I believe that the minister should apologize to Canadians for wasting taxpayers' money in the past five years. He should apologize to church groups and other nongovernmental organizations. He should apologize to immigration lawyers. He should apologize to Rabbi Plaut for ignoring their advice. They all said that the initial screening would not work.
I want to emphasize that this government five years ago set up a two-stage process. The first stage was a screening known as the credible basis stage when it was the job of an adjudicator and a member of the refugee division to determine whether there was a credible basis for the claim. The second stage was the hearing on the merits before two members of the refugee division.
Rabbi Plaut, in his report submitted to this government in about 1985, rejected the idea of screening out refugee claimants with what are really known in international practice as manifestly unfounded claims which is really what the credible basis process was all about.
He reviewed this practice in those countries that had tried to introduce such a screening system only to find it unworkable. In these countries some cases which at first were judged to be manifestly unfounded claims eventually were determined to be refugees by a higher authority.
Rabbi Plaut then said that kind of procedure was not needed, but the government ignored all of the unanimous advice it received and went ahead.
I refer to the document that the government tabled with this bill last week. Today, the government says:
"The first stage has proved less effective and more costly than expected. Experience has shown that over 95 per cent of claimants have a credible basis for their claims so that the first stage actually screens out very few claimants. This preliminary stage will be eliminated. This change alone will reduce delays in the system by three to six months, depending on the circumstances of specific cases".
This was the recommendation of the non-govemmen-tal organizations and Rabbi Plaut six years ago. Does the minister today acknowledge the error he made? Does he acknowledge the enormous costs that were imposed on people, the delays in people's lives? Does he say he made a mistake but today he recognizes this and is going to correct that mistake? Not a chance. Not one chance that this government would admit a mistake even as blatant as that one.
Another mistake which shows again that the government has not learned from past experience is the lack of an appeal. Again this is an area in which the government ignored the advice of non-governmental organizations and failed to provide refugee claimants an appeal on the merits from a negative decision of the refugee board. This bill, again, provides for no such appeal. The government, presumably, has not recognized the folly of its ways. Because there is no appeal the only recourse for an unsuccessful refugee claimant is to apply to the minister for consideration on compassionate or humanitarian grounds.
June 22, 1992

The circumstances under which such considerations are given are extremely restrictive. Inevitably it ends up on the minister's desk. This recourse, as I said, because it is so restrictive, is futile. In Ontario and Quebec in 1991 only 23 such applications were accepted out of a total of 3,485. The door is practically hermetically sealed.
What I would like to suggest to the minister and to the government tonight is that they provide an appeal on merits and if they did we would not need this futile procedure known as an application on humanitarian and compassionate grounds to the minister.
Why should there be an appeal? I would like to ask the House to reflect on the reasons for courts of appeal in general, in civil and in criminal law in our system of law. Quite simply it is because people make mistakes. Should there not be an appeal on decisions when it is a matter of life and death?
Remember the context. Refugees have left their homes because of war and persecution. Even refugee claimants who one might expect to be fairly articulate, such as lawyers, teachers and union leaders, have been known to break down during refugee hearings. They have been unable to face the past, unable to talk about the experiences to which they have been subjected. We must understand that refugee claimants are in a new country. They may speak neither English nor French. Unquestionably they are unfamiliar with our laws and our procedures.
It is vital that such an appeal be provided for by the government in this procedure. Again, I hope this is an area which the government would reconsider.
In closing, I wish to quote from a communique published by the Canadian Council for Refugees which said that it is disturbed by the language and orientation of the government's statements. The emphasis and control and abuse, not justified by any available statistics, will undermine public sympathy for refugees.
As I said earlier in comments in the House this evening, this is perhaps the most deplorable aspect of the government's campaign of disinformation. By standing up and suggesting that we have somehow lost control of our borders, by standing up and suggesting that the country is being flooded by thousands of refugees with totally unfounded claims not supported by any statistics, this government is setting up a straw man which it will then proceed to knock down with its legislation and with its speeches in what I regard as a very cynical gesture.
Government Orders
I am confident that Canadians will not accept this subterfuge.

Mr. Speaker, this is a very important bill because it signals the reality of Canada in the global context.
There are not too many things we can be sure of in this day and at this time. We can be sure of one thing and that is that the population of the world is growing. We are now talking about five billion people. These are five billion people who are crowding the borders of almost every nation in the world.
They are crowding the cities of the world. As they crowd they seek what we have and that is open space, the number one place, the best country in the world according to the United Nations. Naturally there is a strong demand in the world for Canada, a strong demand that cannot possibly be met by Canada alone.
This is complicated by the situation that the world used to move freely among itself. The world no longer moves freely among itself. It used to be that in the world there were many countries that should you or I or anyone else choose to move to, you could do so easily. It used to be that if there were a political or a natural catastrophe here, you could move across the border in the next place and it would welcome you.
Those welcome mats have disappeared everywhere in the world. Every country has said it has closed its borders. Canada was the last country to come to this closing process through a target or quota system, a quota system that was put in place by every nation in the world in a very stringent way.
The world borders have been closing and as the world's borders close, it creates the 10 or 15 million refugees in the world; displaced people who cannot find another country for their home.
There are a lot coming as the hon. member knows. We were both in those refugee camps. Bud Cullen was the Liberal minister at the time and I said to him when we set that target level back why not take some as refugees. They would make the best citizens in the world we could find; people fleeing for their safety and their security from their own country. I asked: "Why not set a target of 5,000?" He said to me, and it is in the proceedings of the committee: "Good idea. If you think you have the Conservatives", the opposition at that time, "to go

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
along, then let us have a look at it". Six weeks later he announced 5,000, the first target of refugees.
Then in 1978-79, we had the boat people and our minister in government at that time said it would take 60,000.
What we were doing in that process was responding to a world that was tightening down and opening our doors to a very worthwhile group of people who have made fine citizens for Canada. Really we only opened the door a little crack because what is 60,000 out of 15 million? Anyone in a refugee camp would choose to come to Canada given that opportunity.
Canada as an oasis of hope and opportunity is facing the pressures of a world that wishes to come here. What a change from 40, 60 years ago when Canada went out and advertised for immigrants: please come to Canada. It had to give all kinds of incentives to come to Canada. That is not the situation today and our Immigration Act needs to reflect that. Canada is under the pressure of a massive number of applications. Our program now is to choose from among those applications, both in the interest of the person wishing to come and in the interest of our country.
The interest of our country changes from time to time. Right now there is a very strong interest and need in our country for young people with skills to come and help us build our country. There is a need for business men and business immigration and our act addresses this issue. It says we should welcome the entrepreneurs and business men of the world because this is now a global economy. Any part of the world that says it is going to be an isolated island is doomed to failure, poverty and a reduced quality of life.
We have to respond to choice. We have made the most generous choice of any nation in the world by saying we will set a target of 250,000. Who will these 250,000 be? As I said, they need to be young people, skilled people and business people. Of course we must have a very special place for immediate family and true and legitimate refugees. That is what this act says.
I do not think there is a Canadian sitting there listening to us tonight or reading in Hansard tomorrow who would disagree with those priorities. That is what
this legislation is doing. It is saying we will create stream one and we will not put a limit on it. In that stream we will look to the priority of Canada's needs: immediate family, refugees and business immigration.
Of course that is not to say I agree with everything in the report. My immigration committee will report back to the House soon I hope. We are getting near the end and we are going to support business immigration. We are recognizing business immigration is more than just investors who will not become actively involved and just invest money in Canada. It is also entrepreneurs and the self-employed.
Therefore we suggest the government give us an idea of how the system might work. It is not fixed in stone at this stage. The government will look at the report of our committee and at the Ernst & Whinney report that is coming in later. It will take the Ferguson task force report, its own internal report and we will create the regulations that look to these kinds of examples as outlined here.
Obviously we want to take control of Canada. What kind of a government would not take control of Canada? That means we shall select the millions of people who want to come here in the interest of Canada, our country. That is 250,000 now for the next three years and perhaps some adjustment to that target over the intervening years. Perhaps that target will even grow because as we become stronger perhaps this country should not be just 30 million. Maybe it should be 50 million. Maybe 50 million is a viable population, a small not very dense population for the second largest country in the world that can deliver a high quality of life and place for many more people in the world. The old days have gone. Looking at our land as a vast empty unused land just waiting to be filled is an entirely wrong concept in this day and age.
Let us modernize our act. Let us gain control of those who are coming into Canada illegally and let us sort them out. Let us keep those who are legitimate refugees and let us send the rest home and tell them to come and pick through the regular process. I know this is what my constituents want. They want the government to take control of immigration. They want the government to use immigration to build Canada. They want to show our compassionate side through conventional refugees. They want to show our human side through recognizing

immediate family and they want to build our economy through recognizing business immigration.
All of us here have a responsibility to participate in this act, in its process, to get it to committee, to travel across the country and hear the views of Canada. As we hear the views of Canada, and I know that the opposition knows in their heart their job is to oppose, but they know that this act is the right place and the right time.
I have been working on this committee for many years.
I remember 1975 changes, 1976 and 1977 in the committee. I think this is the right time, this is the right act and I support it most energetically and enthusiastically.
Mr. Speaker, I would like to seek the unanimous consent of the House to revert to tabling of committee reports, with your permission.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, if the parliamentary secretary wants to table anything, I am sure we would be amenable to the usual consultation and after that is done, be willing to do that. I think this is highly irregular to do so without such consultations. If there have been consultations I have not been made aware of them, as the acting person directing the debate for our group tonight. Neither the critic nor myself have been made aware of this and we would prefer this consultation first. We will revert to that if there is consent at a later time.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: As I understand, there is not unanimous consent at this time.

Mr. Speaker, it has been a pleasure to sit in the House and listen to the debate and listen to the comments, the direction and the tenor. I of course prefer our side of the argument rather than the side opposite, but it has been interesting to hear the discussion and to see the different points of view as we approach this legislation.
I do not think anybody doubts that Canada has to have an improved immigration law and that we have to have a proper system of immigration. All we have to do is look at our history to realize that is an essential component of building this nation. As we look at the history we see that immigration primarily from Europe made an absolutely most important contribution to making Canada what it is today.
Government Orders
