We hear some of the naysayers and some of the negative people in our country saying it is time to close the door and to shut down immigration all together. All we have to do is to look at the statistics to realize the implications of that.
If we were to shut off immigration entirely now, by the year 2010 we would probably only have about 13 million Canadians because our birth rate is not keeping up and we would face that eventual decline in population rather than an increase. I read as well, and statistics will indicate this, that by the year 2015 if we just keep the present level of immigration, then our population will only be around 17 or 18 million. We need to have immigration if we are going to survive as a country, maintain the social programs and all of the things that we hold dear in Canada.
Immigration can make a tremendous contribution to this nation, but I think we have to realize that immigration as it is now happening will drastically change the mosaic of this nation. There will be a change and it will be one that will cause some people some difficulty. There are all kinds of misconceptions about immigrants and refugees coming and stealing jobs from Canadians, that they are making things difficult and lowering the wage rate, all of those types of arguments. Those are misconceptions that have to be cleared away from this issue.
We have to analyse the legislation on its merits to see whether it achieves the goals that we want. That is for a system that is fair and equitable to all and allows proper immigration and refugees to reach our shores and our country and to be properly taken care of once they are here. We on this side are most supportive of the concept of coming up with legislation and amendments to legislation in order to achieve that goal and that objective. But when you look at this particular bit of legislation, does it achieve the goal? We have to say, no, it does not.
As is typical, there are always some good sides to the legislation and there are some things we are supportive of. Obviously the first stage hearing being eliminated is a positive step because it did not work. It did not have any effect. About 90-some-odd per cent of the people got through that stage no matter what was there. In that sense it did not work.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
We are concerned about things, and all we have to do is look at them very quickly because time is limited. This bill shifts the onus away from this place and puts it in the regulations and in the hands of administration, rather than having legislation with the weight of legislation.
There is a shift in authority. One wonders where the accountability will be. We know that we should have those regulations at least as a bare minimum brought back to this place to be reviewed to see there is the just system that we are all striving for.
We are concerned as well about the idea of a safe third country and the concept that if a refugee passes through a country before arriving in Canada, we can send that person back to that "safe country". All you have to do is look at the example of some of the people who have fled countries through the United States to arrive here, knowing that if they are sent back to the United States they will be sent back to their own country and face the responsibilities of fleeing that country and the possibility of death associated with that type of decision. So we have concerns about the safe third country concept.
We agree with the idea that there is more discipline as far as the refugee board is concerned. We have all been appalled at some of the shenanigans that have gone on with respect to that. In that sense we would like to see the changes put in so that something is accomplished there.
We also have to look at what happens in this whole area and what happens to new arrivals to our country. At the same time this government is cutting back on social programs and putting added burdens on the provinces and we are not sure whether the housing and the health and educational systems are in place to handle what is contemplated. I think we have to go back and hear more and not rush this legislation. Rushed legislation is normally bad legislation and this bill has the potential to be quite bad in the long run.
We are concerned about the idea that the minister can pick where an immigrant or a refugee will go once they arrive here. That is fundamentally opposed to our Charter of Rights and Freedoms. I know that there are many people in this country who will say well, you do not acquire those rights and freedoms until after you are admitted into the country as either a landed immigrant
or accepted as an immigrant, up until then you have no rights, and then you do not even have rights until you really become a citizen. That is wrong. The charter of rights is to protect all because those are fundamental rights. They do not have to be designated that they are rights for only certain people.
I am worried about the idea that a lot of the decisionmaking process will fall into the hands of administrators. We had a problem in Moncton, quite frankly, under the refugee program that was trying to attract entrepreneurs. I know there are all sorts of questions about whether you are buying a passport into Canada. In looking at that whole process and hearing the testimony of Zuoy Lam from Moncton, the investors were told: "Do not come to New Brunswick, it is a bad area. You should not be there, you will lose all your money. They are poor investments". This is the type and calibre of person who is advising people as to where they should be going.
As well, you hear things about the administration having fingerprinting and photos and greater powers of search. I think we are going to have to take a good long look at those types of provisions to see whether the legislation is treating refugees and immigrants fairly, as our system should.
There are many other reasons and rationale for us to take a long steady look at this legislation.
There is no provision for appeals on merit, to name some. There is nothing in the legislation that deals with the use of section 114 and the admission of refugees on humanitarian or compassionate grounds. There is nothing to deal with refugees who were legitimate when they fled their country, but now that things have changed- and we see that in eastern Europe-they are being asked to go back home. We have even seen that in my community. We have a small population of refugees and immigrants, but we have seen that happen.
What is fundamental in all of this-and I am sure that all of us on this side of the House are most concerned about it-is the use of time allocation in order to ram this legislation through. We have known for months and months and months that this legislation was necessary, that it had to come forward. Then, at the time when the democratic process provides a chance to have an input,
June 22, 1992

this government brings in time allocation and gives in effect a day for debate or less than a day.
Under those circumstances we on this side cannot support quick passage. There may be some aspects that we are supportive of, some things that we want to see improved, but we cannot have this type of legislation rammed down the throats of Canadians and soon to be Canadians.
We on this side are going to oppose this legislation on some of the grounds that will become clear in committee but also on account of the high-handed manner in which this government has proceeded.

I rise on a point of order, Mr. Speaker. There have been discussions on both sides of the House, and I would like to seek Your Honour's permission and unanimous consent of the House to revert to the tabling of committee reports.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Is there unanimous consent?
Agreed.
48TH REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present the 48th report of the Standing Committee on House Management.
Pursuant to Standing Order 113(1), this report is deemed adopted upon presentation.
[.Editor's Note: See today's Votes and Proceedings.]

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Valcourt that Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof,
Government Orders
be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope; and the amendment of Mr. Allmand (p. 12472).

Mr. Speaker, I rise to join what is for my constituency perhaps the most important debate this House has dealt with, that is the rules in this country concerning immigration.
This has been an issue that Canadians have gone back and forth with perhaps every decade since World War II, but it is time that we come to grips with this issue, to show the progressive side of this country and to put aside a lot of the concerns and hesitation we have shown in the past.
Unfortunately Bill C-86 amending the Immigration Act is in fact a step backward. This bill is extremely complex and deals with 128 sections and 113 pages. It was presented to the House only a week ago. The House has been asked to deal with it in a very speedy fashion, which those Canadians concerned about legislation find very hard to believe.
I would like to spend my very short time in this debate because of the curtailment of debate explaining to Canadians why a more progressive piece of legislation is needed.
All parliamentarians hear from Canadians their concerns about the job market, about the changing nature of Canada, and about somehow or other losing a sense of what we were in the past through immigration policy. Governments come to represent one way or the other the voice of the past or the voice of the future. It is time this government realizes that it must become the voice of the future, not the voice of the past.
Let me give an example of an area of policy with which this government has refused to deal and which is fundamental to understanding this country. Several weeks ago the government introduced changes in family reunification. Leaving aside the details for the purpose of this debate, they have made it very difficult to bring family members over. Bill C-86 has not in any way addressed the question of the limitations put on family reunification.
For many of the people watching and listening to the debate, questions of family reunification seem to be, in the old Canadian sense, a question of bringing over mothers, sisters, aunts, uncles, cousins and distant relatives simply to have people together in the same house,

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
in the same neighbourhood. It is a social reason for many Canadians and that is all.
For Canadians wishing to retain in their mind a traditional notion of the country, this is offensive because they ask the question in times of high unemployment, in times of the deep recession, why we need so many people when we already have enough here in this country.
If we stop to think of it from a different point of view, if we stop and ask ourselves the basic question about the Canadian economy, we all know from various studies done in the late 1960s right through until the 1980s that the Canadian economy is facing a very difficult problem of foreign ownership.
If we leave aside the banking industry, almost every industrial sector in this country is owned by non-Canadians. We continue to be depleted by profits, by dividends and by industrial strategies outside our country.
We ask ourselves how in the next 30 or 40 years we build up the Canadian corporate structure. We must do it through some type of industrial base, manufacturing base and service industry in this country.
Then we ask who is going to come into this country to build up a base and use that base to expand and take on the country.
The answer in many cases is families working together. Families work together because they trust each other with cash. They trust each other's commitment. They trust each other's use of cash. They move from one generation to the other. It is no good trying to think that one generation is going to build up a company that is going to take on the whole world. In three or four generations they will be able to take on the world if they have enough family members working together. Canadians forget about that because many Canadians have not been involved with the building of a business.
We hear the international trade cliche. We hear the Minister for International Trade talk about competitiveness, getting out and facing the world. Let us stop and think about what the world is. Let us stop and think about our industrial growth rate being somewhere in the optimistic range of 1.5 per cent or 2 per cent per year to perhaps even a shrinkage. Then we can look at the Asian countries which are averaging 3 per cent, 4 per cent, 5
per cent and 7 per cent for the sake of argument. Sometimes it is higher than that. Over a 10-year period, 10 times 3 is 30 per cent growth; 10 times 7 compounded means a doubling of the size of the economy; and 10 times 1 per cent is probably a total growth over a decade of 12 per cent.
The growth we are looking for is over in Asia. To delve into Asian markets means we must have language skills, cultural skills and a knowledge of that particular business community.
I for one, as much as I want to encourage people, will never be an expert trader in Vietnam, Cambodia, Hong Kong, China, Japan, Indonesia or the Philippines, but I want some Canadians to be there. I want some Canadians to have a base for trading from Canada into those countries so that we understand their trading patterns and we understand how to use what they are doing to our benefit.
A family nucleus of two or three people will come over as refugees or immigrants by other patterns. When new Canadians come to me, they say they want their brother, their sister, their aunt or their cousin to come in. It is not because for some romantic reason they want to share a roof, but it is because they want to build a business. It is the people who come from the refugee camps out of Vietnam who will form the nucleus of our business community.
When a government does not stand up, does not share belief in the House and does not articulate that belief for other Canadians, people do not realize the economic benefits to be gained through family reunification. We must take the effort to make sure we develop trade strategies, immigration policies and business support policies. If we want to begin to deal with the world, we must bring home this message to individual Canadian families who are dealing with our immigration policy. The department is not capable of dealing with these issues with optimism and openness. They receive too many messages from their political leaders, that in fact they should be very careful as to how they deal with different communities.
I say this is the opportunity to change this position. The bill as I noted at the outset of my short time of speaking here is a very complex one and I do not pretend that I can deal with more than one or two issues of the 128 being presented to the House.
June 22, 1992

I will say to the House and through the House to Canadians that this government has set us upon a course that is greatly disturbing to people who want to see responsible government. In the last month we have seen a number of initiatives, from immigration policy to the child benefit package, which has been thrust upon us out of nowhere to deal with immediately.
The government is not giving due time to consider how we want to build the country -and one can read on the front pages of the newspapers forever about the Constitution -not dealing with a fundamental openness and honesty in each step along the way, the Canadians you want here, how you want to build the businesses, how you are going to look after children, I could go on and on with the list.
Here the government is asking for the discussion of this bill in a few short hours today, to be hustled off to committee, to be buried from public view because it is answering some political instinct which to quote from one newspaper on May 6: "Tory immigration policy mirrors Reform Party".
It is not the task of Parliament to pursue narrow partisan interests. It is the task of Parliament to consider basic issues of immigration in the context of family development and economic development.
I beseech the government to reconsider its position, to be kinder to refugees, to be kinder to immigrants. If we want a kinder and gentler Canada the place to begin is the withdrawal of Bill C-86 and the rethinking of the immigration policy for the 21st century.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to take a few minutes this evening to speak on the bill that is before the House.
Immigration issues are never easy for Parliament to deal with. Unfortunately, it is all too easy for some to criticize immigration policies and it is all that easier when those you are criticizing do not look the same as other so-called typical Canadians.
Of course what I am indicating to you is that many times we behave in a manner that we cannot always be proud of when we are dealing with these issues. I remember that day in 1986 when Canada was allegedly invaded by 172 people from the Indian subcontinent, more particularly, from Sri Lanka, Tamil refugees that arrived on our shores.
Government Orders
This government recalled Parliament because 172 people had arrived in this country. On any day there are probably more refugee applicants at the Toronto airport than there were in that situation; except that the ones that come in every now and then do not happen to make news the way these 172 people did.
It left me to conclude that we were not reacting to the incident, we were not reacting to the 172 people, but we, this House, more particularly the government, were reacting to the television news of some days before. That is not a good way to govern. It is a pretty sad way to govern actually.
I also remember the original telecast when the people of the community where they landed brought sandwiches to the people who were arriving on our shores. To me, that was the Canadian way of doing things. That is what I like to remember.
When we talk about immigration policy we sometimes forget, very conveniently, what happened some years before. I recently had a conversation with a good friend of Irish extraction. Together we were reminiscing about how and what some people must have thought when the Irish came to our shores during the potato famine. You can imagine at the time the people probably looked slightly different from others, a little shorter, red hair, many of them suffering from malnutrition, getting off the boat, many of them unwell from the trip, many who had suffered tremendously before the trip began. I am sure the day those boats arrived in Montreal from Ireland people must have said: "What are we accepting in this country?"
Looking at it in retrospect, some of the finest citizens of this country came from Ireland. It is easy for me to say that because my wife is Irish. The Prime Minister will no doubt agree with my sentiments. That is where his ancestors came from and the ancestors of many members of this House, no doubt.
In 10, 20 or 30 years from now maybe one of the Tamil people or their children will be members in this House, they will remember that their ancestors were on that boat and we will once again reflect upon what happened and ask: "Was it not interesting how our ancestors came from a situation that was very hard to live with, to a better country and started a better life?" Then we will wonder what people were doing 20 years ago, just as we are asking ourselves now, what were we doing in World

Government Orders
War II when we turned back boatloads of people, Jewish people, many of whom were going back to a probable death.
We should all remember that when we look at amending legislation for immigrants coming to this country. What is the objective we have in mind? All members tonight when we vote on this bill in 30 minutes from now should remember that.
This legislation before us has 128 clauses, 116 pages. My colleague, the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace had about 48 hours to read the length and complexity of this bill before the debate on second reading started. Is that the way to deal with one of the most complicated issues facing us today? Just 48 hours before debating it after the government presented it the government says: "Oh, this is urgent". If it was not urgent enough to present the text of the bill to us earlier, why should it be urgent that we deal with it now so expeditiously? If the government is serious about it, surely weeks and weeks before a copy of that bill should have at least been given to the opposition critics and, indeed, all members of this House for review.
Then the government says: "That is okay. You will have time in committee to listen to witnesses". That may be true, but let us remember how the parliamentary process works. First reading is the printing of the bill so members can see it. Second reading is supposed to be the time when we have read the bill and express to this House and the government whether we think this is good or bad legislation. Is it reasonable that all hon. members were given 48 hours to do that? If that was not bad enough, after one day of debate a government minister stood up and said: "Oh, that is okay. Now you have had only 48 hours to look at this bill of 128 clauses and 116 pages, but I have decided you cannot even debate it any more. You cannot even listen to each other any more because we are cutting this debate off today. We want to go on holidays tomorrow".
This may be a good enough reason for some, but it is not a good enough reason for the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, my colleagues or me.
If the government really wants the support of this House, as some government members indicated earlier in this debate, then why is it acting in such a way? I can
only conclude the government does not care whether this bill is adopted unanimously, on division, with dissent or with half of this Parliament against it. On an issue as important as this, the government should at least have tried to obtain the co-operation of other political parties in the House of Commons.
We have the ugliness of racism in our country. There are those of us who are concerned about this issue and do not want that ugliness in our country. The very least we can do is work together to the best of our ability and do our small part to eradicate some of these bad sentiments we have toward one another in this country. We can only do that with the good honest co-operation of everyone in the House. I am sure I speak on behalf of my colleagues when I say they will do their best to provide constructive amendments in committee, study the bill as thoroughly as possible and listen to witnesses from everywhere.
Let us remember we started debating this legislation at the 11th hour of the 11th day in a so-called emergency the government has known about since 1986. It is off to a bad start.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased and not pleased to have the opportunity to rise this evening to speak to Bill C-86, which is before the House this evening. I am pleased to have the opportunity to give a critique, but the critique is unprocessed, to follow on the words of my colleague who has just spoken. There has been very little opportunity to critique the substantive issues involved in this bill simply because, as my colleague has mentioned, there has been absolutely inadequate time with which to review the 128 clauses and 113 pages which comprise Bill C-86.
Certainly members in this House have been criticizing our immigration policies in Canada for many months. We have been requesting the federal government to bring in amendments to the present immigration law, but it is most unfair not only to all parliamentarians in this House but to the public in general across Canada. It is unfair to the people who engaged themselves on a volunteer basis to assist immigrant applications to this country, particularly the applications made by refugees, the most vulnerable of vulnerable immigrants to our country.
June 22, 1992

There is no reason to justify the curtailing of debate on this bill this evening. There is no reason that justifies bringing us to second reading and a vote this evening.
At second reading of any bill in this House all members of Parliament are asked to vote in principle their support or rejection of proposed legislation.
Because there has been insufficient time to analyse the content of this bill it really is not possible to adequately vote on the substantive principles of this legislation. On this side of the House we will be voting against this legislation on the principle that there simply was not enough time to review and reflect on the legislation before we could determine whether or not we would agree with the legislation in principle.
It is important to say, because the government always says when we get into this kind of debate that the opposition opposes just to oppose, that that is our role. That is not the case. When we have had the opportunity to reflect on legislation which has been presented there have certainly been occasions on which we have agreed to the principle of the legislation at second reading.
It is not only members of the opposition who reject the process of bringing this legislation before the House this evening. I would like to quote from just a few of those organizations which deal with refugee issues and also express their concern. We have received letters from various of the non-governmental organizations which address refugee issues in this country.
I wish to quote from a letter from the Anglican Church of Canada signed by Dorothy Davies Flindall. She states: "There needs to be adequate opportunity for all concerned groups to study the legislation and make substantive recommendations. This can only happen if the second reading of the bill is delayed to allow time for consideration of the bill. Our preliminary reading of the legislation indicates that some of the proposed changes have serious implications for the refugee community with whom we work. Therefore, on behalf of the Anglican Church of Canada, I urge you to delay the second reading of the bill until after there has been time for adequate consultation."
Government Orders
The Jesuit Centre in Toronto states, and I quote from its letter: "This bill poses some very serious problems and should not be rushed through Parliament, but subjected to close scrutiny and serious debate".
The Canadian Council of Churches states: "Refugees and non-governmental groups which work with refugees should have the right to participate in the decision-making which affects their lives and work". I am quoting Dr. Stuart E. Brown of the Canadian Council of Churches: "Churches are worried that the government may use the summer session of Parliament to speedily pass this complex legislation without allowing refugees, churches and other concerned groups adequate opportunities to reflect and to share their concerns".
As I said at the outset, we on the opposition side have many criticisms of Canada's current immigration legislation. Bringing forth this bill this evening in this period of economic difficulty in Canada is a difficult time. When Canada is suffering through difficult economic times, the level of intolerance and the lack of acceptance of immigrants and refugees into our country is very high. The times are fraught with misunderstanding and myths about immigrants and refugees to this country and their impact upon our economic, social and cultural life.
I believe it would have been much more appropriate for this government to have presented this legislation in a way that we could understand its substance and content and reflect more knowledgeably upon the same.
The government could have done a lot more to help the Canadian public to understand the realities of the benefits of immigration to our country. The government could have taken action to deal with myths and to set the record straight. The government has failed to put in place a communication strategy to inform and educate the public.
The government in dealing with immigration issues in the last few years that I have been here has looked at different types of merit and desirability for prospective immigrants.
It bases merit and desirability more and more each day on wealth. The richer a proposed immigrant and the more educated, the more desirable you are as an immigrant.

June 22, 1992
Government Orders
In my view, this is a blinkered approach to the necessity for immigration and the need for us to have open arms and accept refugees. Certainly we do not want the system abused, but does the abuse that exists in this country merit the new directions that policy is taking at this time?
In Canada it is very important as Canadians that we not only address the impact upon present immigration and refugee policies on the economic, social and cultural life of this country, but that we take a much broader global perspective of immigration and the growth of the numbers of refugees world-wide. I believe more and more the stories of refugees will become the stories for this decade and the next decade. We must understand the linkages of environmental degradation to increase refugee flows.
In the past, and I am afraid to some extent still, we in Canada think of refugees only in terms of politics. We must recognize that more and more we are seeing flows of what we would call economic refugees and the thing of the future will be the environmental refugees. I am reminded very strongly of a speech given by the head of state of Micronesia, a southeast Pacific nation, who was speaking about the environmental global warming impact upon his many-island nation.
Global warming has had the impact of raising the sea level around his nation by one and one-half metres. Micronesia has a population of 60 million people. As the sea levels rise around its islands, the people lose the land on which they can live and prosper and have any future. Where are 60 million people going to go if they cannot stay in Micronesia because of the effects of environmental degradation? They are going to look to other lands around the world.
The fact that we regard wealth and education and high educational achievement to be the only criteria that attract immigrants to us is really to neglect facing the realities of global and environmental degradation and the fact that we must encourage these people to develop and help their nations to grow and to promote sustainable development within their nations.
I regret that this House has not had sufficient time not only to address the substantive issues in Bill C-86 but to review Bill C-86 in the context of the larger immigration issues which face not only Canada but the world at large.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Miiliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to participate in this debate, however briefly this evening. I would like to leave a couple of minutes for my colleague from Hamilton West who would like to address a couple of remarks on this important legislation.
I want to express my concern briefly on the failure of the legislation to deal with the important issue of adjustment programs for Canada's recent arrivals. In my own community of Kingston and the Islands where there is a significant and very important and very rich group of relatively recent immigrants to Canada, the situation in respect of language training in particular is very important and has caused a considerable problem. There is a need for enhanced language training. There is a need for better adjustment programs operated on a more consistent and regularly funded basis.
These are not dealt with in this legislation. This government has failed in this bill to deal with this issue in a meaningful way in this bill. It has produced a bill that obviously has taken some considerable time to put together and it has neglected a very important area for Canadian immigrants, an area that helps their adjustment to Canadian society. It helps them find jobs, it helps them find housing, it helps them with language difficulties upon arrival in this country. These are programs that are worth while from the point of view of integration into the fabric of Canadian society and all very important for the integration into Canadian society. Part of the problem that this bill apparently has sought to address is any negative reaction among other Canadians to recent immigrants. The easiest way to solve that problem it seems to me is through sensible adjustment programs. The bill fails to deal with that important issue.
Second, it gives the government considerable power to determine where people will live in Canada, a power hitherto unknown to our immigration system. I suggest it is regrettable because I think it may leave many persons living in communities where they have no relatives and no friends and where adjustment becomes an increasingly difficult problem for those people.
I am sony that my time is so short, but I know what is going to happen. The guillotine is going to fall at a quarter to ten because of this government's approach to legislation in this House. This bill was introduced less
June 22, 1992

than seven days ago, on Tuesday, June 16. By agreement there were three speakers on this bill on Friday. That was the first time it was debated. Very rarely, and let the record show this, is a bill debated at second reading so soon after its introduction in this House. It was introduced on Tuesday, so members of the public had a total of three days to digest the bill before it was called for debate in this House. It was called for debate on Friday. It has been called for debate today and the debate will end today on second reading. This bill will be shunted off to a committee which the government will then have meet to hear public input on this bill.
It has changed the rules in respect of legislative committees to reduce the impact of witnesses. Certain witnesses will not be allowed at legislative committees because of the new rules the government has adopted. It is an attempt to force this bill through Parliament without proper public input, without allowing the public its opportunity to express its views on this bill. I do not mean just the public as represented here in Parliament, but the public across the country who will want to read and study this bill, various groups that work with immigrants and immigrant groups themselves. Various ethnic bodies in this country will want to comment on this legislation. They are being denied an adequate opportunity to do so because of the indecent haste with which the government is moving to ram this bill down the throats of Canadians.
I have had reason to comment before on the government's abuse of the rules of this House and its use of time allocation and closure. I could go through the statistics, but in the interest of time, I will forgo that. This is, as the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace said in his speech on Friday, a disgusting abuse of the rules and the government should be thoroughly condemned for its approach.

Mr. Speaker, on behalf of my constituents in Hamilton West, I again say that I consider it a privilege to rise in this place to debate at second reading Bill C-86, amendments to the Immigration Act. I thank my colleague, the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands, for allowing me a couple of minutes as well to add the voice of my constituents through me to this debate.
Government Orders
Yes, this place, the House of Commons, is the highest court in the land, so each and every one of us on both sides of this House are lawmakers. But before we can rise in our place to lend support to or choose to reject a proposal that is being put forward by the government or any member in this place, we must be given the opportunity to reflect on what is presented. I pass this message along to the members across the way, but especially to my constituents who may be watching this very debate in their homes tonight or may read my remarks at a later time.
This is Bill C-86, the most revamped, revised, revisited immigration act of the Immigration Act since 1978. This bill is complex, 113 pages and 128 clauses. My time is short so I will not plead with the government across the way or the members across the way to be fair, to do what is right, to delay this vote. That plea I suspect will fall on deaf ears. I plead with Canadians who are watching this debate and who may read the remarks at a later time to write their member of Parliament. Write your member of Parliament and request a copy of Bill C-86. Have a look at what members of Parliament on this side of the House, in opposition, have only had less than 48 hours to look at and enter into strong debate in the House of Commons in order to revisit each one of 128 clauses to deal with a bill that is an incredible revamping and an incredible revisit.
This bill, of course, falls on its face in many areas. We are aware of that. We have heard debate this day on this bill and the greater use of regulation by the minister and the cabinet, matters that until now have been in a law, and are being transferred to regulation, reducing of course the power of Parliament.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: Pursuant to Standing Order 52(1), the House will now proceed to the consideration of the motion to adjourn the House for the purpose of discussing a specific and important matter requiring urgent consideration, namely the situation of the northern cod fishery in Newfoundland and Labrador and other parts of Atlantic Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian Tobin (Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte) moved:
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
That this House do now adjourn.
He said: Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise in my place to begin the emergency debate that was granted by the Speaker and to speak about the crisis in the fishery in Newfoundland and Labrador, in particular, but also in Atlantic Canada.
Let me say in rising to initiate this debate that I want to thank the Speaker of the House of Commons and the people who advise the Speaker for deciding to give Parliament an opportunity to conduct this debate.
Let me also thank the more than 60 members of Parliament who over the last four or five sitting days officially petitioned the Speaker to allow such an emergency debate to take place, including many of the members who are sitting here on this side of the House tonight.

June 22, 1992
I particularly want to say that this debate is in the name of all of those who believe that the crisis in the Atlantic fishery in general and in Newfoundland and Labrador in particular, has to be addressed. This debate is brought about by the hard work and determination of the member for Bonavista-Trinity-Conception, the member for Burin-St. George's, both of whom will participate in this debate tonight, the member for Gander-Grand Falls and the member for Labrador are both in their respective constituencies this evening, dealing with the crisis in the fishery in their own respective areas.
If there was ever a doubt whatsoever as to the need for this debate tonight, that doubt was dispelled this afternoon when the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans for Canada, the member for St. John's West, with whom all relevant members on this side of the House want to work, are willing to work, are compelled to work because of the gravity of the situation, we had the incredible spectacle of that minister saying, in essence: "What crisis? There is no crisis".
In answer to questions put to the minister by me and the member for Burin-St. George's, the minister said, and I should quote him to be exact. I quote from the record what the minister said in response to questions on the crisis in the gulf cod stock: "There is an acknowledged crisis in the northern cod stocks but on the gulf cod stocks-"
I put a fair question seeking information. The minister said: "There is not any immediate crisis that I know of in that particular stock at the present time, with the exception that we have had to restrict mobile gear vessels because of the size of the cod that were caught and because of some other activities which had to be discouraged".
The minister said there was not any immediate crisis that he knew of in that particular stock. Let us deal with the gulf cod stock, the forgotten cod stock, the cod stock in the region known as 4R and 3PN, the cod stock that is the fishery that begins off the southwest coast of Newfoundland in the riding of my friend and colleague, the member for Burin-St. George's, and that migrates all the way up through the gulf, all the way up the great northern peninsula. That is the gulf cod stock.
The minister says that stock is not in crisis. Let us examine the record. The record is that approximately 10 days ago the minister's own department conducted a test fishery in the gulf cod stock. It went out itself to conduct a test in the fishery to find out what kind of fish if any were being caught.
What was discovered as recently as within the last two weeks? The department discovered that 80 per cent of the fish being caught in the gulf, fully 80 per cent, were pre-spawners.
Non-Newfoundlanders or non-Atlantic Canadians are asking: "What does that mean?" That means that 80 per cent of the fish being caught were not yet mature enough or old enough to reproduce, and if those fish are caught now before they are able to reproduce it means the stock is wiped out. It means it is fished to commercial extinction.
That is not my test. That is not the union's test. That is not the fishermen's test. That is not the media's test. That is the minister's own department that conducted a test within the last 10 days which showed that fully 80 per cent of the fish being caught were under 18 inches.
In the words of anybody who knows anything about the fishery, to catch a fish under 28 inches is a slaughter, a criminal slaughter of the resource. That is the size of the fish being caught and that is one of the reasons the minister moved to restrict the activities of the mobile fleet in the gulf.
The minister says there is no crisis, but I have in my hand the report of William Steele for the Department of Fisheries and Oceans, for the minister. The report is dated December 1990. What is the conclusion of the report? Let us deal with facts tonight, not with fiction, not with opinion, not with commentary, not with rhetoric. The report was done as a background paper for the working group report on groundfish commissioned by the minister. What does the report say?

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: I would not know about it.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
The minister says from across the way: "I would not know about it". I hope he does know about it.
The report states at page 11 under conclusion: "The cod fishery in western Newfoundland is in a crisis. The fixed gear fishery in western Newfoundland is at a point
June 22, 1992

of no return if there is no strategy to rebuild the cod stocks in the near future."
I could quote pages and pages from this report to show the extent of the crisis that the minister says does not exist, but that is sufficient for the moment.
Let me then pick up a copy of the Marshall report, also commissioned about a year ago by this minister. It was conducted by Jack Marshall, former area manager for federal fisheries in western Newfoundland, the area manager responsible for the gulf cod stock, the stock of which I now speak. What does he say in response to the minister's claim this afternoon that there is no crisis? What does Jack Marshall say, the senior official in the region?
He states, and I am quoting directly from the executive summary of the report: "The cod fishery in western Newfoundland, southern Labrador is in a crisis mainly because the landings are the lowest on record. Employment and income levels have fallen and impacts are highly concentrated in the fixed gear sector. If present trends continue the fishery could collapse completely. Therefore new strategies are needed to rebuild and maintain stocks". We have started with the results of a test fishery done 10 days ago. The results are a disaster. We have had the report of William Steele done in December 1990, a year and a half ago. It says there is a crisis and we are headed for disaster. We have the report of the area commissioner, Jack Marshall, a report done about a year ago. It says the fisheries is in crisis and we need new direction or we are headed for the ultimate disaster.
Then we pick up the latest study. This study which I doubt the minister has yet seen-if he has not seen it I will provide him with a copy-was commissioned by the Central and Northern Community Futures Committees of the great northern peninsula. These groups are funded by the federal government to look at their current economic circumstances and to examine alternatives to the current downturn in the fisheries.
In fact the April 1992 report is called "The Assessment of the Fisheries Downturn on the Great Northern Peninsula Confidential Interim Progress Report." All of the analysis contained in this report is by Canning & Pitt Associates of St. John's. All of the data flows from the data banks of the department of fisheries, the minister's
department. It is not opinion. It is not commentary. It is not hearsay. It is not rhetoric. It is raw data as recorded by the minister's department.
And what does this report say? What does it tell us? Let us review a couple of pages. It tells us that the total landings of all species by weight of fish on the great northern peninsula has dropped from 90 million pounds in 1987 to less than 50 million pounds in 1991. From 90 million to 50 million total weight of all species over a four-year period. That is a dramatic free fall in the total weight of landings of all species.
What does the same report say about the total landings of cod? It says the total landings of cod on the great northern peninsula over the same period of time-and the minister knows these figures-have dropped from in excess of 90 million pounds of cod landed on the great northern peninsula, cod from the gulf cod stock, to just over 30 million pounds. That is a 67 per cent decline in a few scant years. And the minister says there is no crisis.
Let us turn to another page of this recent report. What does this report which is aimed exclusively at the gulf cod stock at the great northern peninsula say in conclusion about the state of that stock?
The region is currently facing-
That word comes up again.
-a crisis in its fishing industry, and if fundamental changes are not made, the situation is bound to get much worse very quickly. At the present rate of resource decline there will be virtually no cod fishery on the great northern peninsula within a few years. Though higher prices have buoyed up the fishery during the past five years, this cannot continue.
It says:
Within households of fishermen and plant workers, the economic effects have undermined personal security and self-worth and increased dramatically family stress-This crisis, which the study terms of reference call the "fisheries downturn," has been in the making for at least 10 years. Even though it has not been sudden, it has been profound, pervasive, and greater than in areas of the province where the drop has been more abrupt and therefore more dramatic.
The report is clearly telling us something different from what the minister of fisheries stood in the House this afternoon during Question Period and told us, that there is no crisis in the gulf cod fishery, that there is no sense of panic in the Gulf of St. Lawrence in the great northern peninsula, that there is no sense of dislocation, no sense of 500 years of collective history and culture being suddenly crushed, vapourized, at the blink of an

June 22, 1992
eye it almost appears to those living in those communities.
When the minister says that, he is showing an incredible degree of insensitivity. The minister is not a stupid man. There is nothing stupid about this minister. This minister is not a minister to waste words. It is not by accident the minister stands in his place in spite of all the evidence I just put before this House and says: "There is no crisis".
That is what scares the people of the great northern peninsula. That is why there were 1,000 people out in St. Anthony last week to say we are here. We exist. We will not go away and we will not disappear. That is why on Thursday there is going to be 1,000 or 2,000 or 3,000 more out in Plum Point to say we are here, we exist, and we will not go away just because the minister says there is no crisis on the great northern peninsula.
What people fear, quite frankly, is this government has begun to gear up its advertising machinery, its propaganda machinery, and I want the minister to tell me that is not true. The government is about to wipe away all of the people, all of the fishermen, all of the plant workers, all of the communities that depend upon the gulf cod stock.
This minister has decided he is going to declare a moratorium on the northern cod stock. He is going to bring in some kind of compensation for those he claims are directly affected.
For the inshore fishermen of Bonavista-Trinity-Conception or for the inshore fishermen who reside in the riding Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte, or for the inshore fishermen who exist along the southwest coast in the riding of the member for Burin-St. George's we are not going to declare a moratorium. We are not even going to recognize a crisis. We are going to abandon those people and let the department of welfare or somebody else look after them. That is the plan of the minister of fisheries.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: Shame.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
What is happening? The member opposite, the parliamentary secretary to the minister of fisheries, may think this is funny. Let me ask him this: does he
think it is funny that in a St. Anthony, Newfoundland plant that several years ago employed 700 people there is nobody working today?
Does he think it funny that in the Port aux Choix plant that normally employs 580 people there are only 100 working today? Does he think it funny that in the Anchor Point plant that normally employs 237 there are only 50 working today? In Brig Bay that employed 137 there is none working today? That in Conche that employed 78 there is only one working today? That in Main Brook that employed 60 there is none working today. That in St. Julien's that employed 32 there is none working today. In Croque a plant that employed 34 there is none working today.
In a New Ferrolle plant there is only a handful of maintenance people where once 200 people worked. In Englee where 323 worked only one maintenance person is employed today. In Raleigh where there were 60 workers there is none today. In Bide Arm where there were 130 workers, none today. In Cow Head there were 65 workers, none today. In Roddickton there were 157, none today. In Savage Cover there were 80 workers, none today. In Green Island Cover where 150 worked there is none today. Bear Cove, none, Cook's Harbour, none, Bartlett's Harbour, two out of 35 and Flowers Cove none out of 65.
Does the parliamentary secretary think that is funny? Does the minister continue to insist there is no crisis in the fishery on the great northern peninsula?
, Mr. Belsher: On a point of order. The hon. member keeps saying does the parliamentary secretary think that is funny? I do not think it is the least bit funny. I have been listening here to every word he has said and I have not been ridiculing either.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: We do not find you funny either.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: To put the record clear that is not a point of order and the hon. member knows it.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, if the parliamentary secretary tells me he does not find that funny I am reassured. It means we have made a beginning with the parliamentary secretary. Now we have got to work on the minister of fisheries, the member for St. John's West
June 22, 1992

who insists in the face of the evidence, and I submit if we were in a court of law that would be sufficient evidence.
In the face of the evidence the minister has now got to admit that, indeed, we do have a dramatic crisis in the gulf fishery, the gulf cod stocks.
The minister will be the first to rise and say -and I will be the first to agree with him -that there is a crisis in the northern cod stock, that the northern cod stock has been devastated. In fact, what is frightening about that stock is what we do not know. The lack of scientific evidence that exists for us to make enlighted, intelligent, and knowledgeable decisions about how to manage that stock.
The minister will rise and tell us he is seriously considering placing a moratorium on that stock. I agree with him. You know why? Because there has been a 60 per cent decline in landings from the northern cod stock.
In fact, if you go back far enough it has been greater than that. My friend from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception reminded me before I began my speech that in 1968 there were 815,000 tonnes and by last year it was down to
127,000	tonnes. Just in the last four or five years, there has been a 60 per cent decline in landings in the northern cod stock.
I agree with the minister that is a crisis. I agree with the minister that he has to be prepared to compensate those who have been affected. If he agrees that a 60 per cent decline is a crisis, I ask him why then is a 67 per cent decline in the gulf cod stock not equally and similarly a crisis?
I want to put an interesting proposition to this minister. I want to remind him of something. At the end of the day, when it comes to the northern cod stock the area referred to as 2J-3KL, the eastern coast of Canada, the east coast of Labrador if you could picture the map of the east coast of Canada going off into the Atlantic, when it comes to that cod stock, the Government of Canada can always say: "We did our best to manage it well but offshore foreign vessels did not play the game". Foreign vessels overfished as the minister has said and foreign nations have to cease their fishing as we have. The minister pointed out that there is no point having a moratorium on Canadian fishing efforts if foreign fishing efforts continue. The minister is right.
The minister can always claim that despite his best efforts somebody can always trip him up in his management of the northern cod stock and to some extent there is truth to that.
We have a unique opportunity in the gulf. The gulf cod stock and the Gulf of St. Lawrence is surrounded completely by Canada. It is the only major coastline of the east coast of Canada and the only major cod stock that is not adjacent to the offshore and is not bounded by the 200-mile limit. It is the only stock in which we do not have foreign vessels just outside our 200-mile limit operating freely and at their own will. It is entirely enclosed and bounded by the provinces of Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, P.E.I. and western Newfoundland. It is totally in our control. Therefore we have nobody but ourselves to blame or to praise for any wrong that is done or any right that occurs.
I submit to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans that the minister ought to grab on to the gulf cod stock, to that cod stock that migrates within the Gulf of St. Lawrence. It migrates from southwest Newfoundland to the great northern peninsula. He could use that gulf stock as a pilot project to show what Canadians when they are in control can do to rebuild the fishery. That is within the power of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans to undertake if he has the imagination and the courage and the support of his colleagues in cabinet to do.
I want to say that we on this side want to support the minister in any attempt to rebuild the stocks. We know that tough decisions have to be made. It would be damn easy for us to sit on this side of the House and just say to the minister: "It is your fault. You fix it up. We have nothing more to contribute". We are prepared to stand with him and make some of the tough decisions.
We are not prepared to stand silent. We are not prepared to say to our constituents as Parliament closes for the summer recess: "You will not be heard. The reality of the desperate circumstances you live in will not be talked about and we will not call upon the minister tonight to give this House a commitment that when it comes to those displaced by a reduction in the northern cod stocks and by a reduction in the gulf cod stock that this government is going to provide the kind of short-

June 22, 1992
term and long-term economic assistance that the Prime Minister himself committed himself to on behalf of the government in this House last week".
I ask the minister when he comes to his feet to acknowledge that we have a crisis. I ask the minister to reach out and to accept that those on this side are willing to work with him, to share some of the burden of the tough decisions, but he has to have a plan of action. It is no plan simply to say there is no crisis and therefore there is nothing I propose to do. That we cannot and will not accept on this side of the House.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I did not hear the minister say this afternoon that there was no crisis in the Atlantic cod fishery. I was not here but I heard he is being quoted all across Newfoundland as saying this. I hope the minister is able to stand up this evening and tell us he was totally misunderstood by those who heard him in the House and all over Newfoundland this afternoon. If the minister himself does not recognize there is a crisis, then we are truly in great trouble. Certainly this species could very well become extinct.
I have told the story before of being told by the manager of the biggest fishing company in the area that within five years we could be looking for the last codfish off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland. That was told to me three years ago. We are getting perilously close to the extinction of the species if the minister himself is not aware just how serious the matter is.
I had a telephone conversation with Clyde Newhook, our candidate in the Ferryland constituency by-election, to see what he knew about whether or not there truly is a crisis in the cod fishery in that area. He told me it is a total and complete failure everywhere. Perhaps he was exaggerating, but he did talk about three boats that went out in the past three days. They went 140 miles out from the southern shore and 70 feet of net was hauled three times. Fifteen cod were all they got for their effort. He told me of the inshore cod fishery at his own Ferryland constituency. Over three weeks of fishing there was no sign of any fish. A few fishermen who did catch some found them to be very small at 10 inches long. The fishermen there are saying if there is to be a closure, impose it immediately while there is still some hope of achieving something before any more damage is done.
In the offshore fishery in the 3N-0 district the few cod
being caught are full of spawn. We are destroying what little is left of the spawning stock in that area.
The only answer is to quit fishing. It is drastic. I suggested that 18 months ago in this House, and of course no attention was paid to it. I did not expect it would be.
If we do quit fishing, we have to provide for the fish shore workers, the inshore fishermen and the trawler-men. I think Canada is ready to do that.
The minister or anyone else should agree there is a crisis, instead of saying there really is not one right now through lack of knowledge or whatever. They should go to the government and say that, we are liable to wipe out the codfish as a species in the North Atlantic. We need money to pay these people not to fish. There are useful things that can be done, but we have to stop today or tomorrow and no longer. The damage is being done every day those fishermen are out there trying to find fish.
It cannot be like it was when they closed down the salmon fishery. The compensation to those who got out of the industry was paid on the basis of their last three years' catch, which was the worst three years in the history of the industry. We cannot pay these fishermen on the basis of the cod they have caught in the past three years or they will be getting next to nothing.
It is not just the cod, it is the capelin, the primary fish bait or the primary fish food. So far all of the capelin that are showing up, according to Mr. Newhook, are one-half the size of mature fish. The fishermen who see these capelin do not know the reason and I suspect the minister does not either and that is part of the problem. We have to find out why. What does it mean? What does it mean to the future of the capelin?
I have talked about the seals before and I am prepared to do it again. The population seems to be exploding in all the areas where they are not looking for fish. They are in quantities never seen before. There have been arguments as to what the seals are eating and whether or not they eat cod or the cod food. They are certainly part of the food chain, and we know they are not eating corn flakes. Is it already too late to save the northern cod stock?
June 22, 1992

The flounder stock seems low. We have talked about the nose and tail and the jurisdiction. It is time to do something about that. I think if we set an example we would not have to get tough with these people. We should say to these people this is serious. We are in danger of wiping out the species, Canadians are going to quit fishing in those areas. Quit fishing for cod. We want you to join with us in a management plan for the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. Co-operate with us to make sure there is no cod fishing in those areas as well as within the 200-mile limit.
Let us challenge them to show that they too want to save that stock for future generations rather than wiping it all out in a matter of one or two years.
Mr. Newhook told me about visiting families in his constituency where unemployment insurance ran out May 15. They are afraid they will not be able to feed their families. They are trying to get social welfare, but something more has to be done for these people, something that will encourage them not to fish.
The minister and others have said before that we do not really know what is going on. When I travelled to Europe two or three years ago with the fisheries committee under external affairs and talked to these people from the European Community about the alleged overfishing, they said that we did not have sufficient scientific evidence to prove our case. We had not proven our case to them. They said that we do not really know what was going on there.
The minister himself has suggested on several occasions that perhaps it had something to do with the high incidence of ice. The waters were so cold this year and maybe the fish went somewhere else. That could be but we do not know where they are. If they are somewhere else, let us find them. Before we catch another cod, let us try to find out where the survivors are if there are survivors. If we cannot find them, then until we do find some, we have to assume that the population is getting dangerously low and take some desperate steps. The thing we can do most effectively and immediately is to cease cod fishing, compensate the people who are going to lose their livelihood immediately and reasonably and persuade all other nations fishing in those areas to join with us.
We must mount a tremendous scientific campaign to try to find out what is happening. Talk and listen to the fishermen. Some of those people have a lot of knowledge. It is their livelihood and some of them know more than others. Some of them know more than people who are here in Ottawa trying to run the industry and run departments.
Let us find out and let us prove to the world that we are doing our best to make sure we know exactly what is happening in that area of the world, what has caused the deterioration in the quantities of cod, the legendary quantities that were there a few hundred years ago. We have all heard stories about how you could walk on the cod, how you could scoop them up by the netful, no problem at all.
It is not a case of laying blame. We know this has been going on for a number of years. There have been Liberal governments and there have been Tory governments. That does not matter right now. We can worry about those thing during the election campaign. Right now we have to arrive at a common decision that it is Canada's responsibility to do everything possible to save that species.
I am convinced that means talking and listening to people. From what I have seen on site, I am convinced that it means stopping cod fishing immediately and totally, demonstrating to the world this is the way to save the species. We have to prove to the world we are going to put the scientists to work who can accomplish anything, who can show us anything, who can tell us anything and teach us anything. We are going to find out what is happening and we are going to manage that resource in the way in which it should be managed, to have it as a perpetual resource for mankind and for the cod themselves.
It is serious. It is serious or we would not be doing it at this time of night. It is serious or the Speaker would not have agreed to this emergency debate this evening. A lot rests on this minister. He can argue and he can present other points of view. He can present other reports, no doubt, and tell us it is not as bad as we are led to believe it is and make us think that perhaps it is going to be better if we are patient.
I submit to the House that he does not know. The evidence to me is so overwhelming there is a serious problem that it is his responsibility to close down the cod fishing and do whatever is necessary to rebuild that stock so the species does not become extinct. He has a responsibility and an opportunity to turn back the tide, to undo the damage that has been done by 10, 12 or more

June 22, 1992
years of Liberal and Tory governments, and to preserve that species. I hope he does not fail us and the cod.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this is an emergency debate on the fisheries situation on the east coast of Canada.
If I might just review some of the ground, it was at the beginning of June that the NAFO Scientific Council at our request met with CAFSAC, Canadian fisheries scientists, to review the findings and all the additional research we have had done in the last year or two years with reference to the state of the northern cod, the 2J-3KL cod known as the northern cod.
The northern cod is approximately 40 per cent of the value of all landings of fish in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador. It is 11 per cent to 13 per cent of the value of all landings of fish in Atlantic Canada. It is a very important stock and probably the main reason Newfoundland was settled in the first place. It is a stock of fish very close to the hearts, minds and consciousness of Newfoundlanders.
We had referred this to the NAFO Scientific Council. It spent several days reviewing all this evidence with Canadian scientists. They agreed with the findings of CAFSAC, the Canadian scientists, and they came to certain conclusions which I am sure the House would be quite familiar with. I have the report here. Anyone can ready it. At pages 31 and 32 we see the conclusions. It stated that the age three biomass between 520,000 and
640.000	tonnes and, even more disturbing, the age seven plus biomass-that is the spawning biomass-between
72.000	and 110,000 tonnes were currently at or near the lowest levels ever observed for this stock. The fishery in 1992 would be dominated by only two year classes: those of 1986 and 1987. The limited information available indicated that the 1988 year class was below average and was currently estimated to be about the level of the weak 1983 and 1984 year classes.
Then it continued on page 32 by indicating that it therefore recommended that fishing mortalities should be reduced in 1992 from the levels of recent years.
We had already reduced the total allowable catch for this stock from 266,000 tonnes in the year 1988 down to
120.000	tonnes in February 1992. We set it in December 1991 at 185,000 for this year. There have been reductions in every year since 1988 because of revised estimates, forecasts and projections by our scientists. There have been very severe reductions already up to this time.
It recommended again that fishing mortality should be further reduced. It said that at FO.l, that is the fishing mortality rate of 0.25, the total catch should not exceed
91.000	tonnes. Given the uncertainties in the assessments and the obvious requirement for caution, it would be wise to consider the FO.l catch to be at the lower value of 50,000 tonnes. It should not be forgotten that at least 20,000 to 25,000 tonnes appeared to have already been caught in 1992.
That is its main conclusion. It says that the stock was at the lowest level it had been since it started observing the
stock.
I do not have the time tonight, but I can point out that it is at the same level as it was in 1977, which was the previous lowest level for this stock in its known scientific history. Obviously there is a serious problem with the 2J-3KL northern cod stock.
After the NAFO Scientific Council report came out, I said that I would have to review again the total allowable catch for northern cod for the year 1992. Already it had been reduced by 35 per cent from 185,000 tonnes to
120.000	tonnes. However, in light of this further information from the NAFO Scientific Council in CAFSAC, I would have to review the situation again with a view to either a lower total allowable catch or perhaps even a moratorium on the hatching of the northern cod if I concluded that the stock was threatened so that it might disappear if there were not a moratorium. This was obviously an option that had to be looked at as well. That was all said in the first week of June.
I said that during the month of June and early July, certainly during the month of June, we would be observing the northern cod stock hatched in the inshore fishery. We stopped the offshore fishery for northern cod last
June 22, 1992

February. There has not been an offshore Canadian fishery for the northern cod since last February. We wanted to see what happened in the inshore fishery during June and what cod fish were being caught.
The disturbing thing about the state of the northern cod is its age distribution. There are two good year classes, 1986 and 1987, followed by poor year classes preceded by poor year classes. The classes of 1986 and 1987 have not yet reached spawning age, which is the age of seven. They are only five and six years of age. We had to be careful this year not to allow these two year classes to be caught up this year and next year before they can spawn or else the future of the stock will be threatened. This is what we are watching for. This is now a problem greater than it was in 1977 because of the age distribution of these year classes of the cod.
This is based on evidence. The scientists examine the cod that are caught. They can tell you the distribution of the age classes by counting the rings in the inner ear. This is based on firm evidence that the age distribution of this cod stock is very peculiar. It is based on 1986 and 1987 year classes and the classes since have been very poor. That is why I am contemplating whether or not there should be a moratorium or a further reduction in the TAC.
A further reduction of TAC would still have serious consequences. Even last year, which was a bad year in the fishery, 127,000 tonnes of northern cod was caught by Canadians. The TAC was 190,000 and we caught 127,000 tonnes. Just in 1990 in the inshore fishery alone in Newfoundland we caught 114,000 tonnes of the northern cod. It has not been all bad years leading up to this year. V/e should not pretend that there has been complete decimation over the last two, three, four, five or six years in the fishery. There have been good fisheries and poor fisheries. In 1990 there was a superb inshore fishery in the northern cod. Last year the inshore only caught
75,000	to 78,000 tonnes. It is not all complete disaster in the last few years fishery. That is still the position.
The inshore fishery can come early or late in June or it can come in July. We do not know what the inshore cod fishery is going to be like yet in Newfoundland. Naturally everybody fears it is not going to be too good. We know that the capelin is late arriving. We know that the capelin
that are out there are small, stunted, weenie, little creatures. They are not the size that you can sell in the Japanese market or anywhere else as yet. We know there are problems with capelin and with the northern cod.
Some time in the next week or 10 to 12 days I have to make a decision and I will as to whether we are going to have a moratorium on the northern cod fishery or not or whether we are going to reduce the TAC from 120,000 tonnes for this year to something much less. I will have to make that decision and I will not hesitate to make the decision. I have already said that I am going to make the decision based on the survival of the species. Whatever is necessary for the northern cod to survive, that will be my decision. When that decision is made, whether it is a moratorium or whether it is another severe reduction in the total allowable catch, we will be announcing a program of assistance for those affected by the state of that stock, who are affected by that decision whether it is fishermen, trawlermen or plant workers, the people involved will receive assistance.
If there is a moratorium then the assistance will be based on that. If it is a reduction to 50,000 tonnes or
70,000	tonnes that imposes hardship, it will be some kind of plan to help in that eventuality. I helped them last year. The government helped them last year. The Prime Minister helped them last year.
Last year they got ice compensation when we had a fantastic ice year with ice still coming down in August. We did not hesitate to help them. Last year we also helped the fisherpeople of Newfoundland and Atlantic Canada with a catch failure program, an emergency job creation projects and a gear-up program. The like of the assistance we have rendered to the fishermen of Atlantic Canada has never been heard of before in Canada. We do not need anyone from the opposition or from anywhere else to tell us that we have obligations we should meet. We have met them and we are going to continue to meet them.
We have worked night and day to get fish plants opened that were closed, like Galtus, Grand Bank, programs of economic development and diversification outside the fishery, programs of diversification inside the fishery. We do not need any tongue wagging or finger shaking at us because whenever called upon, we have

June 22, 1992
met the situation we were called upon to deal with and that is going to continue.
We have set up a task force, an incomes and adjustment for the Atlantic fishery, headed by Richard Cashin, the president of the largest fishermen's union in the country with five other people from the trade, the unions and universities.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: One of whom is in the gallery right now, Professor Darby.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext:
Professor Darby is in the gallery. He is a member of this task force. As a matter of fact the task force is working in Ottawa this week. We cannot produce a rabbit out of a hat for our immediate situation. We will be expecting them to give us advice on the longer term aspects of this situation. A whole series of steps have been put in place.
Hon. members opposite want to have an emergency debate. I understand that. They want to be on the record that they are concerned. Sure, we know they are concerned. I can see they are concerned. If they are not concerned, why are they members of Parliament? Why do they seek to get elected? Why are they here if they are not concerned? I will agree they are concerned and we on this side of the House are concerned. The member for St. John's West is concerned. The member for St. John's East is concerned. Naturally, we are concerned. We understand why they wanted an emergency debate. It is premature because I have not made a decision yet.
It is premature because I have not announced a decision that I have not made yet. It is premature because I do not have my colleagues agreeing on this. I am working night and day on exactly what program of assistance I think should be put in place in the eventuality that I have to make this or that decision.
I am seeing the Prime Minister tomorrow morning to review this with him. I know very well I will have his support. He has already indicated in the House that he is waiting for me to bring forward a plan that he can support. Why will he support it? Because he is humane. He is humanitarian. He has a big heart. He is concerned. He is eager. He knows why this is necessary. Much maligned, but there has never in the history of Canada been a Prime Minister or a member of this House who did more for the people of Newfoundland and Labrador than Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES NORTHERN COD FISHERY
speechtext: Absolutely right. He made a promise and he kept it.
